questions.text:
1. A 20-year-old boy presented with yellowish discoloration of the skin and sclerae for the last 3 days. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He had a viral fever one week ago which has now resolved. His investigations are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
This patient has a short history of jaundice, which appeared only during a period of stress (viral fever). The lab reports show increased unconjugated bilirubin (normal 0.2-0.8 mg/dL) and normal AST and ALT levels. All this points toward a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, fatigue, or alcohol use. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-glucuronyltransferase production. This causes a reduction in the liver's ability to conjugate bilirubin, thus causing unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The total bilirubin value is usually < 3 mg/dL. 

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and bilirubinuria. Patients are asymptomatic and other laboratory tests are normal. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment in the lysosomes of the centrilobular hepatocytes.

Option B: Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but has a milder presentation. Conjugated bilirubin levels are elevated. The liver biopsy does not show pigment deposition.

Option D: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is another syndrome that has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It is of two types, with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in infancy.

questions.text: 2. A 32-year-old woman working in a night-shift call center presents with complaints of generalized weakness and fatigue for the past 3 months that has progressively become worse. She says it gets worse towards the morning, and she feels better in the evenings after a period of rest. She has unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the right eye. Following evaluation, she is started on tablet edrophonium for the treatment of her condition. Which of the following autoantibody is not associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) but not with myasthenia gravis.

The patient experiences generalized weakness, which progresses and becomes worse after exertion. The presence of unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the right eye along with generalized weakness is suggestive of a diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.

Treatment for myasthenia gravis involves:

* Symptomatic therapy: Anticholinesterase agents and pyridostigmine are generally started as the first-choice medication.

* Long-term immunomodulatory management: Glucocorticoids such as prednisone, along with additional immunosuppressive agents like azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, and cyclosporine. These are used when patients are significantly symptomatic despite being on pyridostigmine.

* Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment.

* Surgical approach: Thymectomy

Preferred drug for diagnosis: Edrophonium

Pearl PM1844: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: 3. A 40-year-old male who visited North America presents with low-grade fever, chest pain, cough, and hemoptysis. Radiological examination of the chest reveals cavity formation with lung abscess. Culture from the abscess at 37°C, shows the appearance given in the image. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of travel to North America suggests the diagnosis of pulmonary blastomycosis caused by Blastomyces fungi. 

Blastomycosis is a chronic infection caused by a dimorphic fungus called Blastomyces dermatitidis. It is characterized by the formation of suppurative and granulomatous lesions in the lungs and skin. It is most common in North America and is also called North American Blastomycosis.

Humans are infected by the inhalation of spores in contaminated soil.

Blastomycosis can present in three forms:

* Pulmonary infection - can be asymptomatic, focal or diffuse consolidation, military lesions or abscess formation. 

* Disseminated disease - can lead to multiple abscesses and has high fatality.

* Cutaneous disease over the skin of the face. Lesions may be a papule, around which secondary nodules develop and coalesce to form elevated ulcerative lesions. 

B. dermatitidis when cultured at 37°C shows thick-walled round yeast cells with a single broad-based bud.

Localized lesions are effectively managed with itraconazole for 6 months. Invasive or severe cases are treated with amphotericin B.

Other options:

Option B- Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus causing histoplasmosis. Infection is acquired by inhalation. Most infections are asymptomatic but infection of the reticuloendothelial system manifests as lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and anemia and it is highly fatal. 

Option C- Coccidiodes immitis is also a dimorphic fungus causing coccidiomycosis. Infection is acquired through inhalation of dust-containing spores of the fungus. Mostly they are asymptomatic and a self-limiting influenza-like fever termed valley fever or desert rheumatism develops in some individuals. The infection leads to lifetime immunity. 

Option D- Paracoccidiodes brasiliensis is again a dimorphic fungus causing paracoccidioidomycosis also termed South American blastomycosis. Infection is initially acquired by the inhalation of spores causing primary pulmonary infection. It spreads to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics by hematogenous spread resulting in ulcerative granulomas of the buccal and nasal mucosa.

Pearl PM2370: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

* Mycelial growth showing spherical spores, which are large (8-10 μm size) and thick-walled, with tubercular projections.

* Tiny oval yeast cells (2-4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 



2. Blastomyces: Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 



3. Coccidoides: Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20-80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 



4. Paracoccidioides: Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: 4. A patient presents with breathlessness and chest pain for 3 weeks. He had a URTI 4 weeks ago. ECG shows ST elevations and Troponin I is elevated. A biopsy of his heart is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with complaints of breathlessness and chest pain, and a biopsy showing lymphocytic infiltration in myocardial tissue, is suggestive of lymphocytic myocarditis.

The inflammatory process of the myocardium is termed myocarditis. Patients mostly present with fatigue, chest pain, cardiogenic shock, and even cardiac arrest. Viruses are the most common among the infectious causes of myocarditis. Endomyocardial biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis, and it shows diffuse, mononuclear, lymphocytic infiltration, as shown below.



Myocarditis begins with the direct invasion of an infectious agent(Most likely an enterovirus in this case from his URTI). It subsequently replicates within and around the myocardium, causing myonecrosis. This infiltration and replication of the infectious agent lead to the destruction of cardiac tissue. 

Myocarditis can also cause ST elevations and elevated troponins but should be distinguished from a myocardial infarction based on the duration of symptoms and past medical history. 

They are treated with supportive management. 

Other Options:

Option : Aschoff's bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence, they are also called caterpillar cells.

This condition classically occurs a few weeks after an episode of group A streptococcal pharyngitis or, less commonly, skin infections, and Aschoff's bodies are seen in the image below.



Option B: The myocarditis of Chagas disease has distinctive features of the parasitization of scattered myofibers by trypanosomes accompanied by a mixed inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils, lymphocytes, macrophages, and occasional eosinophils. The clusters of amastigotes cause swelling of individual myocardial fibers and create intracellular pseudocysts. There is focal myocardial cell necrosis accompanied by extensive, dense, acute interstitial inflammatory infiltration throughout the heart.

The image below shows the amastigotes within a myocyte (arrow) and the surrounding inflammatory response.



Option C- Myocardial infarction presents more acutely and not with symptoms occurring over 3 weeks. Additionally the history of URTI adds support to a diagnosis of myocarditis, rather than a MI

questions.text: 5. Which of the following proteins is responsible for the intercellular chemical signaling mechanism depicted in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows gap junctions between the signaling and target cells, and the protein responsible for the signaling is connexon.

Gap junctions are intercellular junctions that allow the passage of ions and smaller molecules between the cells. It permits rapid cell-to-cell spread of action potentials that provide for coordinated and smooth contraction. They are present in the intercalated discs, urinary bladder, ureter, uterus, and choroid plexus between the cells, etc.  

The functions of gap junctions are

* Passage of ions, sugars, amino acids, and other solutes with molecular weight up to about 1000 Da. It permits these substances to pass between the cells without entering the extracellular fluid. 

* Provide both chemical and electrical coupling between cells. 

The structural unit present in the gap junctions is connexons, made of subunits called connexins. These connexons determine the permeability and selectivity of these junctions. 

Mutations of the connexin have predisposed to conditions like arteriosclerosis, myoclonic epilepsy, idiopathic atrial fibrillation, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (X-linked), etc.



The different intercellular connections and their structural units are given below:

Intercellular connection Structural units
Tight junctions or zona occludens Occludins, claudins and junctional adhesion molecules
Gap junctions Connexons
Zona adherens Cadherins
Desmosome Cadherins like desmoglein
Hemidesmosome Integrins

questions.text:
6. Choose the correct statements about glucokinase.

* Located in β cells of the pancreas and helps in insulin release.

* Has a high affinity for glucose.

* Is induced by insulin.

* Inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate directly.

* Mutations in the glucokinase gene can lead to MODY.
questions.solution:
Glucokinase is located in pancreatic β cells and helps release insulin. It is also stimulated by insulin, leading to increased hepatic uptake of glucose and glycogen synthesis. Mutations in glucokinase can lead to maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY).

The enzyme responsible for glucose phosphorylation in liver and pancreatic β cells is glucokinase. It is located in the pancreatic beta cells and the liver (statement 1).  In the liver, its function is to remove glucose from the portal blood during the postprandial hyperglycemic state. This limits the amount of glucose available to the peripheral tissues, and enables glycogen synthesis and lipogenesis in the liver.

In pancreatic β cells, glucokinase detects the changes in blood glucose levels. If there is more glucose, more glucose-6-phosphate is produced by glucokinase, leading to increased glycolysis and ATP production. Increased ATP leads to the closure of ATP-sensitive potassium channels and insulin release. 

Compared to hexokinase, glucokinase has:

* High Km — has a lower affinity (statement 2) for glucose, and requires a higher concentration of glucose for its action.

* High Vmax — has a higher capacity to convert substrate into product.

Glucokinase is inhibited indirectly by fructose-6-phosphate. It is not inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate directly (statement 4), even though it is the end product of the reaction catalyzed by glucokinase. In the presence of fructose-6-phosphate, glucokinase binds tightly to its regulatory protein and is translocated to the nucleus, rendering it inactive. Glucokinase is stimulated by insulin (statement 3).

Mutations in the gene encoding glucokinase lead to maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) type 2, in which the patients have impaired insulin secretion and hyperglycemia.

The differences between hexokinase and glucokinase are summarized below:

  Hexokinase Glucokinase
Location  Most tissues except liver and pancreatic cells Liver and pancreatic β cells
Km Lower (Higher affinity) Higher (Lower affinity)
Vmax Lower (Decreased capacity) Higher (Increased capacity)
Induced by insulin No Yes
Inhibited by Glucose-6-phosphate Fructose-6-phosphate

questions.text: 7. A 3-day-old newborn baby was found dead in the waste bin of the hospital. An autopsy was conducted at the request of the police to know if the baby was stillborn or live-born. During the autopsy, the abdomen was opened to visualize the level of the diaphragm. The baby will be considered live-born if the diaphragm is:

choices.text: At the level of the 3rd rib
At the level of the 6th rib
At the level of the 5th rib
At the level of the 4th rib

questions.solution:
The baby will be considered live-born if the diaphragm is at the level of the 6th rib.

During the postmortem examination, the abdomen should be opened first before the thorax to note the highest point of the diaphragm.

* The diaphragm is at or above the 4/5th rib: Respiration has not occurred

* The diaphragm is at or below the 6th/7th rib: Respiration has occurred.

Autopsy findings to differentiate before and after respiration:

Autopsy findings Before respiration After respiration
1. Shape of chest Flat, 1-2cm less than the abdominal circumference  Dome or arch-shaped
2. Position of the diaphragm At or above the 4th/5th rib At or below the 6th/7th rib
3. Lung margins Sharp Rounded
4. Lung consistency Dense, firm, non-crepitant Soft, spongy, elastic, crepitant
5. Lung weight 1/70 of body weight 1/35 of body weight
6. Lung color Uniformly reddish-brown or bluish-red Mottled or marbled appearance
7. Hydrostatic test Specific gravity is 1040-1050 Specific gravity is 940
8. Stomach Contains only mucin and sink in water Contains mucin and air. Floats in water
9. Middle ear Contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue Air replaces the embryonic tissue


 

Other tests for live birth:

* Breslau’s first life test (also known as Hydrostatic test/ Raygat’s test)- the organ tested is the lung. It is based on the ability of the lung to sink or float in water.

* Breslau's second life test: It is based on the air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water to check if it floats or sinks.

* Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth.

* Fodere’s test – Based on the increase in the weight of lungs due to increased blood flow after birth.The weight of the unrespired lung is 30-40 g whereas the weight of respired lung is 60-66 g.

* Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.

* Unrespired lungs - 1/70

* Respired lungs - 1/35

Pearl PM1326: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

* Atelectasis

* Pulmonary edema

* Pneumonia

* Congenital syphilis

* Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration

* More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration

* Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

* Putrefied foetus

* Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

* Fetus is monstrous

* Fetus is macerated or mummified

* Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation

* Stomach contains milk

* Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: 8. A multiparous woman presents in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterus appears asymmetrical and fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. On fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and on the pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. All of them are true in this condition except

choices.text: Prematurity is the most common cause
Dorsoposterior is the most common position

questions.solution:
The given examination findings are suggestive of a transverse lie and the false statement is dorsoposterior is the most common position. In transverse lie, dorsoanterior is the most common position.

The position is determined by the position of the back. There are 4 positions - dorsoanterior, dorsposterior, dorsosuperior and dorsoinferior. The position of the fetal head determines right or left. Left is more common. The likely fetal position that can cause arm prolapse is the dorsoposterior position.

The most common cause of transverse lie is prematurity.

Other etiological factors are 

* Multiparity

* Twins especially in the second baby

* Hydramnios

* Contracted pelvis

* Placenta previa

* Pelvic tumors

* Malformations of the uterus

* Intrauterine death

Clinically, fundal height is less than the period of amenorrhea. The fundal grip demonstrates an impalpable fetal pole. The lower pole of the uterus is empty in the pelvic grip.

Management is an external cephalic version and if it fails or is contraindicated, a cesarean section should be done.

questions.text: 9. Identify the incorrect statement regarding carbapenems.

choices.text: They act by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis.
Enterococcus faecium is resistant to imipenem.
Cilastatin is administered along with meropenem.
Ertapenem has longer half life than imipenem.

questions.solution:
Cilastatin, a dehydropeptidase inhibitor, is administered with imipenem (and not meropenem) to prevent its inactivation by renal dehydropeptidase.

Meropenem, doripenem, and ertapenem are resistant to inactivation by the enzyme and hence do not need cilastatin.

Other options:

* Carbapenems are structurally related to beta-lactams and act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

* Enterococcus faecium, methicillin-resistant strains of staphylococci, Clostridium difficile, Burkholderia cepacia, and Stenotrophomonas maltophilia are resistant to imipenem.

* Ertapenem has longer half-life than imipenem, meropenem and can be given as one daily dose.

questions.text: 10. A 75-year-old female patient presented with complaints of poor vision, eye pain, photophobia, and watering from her right eye along with headache for the past one week. Examination reduced visual acuity with only light perception, a deep anterior chamber, and the finding as shown in the image. Intraocular pressure increased. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a patient with signs and symptoms of glaucoma (diminution of vision, eye pain, photophobia, watering, headache, corneal edema, mid-dilated pupils, raised intraocular pressure) occurring in association with a senile hyper mature Morgagnian cataract (as shown in the image). Presence of a deep anterior chamber points towards the diagnosis of secondary open-angle glaucoma - phacolytic glaucoma.

Phacolytic glaucoma is secondary open-angle glaucoma occurring in association with hyper mature morgagnian cataracts.

Trabecular obstruction is caused by high molecular-weight lens proteins that leak through the intact capsule in cases of the hyper mature cataract into the aqueous humour; macrophages containing lens proteins may also contribute to this.

Presentation:

* Eye pain

* Diminished vision

* Photophobia

* Lacrimation 

* Headache

* Increased intraocular pressure

* Deep anterior chamber with fine white protein particles which may settle as pseudohypopyon

* Open-angle seen on gonioscopy

* Lens: Milky white cortex with sunken brownish nucleus (Morgagnian cataract)

Treatment:

* Medical therapy to lower the intraocular pressure

* Surgery to extract the lens.

Option A: 

Phacogenic (previously phacoanaphylactic) glaucoma is an autoimmune granulomatous reaction to lens proteins following exposure due to incomplete cataract extraction, trauma, or rarely capsular degeneration. The patient usually presents with a history of trauma or ocular surgery and a latent period following which the symptoms of glaucoma manifests. It is also a type of secondary open-angle glaucoma. 

Option B: 

Phacomorphic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma caused by an intumescent cataractous lens due to rapid maturation of cataract or following traumatic capsular rupture. The swollen lens obliterates the angle by forcing the root of the iris against the cornea. The patient presents with features of acute glaucoma with a shallow anterior chamber and a swollen cataractous lens.

Option D:

Phacotopic glaucoma is an acute secondary angle-closure glaucoma due to anterior subluxation or dislocation of the lens into the anterior chamber and spherophakia. Examination reveals a shallow anterior chamber.

questions.text: 11. Which of the following Alpha subunit of GPCR and its downstream action is incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times. They also serve as receptors for various peptide hormones, neurotransmitters, amino acids, etc.

Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go.

GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

* Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and results in Ca2+ channel opening.

* Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and results in K+ channel opening.

* Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.

* Gq causes activation of phospholipase C, which generates the second messengers inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). The water-soluble IP3 diffuses to the cytosol and mobilizes Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum depots.

The given below image shows the effects of phospholipase C after activation by Gq

questions.text: 12. A 40-year-old female patient presents with headaches and high blood pressure. On investigation, increased aldosterone levels are seen and a diagnosis of Conn's syndrome is made. Which of the following is least likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is least likely to be found in this patient with Conn's syndrome. Patients with Conn's syndrome usually have hypokalemia.

Patients with Conn's syndrome have primary hyperaldosteronism which results in a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually less than 4-6 mEq/L over the normal range, hypokalemia (due to increased K+excretion), hypertension (due to slight increase in ECF volume), metabolic alkalosis because increased hydrogen ions are secreted in the urine.

Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in plasma sodium remaining fairly normal.



Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to the autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. When primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma, it is called Conn's syndrome. Patients are usually treated with spironolactone followed by surgical removal of adenoma. In patients treated with spironolactone, the adenomas contain eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions called spironolactone bodies.

questions.text: 13. A 60-year-old male patient with a history of coronary artery disease developed acute mesenteric ischemia. A laparotomy procedure was done with resection of the gangrenous bowel. Around 190 cm of small bowel was kept intact and the rest was resected. Which type of renal stone will this patient be at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient will be at risk of developing oxalate stones in the kidneys. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of short bowel syndrome.

Patients with short bowel syndrome are at risk of developing oxalate renal stones due to hyperoxaluria as a result of increased absorption of oxalate in the colon and gall stones due to interruption of the enterohepatic cycle of bile salts. 

Short bowel syndrome is referred to intractable diarrhea with malabsorption of nutrients after intestinal resection or intestinal bypass surgery leading to malnutrition. The features of short bowel syndrome usually appear when the length is less than 200 cm of the small bowel, but the length and nature of the remaining bowel are also important.

The common causes for short bowel syndrome are resection due to Crohn's disease, mesenteric vascular occlusion, radiation enteritis, and tumors.

Complications of resection include:

* Steatorrhea - due to fat malabsorption

* Peptic ulcers - due to gastric hypersecretion

* Cholelithiasis

* Oxalate renal stones

Management:

Initial treatment priorities include repletion of fluid and electrolytes lost in severe diarrhea by initiating total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Long-term management involves:

* Administration of oral cholestyramine to bind with bile salts

* Dietary fat restriction

* Parenteral vitamin and mineral supplements

* Proton pump inhibitors to lower gastric pH

* Octreotide to reduce the volume of GI secretions

* Antimotility agents such as loperamide hydrochloride to delay small-intestinal transit

* Hormonal therapy such as growth hormone, glutamine, and GLP-2 (glucagon-like peptide-2) analog (teduglutide) are used to promote intestinal adaptation

Small intestine lengthening procedures done to increase absorption and transit time are:

* Longitudinal intestinal lengthening and tailoring procedure (LILT) (Bianchi procedure)

* Serial transverse enteroplasty procedure (STEP)

Intestinal transplantation is indicated only in complicated cases.

Other options:

Option B- Uric acid renal stones are seen in myeloproliferative disorders, conditions with increased uric acid production, inflammatory bowel disease, and ileostomies 

Option C- Cystine renal stones are seen in familial cystinuria.

Option D- Phosphate renal stones are seen in infections (Proteus, Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus) and renal tubular acidosis type I.

questions.text: 14. A man was brought to the emergency room after an accident. He feels the urge to micturate but is unable to urinate. On examination, blood at the urethral meatus and a high-riding prostate are seen. What is the common site involved in this type of injury?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of trauma, urinary retention, blood at meatus, and a high-riding prostate has a proximal urethral injury. Proximal urethral injuries most commonly occur distal to the urogenital diaphragm and involve the membranous urethra ( 2 in the image) with disruption at the bulbomembranous junction.

questions.text:
15. A patient presented with multiple itchy lesions, as shown in the image below. KOH stain revealed the presence of predominant macroconidia and scanty microconidia. The hair shaft showed ectothrix, but the nails were spared. Which of the following is likely to be the cause of this condition?

KOH - Potassium hydroxide
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with the involvement of the hair and skin but not the nails along with the microscopic examination findings point toward a diagnosis of Microsporum infection.

The given image shows annular lesions with central clearing, which is seen in dermatophytosis. Dermatophytes involve only the superficial cornified layer of skin, sparing the dermis. It should be differentiated from dermatomycosis which is the cutaneous involvement of systemic fungi.

Dermatophytes are of three types:

* Trichophyton: Infection involves the skin, hair, and nails. The species include Trichophyton rubrum, Trichophyton mentagrophytes, Trichophyton tonsurans, Trichophyton schoenleinii, and Trichophyton violaceu. Microconidia > Macroconidia

* Microsporum: Infection involves skin and hair. The species include Microsporum gypseum, Microsporum canis, and Microsporum nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.

* Epidermophyton: Infection involves skin and nails. Only Macroconidia. Epidermophyton floccosum is the only species in this genus.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum:

* Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.

* Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellophane tape (cellophane tape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Endothrix refers to dermatophyte infections of the hair that invade the hair shaft and internalize into the hair cell. As the name suggests, endothrix causes infection inside the hair shaft and ectothrix causes infection outside the shaft.

* T. tonsurans, T. violaceum, T. schoenleinii, Trichophyton yaoundei, and Trichophyton soudanense cause endothrix type of tinea capitis.

* Remember: TV is always kept inside the house (ENDO) — so T. tonsurans and T. violaceum cause endothrix.

* Microsporum audouinii, M.canis, Microsporum equinum, and Microsporum ferrugineum cause ectothrix infection.

Sporothrix does not cause superficial mycoses.

Pearl PM0260: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text:
16. A 10-year-old boy who is a known case of asthma is rushed to the casualty because of breathlessness for the last 3 hours. The patient is conscious and alert. Physical examination shows tachypnea and tachycardia. There is no fever or sputum production. Which of the following are the most appropriate steps for the management of this patient?

* Supplemental oxygen

* Immediate intubation

* Antibiotics

* Nebulized salbutamol

* Systemic steroids
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute severe asthma. While supplemental oxygen, nebulized salbutamol, and systemic steroids are appropriate, there is no role of antibiotics or intubation in the management of this patient.

Patients with asthma can present with an acute attack of bronchoconstriction, presenting as acute onset breathlessness accompanied by tachypnea and tachycardia. The peak expiratory flow rate during acute severe asthma is often <200 mL/min (between 33-50% of predicted). An arterial blood gas analysis should be mandatorily obtained in such patients. A normal or elevated PaCO2 on ABG indicates respiratory fatigue setting in, and indicates a dangerous situation.

The treatment of acute severe asthma includes:

* Supplemental oxygen

* Inhaled bronchodilators such as short-acting β2 agonists like salbutamol. Inhaled ipratropium can also be used as an add-on drug.

* Systemic glucocorticoids reduce the inflammatory response and enhance the recovery of the patient from the acute exacerbation episode.

* IV magnesium may provide some additional bronchodilation in some patients.

PEFR should be recorded every 15-30 minutes initially and SpO2 should be maintained above 92%. 

Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation (statement 2) should be considered only if the patient has features of impending respiratory failure. These include:

* PEFR <100 mL/min

* SpO2 < 92% or PaO2 < 60 mmHg, despite the patient being treated with supplemental oxygen

* Normal or raised PaCO2

* Silent chest or feeble respiratory efforts

* Hypotension, bradycardia, or arrhythmias

* Exhaustion

* Cyanosis

Antibiotics (statement 3) are not used routinely in the management of acute severe asthma. They are given only if there are signs of infection such as fever and sputum production.

questions.text: 17. During the clinical examination of a patient with carpal tunnel syndrome,which of the following tests is least relevant?
questions.solution:
Neer's test is used in the diagnosis of impingement syndrome/painful arc syndrome.

Clinical tests in carpal tunnel syndrome include the reproduction of sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pain by performing the following tests:

* Durkan's test - By applying direct median nerve compression for about 30 seconds.

* Tinel's test (sign) - By percussing the median nerve.

* Phalen's test - By holding the wrist in flexion for about 60 seconds.

The following image shows Phalen's test:



The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies can be done in patients with atypical symptoms to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome. The tests will show slowing of nerve conduction across the wrist.

Carpal tunnel syndrome usually presents at an age of 40–50 years. The common risk factors are pregnancy, rheumatoid disease, renal failure, and gout.

Most of the patients present with burning pain, tingling, and numbness in the distribution of the median nerve. The symptoms worsen with activity and at night. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed and shaking the arm relieve the pain.

Night pain and pregnancy-related symptoms can be reduced by using splints to prevent wrist flexion. Temporary relief from pain can be attained using steroid injection and is a diagnostic tool also.

In patients with an intermediate and chronic syndrome, an early carpal tunnel release can be performed. This surgery is beneficial in most patients, and maximum improvement is seen in 6 months after the release.

Other options:

Neer's test: In patients with a positive Neer's impingement sign, injection of 10% lidocaine into subacromial space, and repeating the test demomstrates pain reduction.

questions.text:
19. Which of the following are not sporicidal agents?

* Isopropyl alcohol

* Formaldehyde

* Chlorhexidine

* Silver sulfadiazine

* Ionizing radiations
questions.solution:
The compounds isopropyl alcohol, chlorhexidine, and silver sulfadiazine are not sporicidal (option A- 1, 3, 4).

Non-sporicidal chemical biocides include

* Alcohols 

* Phenols

* Chlorhexidine

* Silver sulfadiazine 

Isopropyl alcohol and other alcohols have antimicrobial activity against vegetative bacteria, viruses, and fungi. These are bactericidal but are not sporicidal.

Formaldehyde or glutaraldehyde is used for the sterilization of various surgical instruments and endoscopes. They have both bactericidal and sporicidal activity. Sporicidal activity is seen when these compounds are used as a 2% solution. 

Chlorhexidine is a disinfectant and preservative, commonly used in products for hand and oral hygiene. It is bactericidal but not sporicidal.

Silver sulfadiazine is a combination of silver and sulfadiazine, two antibacterial agents. It is not sporicidal.

Ionizing radiations (gamma or x-ray) leads to the formation of free radicals that damages biological molecules like proteins, DNA, etc. These radiations have both bactericidal and sporicidal activity.

Phenols are used for their antiseptic and disinfectant properties. These are not sporicidal.

questions.text: 20. A patient presents with claudication in the right thigh during walking. There is no history of impotence or buttock claudication. On examination, the right femoral and distal pulses are absent. Angiography is given below. What will be the best surgical management?
questions.solution:
The symptom of pain in the right thigh while walking and the given angiography findings are suggestive of aortoiliac occlusive disease with right common iliac artery obstruction. The treatment of choice for unilateral iliac vessel occlusion is an aortofemoral bypass.

Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases.

Diagnosis of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases includes:

* Clinical examination- weakened pulses below the level of obstruction

* Reduced Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) -<0.9 - intermittent claudication (occlusive arterial disease)<0.3 - critical limb ischemia.

* Color doppler- normal artery has a triphasic signal

* Biphasic waveform - mild-moderate stenosis

* Monophasic waveform - severe stenosis

* Duplex scanning - a non-invasive technique that uses a combination of B-mode ultrasound and Doppler study. 

* Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is now the standard technique. The artery is better outlined because the photos are digitized by a computer, which removes extraneous tissues.

* CT angiography (CTA) and MR angiography (MRA) - for extent and type of obstruction. These are not used routinely for the diagnosis but only if symptoms warrant surgical intervention.

Below is an angiography image showing the right common iliac artery obstruction.



Management of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases is as follows:

* Carbohydrate and lipid-free diet

* Graduated exercise program in combination with smoking cessation improves walking efficiency

* Control of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia

* Percutaneous transluminal balloon angioplasty (PTA) - is more useful for isolated iliac stenosis (<4cm in length) rather than occlusion

* Bypass graft surgeries

questions.text: 21. Identify the amputation done at the level shown in the below radiograph.
questions.solution:
Chopart amputation is done at the level shown in the above radiograph.

Chopart amputation is a type of midfoot amputation through the talonavicular joint and calcaneocuboid joint. One of the indications is diabetic foot. It can be done only if calcaneum and talus are free of infection.

The image below shows X-ray foot after Chopart's amputation.



Other options:

Option A: Pirogoff amputation is a type of hindfoot amputation. It involves a vertical section through the middle of the calcaneum followed by arthrodesis between the tibia and the remaining part of the calcaneum.

Option B: Syme's amputation is a type of hindfoot amputation where the bone section is done at the distal tibia and fibula.

Option C: Lisfranc amputation is a type of midfoot amputation that is done at the level of tarsometatarsal joints.

questions.text: 22. A 4-year-old child is brought for evaluation of weakness, vomiting, difficulty walking, and pallor. The family recently moved to an old house with peeling paint and were still planning renovations. The peripheral smear is shown below. What would you advise for the patient?
questions.solution:
The slide shows basophilic stippling (punctate basophilia), seen in chronic lead poisoning (also called plumbism or saturnism). The history of moving to an old home with peeling paint hints at the usage of lead-based paints in old houses. The next step in diagnosis would be to obtain to peripheral venous blood sample for blood lead level evaluation.

Sideroblastic anemia occurs in lead poisoning as lead inhibits the enzymes ferrochelatase and δ-aminolevulinate dehydratase which are responsible for the heme synthesis pathway. This leads to the accumulation of the heme precursors in the cell. They can be stained by Prussian blue staining and can be visualized in the RBCs on a peripheral smear. 

The hematological findings that are associated with lead poisoning are anemia, ringed sideroblasts, and basophilic stippling of the RBCs.

Diagnosis involves screening tests such as measurement of:

* Coproporphyrin levels in urine. It is less than 150 mcg/100 mL in non-exposed individuals.

* Aminolevulinic acid levels in urine: A reading greater than 50 mg/L indicates lead absorption

* Blood and urine levels of lead: A reading greater than 0.8 mg/L in urine indicates lead absorption. A reading greater than 70 mcg/L in blood indicates lead absorption.

Other Options:

MRI brain and Skin biopsy are not used in the evaluation of lead poisoning. 

Bone marrow biopsy is used to evaluate for myelodysplastic syndrome which can also cause sideroblastic anemia. However, there is also presence of signs of other cell line deficits like recurrent infections or bleeding diathesis, which is lacking in this patient. 

Prevention of lead poisoning includes incorporating personal protective measures, regular screening of workers, good housekeeping practices, and health education.

Lead poisoning is a notifiable and compensatable disease in India.

questions.text: 23. According to Truelove–Witts criteria, which of the following is not a criterion to diagnose acute severe colitis?
questions.solution:
The presence of jaundice and pruritus is not a part of Truelove–Witts criteria, which are used to define acute severe ulcerative colitis. 

Truelove–Witts criteria define acute severe colitis as the presence of:

* ≥ 6 bloody stools/24 hrs

* Plus, one or more of the following features:

* Anemia (Hemoglobin <10 g/dL).

* Mild fever (>100.04°F).

* Tachycardia (Pulse ≥90 beats/min).

* High inflammatory markers (ESR > 30 mm/hr or CRP >30 mg/L).

questions.text: 24. A 40-year-old P2L2 woman presents to your office with foul-smelling bloody discharge per vaginum. Her CECT reports show a 3.5 x 4 cm ulceroproliferative mass in the cervix invading the parametrium, with para-aortic node involvement. What is the line of management for this case?

choices.text: Radical hysterectomy + Pelvic lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
The patient has carcinoma cervix, which is at stage IIIC2 due to para-aortic node involvement. As per FIGO 2018 guidelines, the treatment for this stage is chemoradiation.

Chemoradiation can improve survival rates. It allows for remission in certain cases or a reduction in morbidity.

Other options:

Pelvic exenteration may be considered in stage IVA. 

Surgical treatment is considered in the early stages of the disease. Radical hysterectomy is preferred in stages IB1, IB2, and a few cases of IIA.

* C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

questions.text: 26. Following general anaesthesia for a procedure, a 45-year-old lady experienced prolonged somnolescence. On administration of physostigmine, she showed rapid improvement of her mental status. Which of the following drugs is not likely to cause this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of the central anticholinergic syndrome, which is not caused by glycopyrrolate. 

Glycopyrrolate usually does not produce central anticholinergic syndrome because is a quaternary amine compound, lipid insoluble, and does not cross the blood-brain barrier. Glycopyrrolate blocks the peripheral muscarinic side effects (caused by increased acetylcholine levels by neostigmine) without causing unwanted central anticholinergic effects.

Drugs that can cause anticholinergic syndrome include:

* Atropine

* Scopolamine

* First-generation antihistamines 

* Tricyclic antidepressants 

* Phenothiazines

The anticholinergic syndrome can present with central manifestations ranging from delirium and agitation to CNS depression, stupor and coma. It is a rare reaction due to either overdose or any unusual reaction to the usage of the drugs mentioned above. Physostigmine is useful in reversing the central anticholinergic syndrome produced by overdosage or an unusual reaction to these drugs.

questions.text:
27. Match the lupus nephritis lesions with their treatments.

1. Focal Lupus Nephritis a. Only supportive treatment, no specific therapy
2. Membranous Lupus Nephritis b. A short course of high-dose corticosteroids
3. Mesangial Proliferative Lupus Nephritis c. Hemodialysis
4. Advanced Sclerosing Lupus Nephritis d. Corticosteroids+ Immunosuppressants +/- ACEs/ARBs
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c.

Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of systemic lupus erythematosus, seen in about 30-50% of patients with SLE. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and/or throughout the glomerulus.

Management of lupus nephritis:

* Class I (minimal mesangial) and II lesions (mesangial proliferative): They are associated with minimal or no symptoms and have an excellent prognosis. They do not require any therapy. 

* Class III lesions (focal lupus nephritis): They are associated with few symptoms and a good prognosis. Management includes the administration of a short course of high-dose corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents.

* Class IV lesions (diffuse lupus nephritis): Manifestations include hematuria, nephrotic-range proteinuria, and renal casts. Treatment includes the administration of high-dose steroids combined with either cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil for 2–6 months. It is followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine.

* Class V lesions (membranous lupus nephritis): They are associated with severe manifestations and a poor prognosis. Management includes the administration of steroids in combination with other immunosuppressive agents. Inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system may be administered to attenuate proteinuria.

* Class VI lesions (advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis): They present with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and require hemodialysis.

questions.text: 28. A 15-year-old girl presented with fever, hypotension, and skin rash. She had a tampon in situ for 24 hours. A bacterial cause is suspected. The toxin responsible for this condition binds to which of the following regions on the T-cell receptor?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with fever, hypotension, and skin rash after retaining a tampon for 24 hours is likely to be staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome. The toxin involved in this condition is the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which is a superantigen that binds to the variable beta (Vβ) region on the T-cell receptor (TCR). 

The TCR is a transmembrane heterodimeric protein containing two disulfide-linked chains. It is made up of two distinct TCR classes known as alpha-beta (α and β) and gamma-delta (γ and δ). The majority of the T cells contain the αβ TCR phenotype.

There are two extracellular domains on each TCR chain: a variable region and a constant region, where the variable region binds the peptide-MHC complex, whereas the constant region is closer to the cell membrane.



Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity, i.e., they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

TSST-1 binds to MHC class II molecules and causes T-cell stimulation by bypassing the normal activation pathway. This leads to the overactivation of cytokines particularly, IFN-γ.  IFN-γ in turn activates macrophages to produce IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-α, all of which may contribute to a “cytokine storm” causing severe symptoms of shock and multiple organ failure.

Toxic shock syndrome generally occurs in menstruating women who use superabsorbent tampons and do not change them often. However, it can also occur in post-surgical infections, burns, soft tissue infections and retained foreign bodies like nasal packing, and catheters. 

Clinical features of toxic shock syndrome include fever, desquamative skin rash, hypotension, and multisystem organ involvement.

Treatment involves prompt removal of the source of infection such as tampons, nasal packing or debridement. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered after culture samples have been taken. The patient should also receive aggressive hydration with crystalloids.

questions.text: 29. A patient with an angle of 10° as shown below was prescribed a cervical-thoracic-lumbosacral orthosis brace. Which of the following braces was prescribed to this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the measurement of the Cobb's angle which is used to assess the severity of the curve in a patient with scoliosis. Milwaukee brace is a type of Cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO) used in the treatment of scoliosis. 

Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb's angle of > 10°

Cobb's method consists of three steps:

* Locating the superior-end vertebra of the curve

* Locating the inferior-end vertebra of the curve

* Creating intersecting perpendicular lines from the superior surface of the superior-end vertebra and the inferior surface of the inferior-end vertebra.

The angle of deviation of these perpendiculars is the angle of the spinal curve known as Cobb's angle.



Braces are used to prevent progression and avoid surgery in scoliotic curves between 20 and 30 degrees. A variety of braces are available, some are created as cast and some are prefabricated. They usually extend from the thoracic and lumbar spine to the pelvis and have pads to push the spine into correct alignment. 

Braces used in scoliosis:

* Milwaukee brace: Originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO), introduced in the 1940s

* Less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces

* Still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine



* Boston brace: (option C)

* It is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). 

* It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside.

* It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower.



* Charleston bending brace: (Option C)

*

* Is a thoraco-lumbo-sacral orthose (TLSO) used while lying down and sleeping at night for 8 to 10 hours

* Best suited for single thoracolumbar or lumbar curves



Other options:

Option A: SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace is a cervicothoracic orthosis used to treat cervical spine injury. It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it.

questions.text: 31. A 10-year-old child with HIV was brought to the hospital with complaints of persistent diarrhoea and fever for the last month. The examination of the oral cavity was as given below. What is the most probable stage of the disease the child is suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with HIV, and persistent diarrhea and fever with oral candidiasis (as given in the image) suggests stage 3 of HIV infection. 

Features of Stage 3 of the disease include 

* Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy

* Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)

* Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)

* Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

* Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)

* Oral hairy leukoplakia

* Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

* Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB

* Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia

* Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis

* Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Clinical features of HIV infection are highly variable. Initial signs and symptoms are non-specific like lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, recurrent diarrhea, and failure to thrive. The status of the disease may be assessed based on the clinical features and immunological response. 

The diagnosis of HIV infection in babies born to HIV-infected mothers is done by HIV proviral DNA or RNA PCR, HIV culture, or HIV p24 antigen. The national program (Early Infant Diagnosis) now uses HIV total nucleic acid (RNA + proviral DNA) PCR test on dried blood spot samples. All positive tests need to be confirmed with an HIV PCR test on another sample. According to the national AIDS control organization (NACO), an infant born to an HIV-positive mother should be breastfed exclusively or by replacement feeds exclusively for 6 months of age. If exclusive replacement feeding is done, infants should receive ARV prophylaxis with syrup nevirapine or zidovudine, even if the baby is tested negative.

questions.text: 32. A male COVID patient who was on oxygen support was discharged and was prescribed an oral anticoagulant acting at the site marked in the image below. Which of the following is the specific reversal agent for the prescribed oral agent?
questions.solution:
The oral agent acting on thrombin (factor IIa) is dabigatran, and idarucizumab is the specific reversal agent for dabigatran (oral direct thrombin inhibitor).

Idarucizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (Fab) that binds to dabigatran with an affinity many times higher than that of thrombin. The irreversible idarucizumab-dabigatran complex is then excreted by the kidneys. Idarucizumab is infused as two intravenous boluses, each of 2.5 g.

Other options:

Option A- Andexanet alfa is a specific reversal agent for oral factor Xa inhibitors. It is a recombinant analog of factor Xa which rapidly reverses the anti-factor Xa action and restores thrombin production.

Option B- Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin (IIa) inhibitor. It competitively and reversibly binds the active site of thrombin and prevents the conversion of fibrinogen to fibrin. It does not require routine coagulation monitoring. It is mainly used in acute venous thromboembolism after initiating parenteral anticoagulation and in the secondary prevention of venous thromboembolism. It is also considered as the oral anticoagulant of choice in discharged COVID-19 patients. Dabigatran is contraindicated in patients having mechanical heart valves.

Option C- Protamine sulfate given intravenously can be used for the rapid reversal of heparin overdose. It binds tightly to heparin. 1 mg of protamine sulfate neutralizes 100 units of heparin. Protamine binds only long heparin molecules, thereby making it a partial reversal agent for low-molecular-weight heparin.

Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants:

* Heparin: Protamine sulfate

* Warfarin: Vitamin K

* Oral Xa inhibitors: Andexanet alfa

* Dabigatran: Idarucizumab

questions.text: 33. In a village with a given population, the total number of births in a year is 5100. There were 100 stillbirths. 25 newborns died within the first 7 days of life whereas 175 died due to various causes between 8 – 28 days of life. There were 50 deaths between the age of 1 month to 6 months of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
Neonatal mortality rate = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year

The total live births in this scenario is 5100 – 100 = 5000 live births.

NMR = (25+175) x 1000/5000 = 40.

Note: Still births and deaths after 28 days of life are not considered in Neonatal Mortality Rate.

Pearl PM1700: Neonatal Mortality Rate

* Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.

* NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year

* Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.

* India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: 34. A 45-year-old man presents with jaundice and pruritus. He has been on treatment for ulcerative colitis for many years. MRCP showed beading in the bile ducts. The biopsy image given below shows the appearance of the bile duct. Which of the following structures is/are involved?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the MRCP findings of bile duct beading, is suggestive of primary sclerosing cholangitis, in which both the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts are involved.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts with dilation of preserved segments. It is more common in men and associated with Riedel thyroiditis and ulcerative colitis, but proctocolectomy does not stop disease progression. 

It presents with generalized symptoms like fatigue and pruritus or asymptomatic abnormal liver function tests on routine tests. It is associated with an increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma.

MRCP showing multifocal diffuse dilation and stricturing of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary trees called beading or chain of lakes is sufficient for diagnosis. The biopsy is only done for equivocal MRCP and suspected malignancy. It is associated with elevated p-ANCA levels.

Ursodeoxycholic acid shows some improvement but does not alter the course of the disease. ERCP is done to dilate prominent strictures, and liver transplantation is done for progressive disease.

questions.text: 35. A researcher conducts a cross sectional study to determine the prevalence of lactose intolerance in a population. Which of the following is true about this type of study?

choices.text: The rate of occurrence of new cases is accounted for
Follow-up examinations need to be done
The natural history of disease can be determined
They are more useful for chronic diseases

questions.solution:
The prevalence of a disease is calculated using cross-sectional studies which are more useful for chronic diseases.

A cross-sectional study is a type of observational study where a cross-section of a population is examined once at one point in time. It is used to calculate a disease's distribution and prevalence. Prevalence helps to estimate the magnitude of health/ disease problems in the community and identify potential high-risk populations. Cross-sectional studies are more useful in studying chronic diseases than acute ones (Option D). These studies do not establish a time sequence and provide no information on the natural history of disease or the rate of occurrence of new cases.

Longitudinal studies are done by repeatedly observing the same population over a prolonged period of time by means of follow-up examinations (Option B). They are useful in studying the natural history of disease and the rate of occurrence of new cases. (Option A and C)

Pearl PM0231: Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

Types of Epidemiological Study Designs

The flow chart below gives a glance into the types of epidemiological study designs and where they are generally used.

Note: Descripitve study is used to formulate aetiological hypothesis of a disease. Whereas analytical study is used to test the hypothesis (i.e to accept or reject the hypothesis).



Pearl PM0228: Incidence and Prevalence

* Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:



It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

* Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:



It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

* In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".

* In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.

* If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.

* If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text:
36. Which of the following can be classified as ionizing radiation?

* Alpha rays

* Beta rays

* Gamma rays

* X-rays

* MRI
questions.solution:
Among the given options, alpha rays, beta rays, gamma rays, and x-rays are ionizing radiations. MRI is an example of non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. 

Ionizing radiation is a type of radiation with enough energy to remove tightly bound electrons from the orbit of an atom, causing the atom to be charged or ionized. They can be either directly ionizing or indirectly ionizing. Alpha rays and beta rays are directly ionizing radiation because they carry a charge and can directly interact with atomic electrons. Alpha and beta rays are also particulate radiation (composed of particles). 

Gamma rays and x-rays are electromagnetic rays. They are indirectly ionizing radiation as they are electrically neutral and do not interact directly with electrons. 

MRI is a technique that produces topographic images by means of magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves. It uses non-ionizing electromagnetic radiation. MRI is based on the ability of nuclei of certain atoms to absorb and emit radio wave energy when the body is placed within a strong magnetic field.

questions.text: 37. The most predominant retinal glial cells are present in which of the following layers of the retina?
questions.solution:
The most predominant retinal glial cells are the radial (Müller) cells, whose nuclei lie within the inner nuclear layer (2).

From this region a single thick fibre ascends radially, giving off complex lateral lamellae which branch among the processes of the outer plexiform layer. 

The structures marked are as follows-

* Inner Plexiform Layer 

* Internal Nuclear Layer

* Outer Plexiform Layer 

* Outer Nuclear Layer

Radial glial cells span the entire thickness of the neural retina. They form the outer boundary of the retinal tissue at the level of the inner rod and cone segments, and the inner boundary at the internal limiting membrane.

Retinal astrocytes are largely confined to the ganglion cell and nerve fibre layers whereas microglial cells are scattered throughout the neural part of the retina in small numbers.

The retina consists of 10 layers, with retinal pigment epithelium(RPE) being the outermost layer below the Bruch's membrane of the choroid and the internal limiting membrane being the innermost layer separating the retina from the vitreous.

questions.text: 38. A 53-year-old menopausal lady presents with bleeding per vagina. Ultrasound of her pelvis shows a thick endometrial stripe, which on biopsy showed grade 1 adenocarcinoma of the endometrium. Identify the true statements regarding this condition.

questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation is indicative of endometrial cancer. Grade 1 endometrial carcinoma shows cellular atypia and the regular glandular pattern is maintained.

The grading of endometrial tumors is based on differentiation, glandular architecture, and anaplasia of the cells. It is as follows,

* Grade 1: The glandular pattern is maintained, but cells show atypia.

* Grade 2: Some glands show the papillary pattern and are solid.

* Grade 3: The glands are solid with cellular proliferation, and glandular architecture is lost. The endometrium is packed with glands and little stroma.

The histopathology image below shows endometrioid endometrial adenocarcinoma with malignant endometrial glands and metaplasia at high magnification.

Histologically, adenocarcinoma is the most common type of endometrial carcinoma amounting to 75%. The rest are clear cells, squamous and serous variety. They are more malignant than adenocarcinoma.

Patients with endometrial cancer present with post-menopausal bleed or abnormal uterine bleeding in the perimenopausal period.

Aspiration cytology from the uterine cavity every 6 months is an effective method of screening in high-risk cases. Ultrasonography is a useful modality for the assessment of endometrial thickening and associated ovarian tumors.

questions.text: 39. A 70-year-old man was referred to you for further evaluation for dementia. After a detailed clinical and laboratory examination, you diagnose this patient to be suffering from subcortical dementia. Subcortical dementia can occur in all of the following conditions, except _____.
questions.solution:
Subcortical dementia can be seen in all the above conditions except Alzheimer's disease, which is an example of cortical dementia.

Dementia or major neurocognitive disorder is a progressive and irreversible intellectual impairment that increases with age. It is seen more commonly in women. It is classified into cortical and subcortical dementia based on the site of the cerebral lesion.

Examples of cortical dementia are Alzheimer's disease, Pick's disease, and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Common causes of subcortical dementia include Parkinson's disease, vascular dementia, Huntington's disease, Wilson's disease, and normal pressure hydrocephalus.

The two types of dementia frequently overlap and an accurate diagnosis can be made only on autopsy.

Pearl PM1780: Revised criteria for the clinical diagnosis of probable and possible dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB)

* Essential for a diagnosis of DLB is dementia, defined as a progressive cognitive decline of sufficient magnitude to interfere with normal social or occupational functions, or with usual daily activities.

* Prominent or persistent memory impairment may not necessarily occur in the early stages but is usually evident with progression.

* Deficits on tests of attention, executive function, and visuoperceptual ability may be especially prominent and occur early.

Core clinical features (The first 3 typically occur early and may persist throughout the course.)

* Fluctuating cognition with pronounced variations in attention and alertness.

* Recurrent visual hallucinations that are typically well formed and detailed.

* REM sleep behavior disorder, which may precede cognitive decline.

* One or more spontaneous cardinal features of Parkinsonism: these are bradykinesia (defined as slowness of movement and decrement in amplitude or speed), rest tremor, or rigidity.

Supportive clinical features:

* Severe sensitivity to antipsychotic agents; postural instability; repeated falls; syncope or other transient episodes of unresponsiveness; severe autonomic dysfunction, e.g., constipation, orthostatic hypotension, urinary incontinence; hypersomnia; hyposmia; hallucinations in other modalities; systematized delusions; apathy, anxiety, and depression.

Indicative biomarkers

* Reduced dopamine transporter uptake in basal ganglia demonstrated by SPECT or PET.

* Abnormal (low uptake) 123iodine-MIBG myocardial scintigraphy.

* Polysomnographic confirmation of REM sleep without atonia.

Supportive biomarkers

* Relative preservation of medial temporal lobe structures on CT/MRI scan.

* Generalized low uptake on SPECT/PET perfusion/metabolism scan with reduced occipital activity ± the cingulate island sign on FDG-PET imaging.

* Prominent posterior slow-wave activity on EEG with periodic fluctuations in the pre-alpha/ theta range.

A. Probable DLB can be diagnosed if:

* Two or more core clinical features of DLB are present, with or without the presence of indicative biomarkers, or

* Only one core clinical feature is present, but with one or more indicative biomarkers

Note: Probable DLB should not be diagnosed on the basis of biomarkers alone

B. Possible DLB can be diagnosed if:

* Only one core clinical feature of DLB is present, with no indicative biomarker evidence, or

* One or more indicative biomarkers is present but there are no core clinical features.

questions.text: 42. A 26-year-old woman delivered a baby vaginally, without any complications. After birth, the placenta was expelled and it was found that the cord was attached to the membranes and the cord vessels were traversing between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. Identify the abnormal placenta.
questions.solution:
The abnormal placenta described is a velamentous placenta, as the cord is attached to the membranes.

The umbilical cord is usually attached at or near the center of the placenta at term.

The cord is attached to the membranes in the case of velamentous placenta. The cord vessels traverse between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels leads to vaginal bleeding and fetal exsanguination. 

Management-

* If fetal bleeding occurs, urgent delivery is done either vaginally or by cesarean section. The infant’s hemoglobin levels should be tested and if necessary, blood transfusion can also be done.

* If the baby is dead, vaginal delivery is allowed to occur.

The below image shows velamentous placenta:



When velamentous placenta is associated with vasa previa, there is an increased chance of rupture of vessels and bleeding:



Option A- Circumvallate placenta is a type of placenta extrachorialis. There is a smaller chorionic plate as compared to the basal plate. The amnion and chorion fold and roll back on themselves to form a ring that is reflected centrally. This leaves a rim of placental tissue exposed extrachorially. There is an increased chance of abortions, hydrorrhea gravidarum, antepartum hemorrhage, growth retardation of the fetus, preterm delivery, and retained placenta and membranes. 

The below image shows circumvallate placenta:



Option B- Battledore placenta, where the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a Previa or a low-lying placenta, there can be cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

The below image shows battledore placenta:



Option D- Succenturiate placenta is characterized by the presence of one or more small lobes of placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins. A leash of blood vessels connects these accessory cotyledons to the main placenta. If these vessels are absent, then it is called placenta spuria. If this lobe is retained postpartum, there can be primary or secondary postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution of uterus, uterine sepsis, polyp formation.

questions.text: 43. A patient in ICU is started with a blood transfusion. After 20 minutes, the patient starts developing a fever with chills and flank pain. His urine appears red in color. What is the most likely pathophysiology behind this reaction?

choices.text: Preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells
Inflammatory mediators derived from donor leukocytes
IgG antibodies against previously sensitized antigens
Factors in the transfused blood trigger activation of neutrophils

questions.solution:
The most likely pathophysiology behind this reaction is pre-formed IgM antibodies against donor red cells that fix complement. The clinical scenario describes an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction as the patient has a rapid onset of fever with chills, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria. 

Acute hemolytic reactions are caused due to pre-existing high-affinity IgM antibodies against the blood group antigens on the donor cells. This leads to complement activation and subsequent complement-mediated lysis, intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria. The signs and symptoms are due to complement activation since osmotic lysis of red cells results in hemoglobinuria with the absence of other symptoms of a hemolytic reaction.

When it is suspected, the transfusion should be immediately stopped and the blood bank should be notified about the reaction. The blood bank should evaluate the patient's blood samples for hemolysis and the presence of antibodies. Antibodies can be tested for by direct antiglobulin test (DAT), sometimes called the direct Coombs test. The blood levels of lactate dehydrogenase, indirect bilirubin, and serum haptoglobin should be assessed.

 Non-immunologic reactions:

* Fluid overload

* Hypothermia

* Hypocalcemia due to increased chelation of calcium by citrate

* Hyperkalemia due to increased release of potassium from lysed cells

* Iron overload

* Transient hypotension

* Transfusion-mediated immunomodulation- Multiple sittings of transfusion of allogenic blood leads to immunosuppression

Other options:

Option B: Inflammatory mediators derived from donor leukocytes cause febrile non-hemolytic reactions. It can present as chills and is usually evident within 6 hours of transfusion of red cells or platelets. These reactions increase with the storage of donor blood and can be reduced by taking measures to minimize donor leukocyte contamination. Antipyretics can be used for management.

Option C: IgG antibodies against previously sensitized antigens cause delayed hemolytic reactions. These reactions are associated with a positive Coomb's test and other features of hemolysis like low haptoglobin and elevated lactate dehydrogenase. Antigens like Rh, Kell, and Kidd can induce complement activation. But if there is no complement activation, it results in the opsonization of red cells, extravascular hemolysis, and spherocytosis.

Option D: Factors in the transfused blood trigger activation of neutrophils and cause severe and fatal transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI).
