questions.text: 44. Direct laryngoscopy was performed to evaluate a 60-year-old man with laryngeal cancer. The tumor was noted in the vocal cord and the anterior commissure. Conservative laryngeal surgery was performed. Which of the following surgeries involves the removal of the affected structures?
questions.solution:
The surgery that involves the removal of the vocal cords and anterior commissure is the partial frontolateral laryngectomy.

This surgery is a type of conservative laryngeal surgery. They're performed to conserve the voice and avoid a permanent tracheal opening. Conservative surgery cannot be done for all types of laryngeal carcinoma so patients should be carefully selected. 

Types of conservation surgeries include:

I) Cordectomy via laryngeal fissure - The vocal cord is excised after splitting the larynx

II) Partial frontolateral laryngectomy - The vocal cord and anterior commissure is excised

III) Partial horizontal laryngectomy - The supraglottis is excised. This includes the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, false cords, and the ventricle.

The other type of surgery is total laryngectomy where the entire larynx along with the hyoid bone, preepiglottic space, strap muscles, and a few tracheal rings are removed. The tracheal stump is sutured to the skin to allow respiration. 

The indications of total laryngectomy are as follows:

* T3 lesions

* All T4 lesions

* Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage

* Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement

* Lesions of the posterior commissure 

* Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery

* Transglottic cancers with cord fixation.

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

questions.text: 45. A 40-year-old patient presented with chest pain and diaphoresis. ECG demonstrates ST-segment elevation, and coronary angiography shows transient vasospasm. The patient is prescribed nitrates. Which of the following drugs can be added to treat this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is Prinzmetal/variant/vasospastic angina. The first-line agents that are used are calcium channel blockers (CCBs) and nitrates.

Prinzmetal angina occurs as a result of vasospasm of the epicardial coronary artery. It may result in transient transmural ischemia. The cause of this spasm is not well understood and is suspected to be due to hypercontractility of cardiac smooth muscles.

This type of angina is commonly seen in women under 50 years of age and is precipitated by smoking and cocaine use.

The vasospasm leads to transmural ischemia, which is seen on the ECG as transient ST-segment elevation although there is no atherosclerosis present on angiography. 

Depolarization of cardiac myocytes depends primarily on the influx of Ca2+ ions. Ca 2+ antagonists relax arterial smooth muscle, thereby decreasing arterial resistance, blood pressure, and cardiac afterload.

So, calcium channel blockers such as long-acting nifedipine and amlodipine are employed along with nitrates to alleviate vasospasm.

Other options:

Option A: Beta-blockers are not used in the management of vasospastic angina and may worsen the symptoms.

Option C: Aspirin is speculated to worsen vasospasm in vasospastic angina, and hence, it must be avoided.

Option D: Although angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEi) are commonly used antihypertensives, they are not used as first-line agents in the management of Prinzmetal angina.

Pearl PM1567: Anti-anginal drugs

Anti-anginal drugs can be divided into the following categories:

* Nitrates - dilates veins > arteries, reduces preload

* Calcium channel blockers - blocks L-type calcium channels

* Dihydropyridines - amlodipine, nifedipine

* Non-dihydropyridines - verapamil, diltiazem

* Beta-blockers - decreases heart rate, contractility and oxygen demand

* Other drugs: 

* Ranolazine - late Na+ channel blocker

* Ivabradine - inhibit funny currents in SA node

* Nicorandil - K+-ATP channel agonist

* Trimetazidine - pFOX inhibitor

* Fasudil - rho-kinase inhibitor

questions.text: 47. For the engineering team project, Mr. X and Mr. Y were paired up. Mr. X, who is generally a lonely person, requested a change of partner. When the tutor asked for an explanation for requesting this change, Mr. X replied, 'Mr. Y wants to be left alone.' Which of the following defense mechanisms best explains Mr. X's response?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, Mr. X's response can be best explained by the defense mechanism of projection. Projection is when you attribute your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings to someone else.

Mr. X is projecting his wishes by stating that Mr. Y wants to be left alone when in reality it is he who wants to be left alone. Mr. X could have probably done this because of severe prejudice against Mr. Y, or because he senses danger or a bad outcome when paired with Mr. Y. 

Other options-

Option (A): Rationalization is making excuses for your behavior. Had that been the answer, he would have made excuses, such as he’s uncomfortable with Mr. Y. 

Option (C): Displacement would have been the correct answer if Mr. X had shouted at Mr. Y for the tutor having paired them together. Displacement is the shifting of emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

Option (D): Repression refers to subconsciously forgetting something. The scenario does not convey this mechanism.

Pearl PM0351: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.


 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: Persistent preoccupation or fear about the possibility of having a serious or life-threatening disease. Physical signs and symptoms are anxiously interpreted as abnormal. 

  • Eg: Believing that one has a tumour which cannot be detected. 

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.


 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.


 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

* Phobia - displacement

* Neurosis - repression

* Grief - denial

* Borderline personality - Splitting

* Schizophrenia - projection

* Enuresis - Regression

questions.text: 49. A 14-year-old girl underwent abdominal ultrasound as a part of the evaluation for stomach ache. She was incidentally found to have an absent uterus and intra-abdominal testes. Clinical examination revealed female external genitalia and breast development appropriate for age but sparse axillary and pubic hair. The karyotype is 46,XY. Which of the following is not preferred as a treatment option in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) and immediate orchidectomy at diagnosis is not a treatment option to manage this condition. Orchidectomy should preferably be performed after pubertal maturation in a patient with complete androgen insensitivity syndrome. It is preferably done at 16-18 years.

Androgen insensitivity syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder in which the androgen receptors are absent, or scanty, or fail to respond to testosterone. As a result, resistance to androgens may be complete, and female external genitalia are found. The individual has a genetic makeup of 46XY but is phenotypically a female. The Wolffian duct fails to develop because of the absence of testosterone receptors. Testes produce Mullerian-inhibiting factors, so the Müllerian system fails to develop. However, the lower portion of the vagina derived from the sinovaginal bulb appears as a dimple of 1–2 cm in length.

AIS can be present in two forms:

* Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome

* Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome

In complete AIS, the individual is born as a phenotypically normal female but generally presents with primary amenorrhea. The external genitalia appears normal, with absent or scant pubic and axillary hair. The vagina is shortened and blind-ending with an absent uterus and ovaries. These patients may also present with a history of childhood inguinal hernias, due to the presence of undescended testis in the abdomen or in the inguinal canal. Due to the constant conversion of testosterone into estrogen, these individuals have normal breast development.

Investigations:

* Ultrasound reveals the absence of ovaries and the uterus.

* Testosterone > 200 ng/mL

* Leutinizing hormone level is raised, but follicle-stimulating hormone level is normal.

* Chromosome study reveals XY chromosomes.

Management:

* Identify the location of ectopic testis and perform orchidectomy after puberty to prevent malignant degeneration. Malignant transformation usually does not occur until after puberty.

* Estrogen therapy for the development of the breasts as well as to prevent osteoporosis

* Surgical vaginoplasty at the time of marriage

* Absent reproductive function, surrogacy is considered.

In partial AIS, a few receptors do respond to testosterone, whereby the clinical features are variable. Some patients present at birth with ambiguous genitalia, and chromosome study reveals XY chromosomes, while others present at puberty, with lack of virilization in a boy or signs of virilization in a girl with primary amenorrhoea.

The treatment is based on the sex in which the child is reared, psychological behavior, and the amount of virilization. If the child is reared as female, it is best to perform gonadectomy in childhood to avoid virilization. In a boy, testosterone will help.

questions.text: 50. All of the following indicate a favorable prognosis for neuroblastoma except:
questions.solution:
All of the above are favorable diagnostic factors except n-MYC gene amplification.

The image shown below is that of Homer-Wright pseudorosettes, which are typically seen in neuroblastoma. The factors indicative of an unfavorable prognosis in neuroblastoma are n-MYC gene amplification and histological examination of the tumor showing no evidence of schwannian stroma and gangliocytic differentiation.

Neuroblastoma is the most frequently-occurring extracranial childhood tumor. They most commonly occur in the adrenal glands but can occur anywhere in the sympathetic nervous system like in the paraspinal ganglia and less frequently in the thorax, pelvis, and cervical areas, after having originated from neural crest progenitor cells.

In children younger than 2 years of age, neuroblastomas generally present as large abdominal masses with fever and weight loss. In older children, they can cause bone pain, respiratory symptoms or metastasize through the hematogenous and lymphatic systems to the liver, bones, and bone marrow. The periorbital region is a common metastatic site and as a result, proptosis and ecchymosis may occur. In neonates, disseminated neuroblastomas may present with multiple cutaneous metastases that cause deep blue discoloration of the skin (blueberry muffin baby).

About 90% of neuroblastomas produce catecholamines, which are an important diagnostic feature; this includes elevated blood levels of catecholamines and elevated urine levels of the metabolites vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA).

Histologic confirmation is required to establish a diagnosis of neuroblastoma. Tumor cells are concentrically arranged around a central space filled with neuropil, an arrangement called Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. MRI is done as a part of preliminary imaging for good resolution and surgical excision planning.

The following image shows the Homer Wright rosettes.



Due to sympathetic neuronal uptake of mIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine), owing to its analogous nature to norepinephrine, the extent of neuroblastoma metastasis can be delineated with an mIBG scan with high accuracy and quality. Bone marrow biopsy is required for tumor staging.

Common paraneoplastic conditions associated with neuroblastoma include opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome and intractable secretory diarrhea (Kerner-Morrison syndrome) due to vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) secretion, Pepper syndrome characterized by extensive metastasis to the liver, Horner syndrome, etc.

A CT scan of the abdomen and chest is recommended to look for calcifications and metastatic lesions.

Stage Stage 1, 2A, 2B, 4S Stages 3 and 4
Age < 18 months > 18 months
DNA ploidy Hyperploid Near-diploid
MYCN Not amplified  Amplified
Chromosome 1p loss Absent Present
Chromosome 11q loss Absent Present
Evidence of schwannian stroma and gangliocytic differentiation on histology Present Absent
Mitosis-karyorrhexis index (number of mitotic/karyorrhectic cells per 5000 tumor cells) <200 >200
TRKA/TRKB expression Present/Absent Absent/Present

questions.text:
51. A 48-year-old employee presented to the ESI hospital with resting tremors, slowness of movements, depression, dementia, and a shuffling, short-stepping gait. He has been working in the same factory for the past 11 years and his monthly income is Rs 20,000. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the benefits he can avail of under the ESI Act?

ESI: Employees' State Insurance Act

choices.text: Outpatient care by a specialist and supply of drugs free of cost
An extended sickness benefit for 3 years.
Inpatient care by a specialist and supply of drugs free of cost

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a patient with Parkinson's disease. He can avail of the extended sickness benefit, which is payable only for 2 years (not 3 years) under the ESI Act. 

ESI act covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month. Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bill. An employee contributes 0.75% of wages. State and Central governments share medical expenditure in the ratio of 1:7.

Extended sickness benefit is payable for 2 years for a set of 34 diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

Few important points to be known about the ESI Act:

Medical benefit comprises complete medical care including hospitalization, free of cost which includes:

* Out-patient care

* Supply of drugs and dressings

* Specialist services in all branches of medicine

* Pathological and radiological investigations

* Domiciliary services

* Antenatal, natal, and postnatal services

* Immunization services

* Family planning services

* Emergency services

* Ambulance services

* Health-education

* In-patient treatment.

Pearl PM0022: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

* Defence 

* Railway  

* Mines 

Finance Contribution

* It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.

* Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.

* Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.

* Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

* Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.

* Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.

* Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.

* Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 

* The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.

* Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.

* Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.

* Disablement Benefits–

* Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.

* Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.

* Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.

* Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

* Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.

* Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.

* Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.

* Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.

* Healthy-work force.

questions.text: 55. A 60-year-old man suffered from acute chest pain, sweating, lightheadedness, and nausea 1 day back. Laboratory reports revealed raised cardiac troponin. This patient had an episode of myocardial infarction one day back. Therefore, LDH-1 is likely to be raised in this case of myocardial infarction.

Normally LDH-2 (H3M1) concentration in blood is greater than LDH-1 (H4), but this pattern is reversed in myocardial infarction; this is called the flipped pattern.

LDH enzyme is a tetramer with 4 subunits. But the subunit may be either H (heart) or M (muscle) polypeptide chains.

questions.text: 56. Staphylococcus aureus was isolated from the sputum culture of an elderly male suspected to have hospital-acquired pneumonia. You perform the Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method to check if the S.aureus strain is methicillin resistant. Which is the culture medium used in this test?
questions.solution:
Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar is used in Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method of antibiotic sensitivity testing. 

To perform Kirby-Bauer’s disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

* Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method

* Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method

* Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E–test (Epsilometer)

questions.text: 57. A 60-year-old male patient with prostatic cancer presents with complaints of hip pain and back pain. Further evaluation confirms the presence of metastatic bone lesions. Which of the following statements incorrectly describes metastatic bone lesions?

choices.text: Tumour cells directly resorb bone in osteolytic lesions
It mainly involves the axial skeleton
It is associated with spread via Batson plexus of veins
The above condition predominantly shows osteoblastic lesions

questions.solution:
With respect to metastatic bone lesions, tumour cells do not directly resorb bone in osteolytic lesions. They release substances like prostaglandins, cytokines, and PTHrP, which causes osteoblasts and stromal cells to up-regulate RANKL, hence promoting osteoclastic activity.

Metastatic tumours are the most common form of skeletal malignancy as compared to primary bone cancers. The radiographic appearance of metastases may be purely lytic (bone destroying), purely blastic (bone forming), or mixed lytic and blastic. 

They spread via (1) direct extension, (2) lymphatic or hematogenous dissemination and (3) intraspinal seeding via the Batson plexus of veins. 

Most metastases involve the axial skeleton (vertebral column, pelvis, ribs, skull, and sternum) where the marrow has a rich capillary network,  facilitating the implantation and growth of the tumour cells.

Prostatic adenocarcinoma predominantly shows osteoblastic lesions, whereas malignant melanoma and carcinomas of the kidney, lung, and gastrointestinal tract show osteolytic lesions.

The goals of therapy are symptomatic relief and prevention of further spread. Treatment options include systemic chemotherapy or immunotherapy, localized radiation, and bisphosphonates. Pathologic fractures may need to be stabilised surgically, especially if the spine is affected by metastases.

questions.text: 59. A male patient was posted for abscess drainage from the ischioanal fossa. While draining the abscess, the surgeon injures the nerve present in Alcock's canal. Which nerve is injured in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
The nerve that passes through Alcock's canal and is injured in the given scenario is the pudendal nerve.

Alcock's canal or pudendal canal is an enclosed fascia along the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa. Its contents include:

* Internal pudendal artery

* Internal pudendal vein

* Pudendal nerve

The pudendal nerve originates from the ventral rami of S2, S3, and S4 of the sacral plexus. It exits out of the pelvis by passing through the greater sciatic foramen. It then enters the perineum below the pelvic floor. 

In the pudendal canal, the pudendal nerve gives off the inferior rectal nerve, perineal nerve, and dorsal nerve of the penis or clitoris.

In females, the pudendal nerve supplies sensory branches to the lower of the vagina. Therefore, in vaginal surgeries, anesthesia can be infiltrated near the ischial spine by a needle passed through the vaginal wall and then guided by a finger.

The image given below shows the contents and boundaries of the ischioanal fossa.

Option A: Obturator nerve is formed by ventral divisions of L2, L3, and L4 of the lumbar plexus. It descends within the psoas major and then on the lateral wall of the pelvis before entering the obturator foramen to enter the thigh. It has no branches in the abdomen or pelvis.

Option B: Genitofemoral nerve is formed by the ventral rami of L1, and L2 of the lumbar plexus. It pierces the psoas major and emerges out on the anterior surface. It descends and crosses obliquely behind the ureter and divides into genital and femoral branches.

Option D: Accessory obturator nerve is formed by the L2 and L3 of the lumbar plexus. It runs on the posterior surface of the superior pubic ramus. It supplies the pectineus and hip joint.

questions.text: 60. Which of the following statements is false regarding the cartilage shown?

choices.text: Corniculate cartilage is an example of this cartilage type

questions.solution:
The cartilage shown in the image above is hyaline cartilage. Corniculate cartilage is an elastic cartilage. 

Hyaline cartilage can be identified by homogenous matrix and chondrocytes arranged as cell nests in lacunae. It is covered by the perichondrium and undergoes calcification with aging. Among the cartilages of the larynx-thyroid, cricoid, and arytenoid (except for the apices) are hyaline cartilages. Whereas epiglottis, corniculate, apex of the arytenoids, and cuneiform are elastic cartilages. 

The following image shows hyaline cartilage:



The fibrocartilage is an intermediate between dense fibrous connective tissue (tendons and ligaments) and hyaline cartilage. It consists of bundles of thick collagen fibers (both type I and II) with rows of chondrocytes present between the bundles. They are not covered by perichondrium.

Fibrocartilage is found in:

* Articular discs (temporomandibular joint and sternoclavicular joint)

* Intervertebral discs

* Menisci

* Glenoid and acetabular labrum  

* Pubic symphysis

* Manubriosternal joint

* The lining of the bony grooves for tendons

The following image shows fibrocartilage:



The elastic cartilage resembles the hyaline cartilage in that it contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibers containing elastin protein. The elastic cartilage is also known as yellow fibrocartilage.

Elastic cartilage is found in:

* External ear

* External auditory meatus

* Auditory tube

* Corniculate cartilage

* Epiglottis

* Apices of arytenoids - Apex

Pearl PM2313: Types of Cartilage

The most likely diagnosis is bedsore or pressure sore. All of the above statements are true about pressure sores except stage 2 is full-thickness skin loss up.

Stage 2 corresponds to partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis.

Pressure sores, also known as bedsores, pressure ulcers, or decubitus ulcers, are defined as tissue necrosis with ulceration due to prolonged pressure. When the external pressure exceeds the capillary occlusive pressure, blood flow ceases leading to tissue anoxia, necrosis, and ulceration. An external pressure of >30 mmHg leads to the formation of pressure sores.

The common sites of pressure sores in decreasing frequency are ischium, greater trochanter, sacrum, heel, malleolus (lateral followed by medial), and occiput.

Staging system for the description of pressure sores:

Stage 1 - Non-blanchable erythema without a breach in the epidermis Stage 2 - Partial-thickness skin loss involving the epidermis and dermis Stage 3 - Full-thickness skin loss extending into the subcutaneous tissue but not through underlying fascia Stage 4 - Full-thickness skin loss through fascia with extensive tissue destruction, maybe involving muscle, bone, tendon, or joint

Below is the image showing the stages of pressure sore.



Management:

Prevention is the best treatment for pressure sores. They can be prevented with good skincare, the use of air-fluidized beds, special pressure-dispersion cushions, or foams. Fecal or urinary diversion can be considered in special cases.

The position of the bedridden patients should be changed once every 2 hours and wheel-chair bound patients should be taught to get off their chairs for 10 seconds every 10 minutes.

Surgical management of pressure sores follows the same principles involved in acute wound treatment. Prior to the operation, the pressure sores should be adequately debrided, and vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) can be used to promote the growth of granulation tissue required for surgical closure. Large skin flaps that have muscle with sensory innervation are best for reconstruction.

VAC is done by applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125 mmHg to hasten debridement and promote granulation tissue formation. Negative pressure decreases edema, removes interstitial fluid, and increases blood flow. This decreases bacterial growth and increases cell proliferation.

questions.text: 62. An 8-year-old boy presented with abdominal pain, swelling of knee joints and non-blanching palpable purpura on the legs. His platelet levels are normal and his urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. An immunofluorescence study of his skin biopsy is given below. What is the immunoglobulin commonly involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the immunofluorescence study of the skin biopsy showing IgA and C3 deposition in the superficial capillaries of the skin is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura. The immunoglobulin commonly involved in the pathogenesis of this condition is IgA. 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), also known as IgA vasculitis, is a common small vessel vasculitis affecting children of 3-8 years of age. It is a type III hypersensitivity reaction characterised by the deposition of IgA in the small vessels of the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidney, resulting in vasculitis.

The exact etiology of HSP remains unknown. But, it usually occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection caused by group A Streptococcus, Staphylococcus aureus, Mycoplasma, and Adenovirus.

Clinical features of HSP include: 

* Palpable purpura is symmetric and occurs in the lower extremities, extensor aspect of the upper limbs, and buttocks

* Arthralgia and arthritis - commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints

* Gastrointestinal manifestations - abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and intussusception

* Renal manifestations - microscopic hematuria, hypertension, and progressive glomerulonephritis

The image given below shows palpable purpura in the lower limbs seen in HSP.



Laboratory findings seen in HSP are nonspecific and include leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, mild anemia, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP). The platelet count is usually normal. A skin biopsy specimen can be useful in confirming leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence. Rarely, IgG and IgM deposits may also be seen.

Glucocorticoids such as prednisolone are used for the treatment of gastrointestinal manifestations in HSP. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine.

questions.text: 63. A 38-year-old G3P2L2 presents at 9 weeks of amenorrhea. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 6 months ago. You inform her about the importance of blood sugar control and about the fetal anomalies that can occur due to diabetes. Which of the following is true about this disease?

choices.text: Poor glycemic control can cause spontaneous abortions in 1st trimester
Diabetic complications cannot be avoided by better glycemic control
Neonatal hypoglycemia is not seen in these cases
Microsomia incidence increases when blood glucose is elevated

questions.solution:
This patient who was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus 6 months before her pregnancy has pregestational diabetes mellitus. Poor glycemic control can lead to 1st-trimester abortions. Women with HbA1c >12% and/or fasting blood sugars of >120mg/dl have an elevated risk of early pregnancy loss.   

Overt diabetes in pregnancy is defined as hyperglycemia that was first recognized during pregnancy that meets the thresholds of diabetes in non-pregnant adults. Pregestational diabetes is diagnosed when women are known to have diabetes before pregnancy. Gestational diabetes is when women are diagnosed to have diabetes during pregnancy that is not clearly overt. 

Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus during pregnancy can lead to complications in the fetus and mother. These include: 

* Fetal effects: 

* Spontaneous abortions

* Preterm delivery

* Malformations

* Altered fetal growth

* Unexplained fetal demise

* Hydramnios

* Neonatal effects: 

* Respiratory distress syndrome

* Hypoglycemia

* Hypocalcemia

* Hyperbilirubinemia and polycythemia

* Cardiomyopathy

* Long term cognitive development

* Increased risk to develop diabetes

* Maternal effects: 

* Preeclampsia

* Diabetic nephropathy

* Diabetic retinopathy

* Diabetic neuropathy

* Diabetic ketoacidosis

* Infections

Many complications of pregestational diabetes that occur in pregnancy can be prevented by periconceptional glycemic control. It is advisable to get the blood sugars under control before planning pregnancy as the risk of complications can be markedly reduced.  The complication risk is also related to the degree of underlying cardiac and renal disease.   

Poorly controlled overt diabetes, preconceptionally and during early pregnancy, is responsible for elevated fetal malformation risk. This risk is higher than in gestational diabetes which causes high sugars later in the pregnancy. Fetal macrosomia is seen with gestational diabetes, risk of malformations is quite low.

Neonatal hypoglycemia is seen in both overt and gestational diabetes mellitus. Chronic maternal hyperglycemia can cause hyperplasia of fetal beta-islet cells causing hyperinsulinemia and hypoglycemia.  

Note: Macrosomia is seen in infants of diabetic mothers, not microsomia.

questions.text: 64. Which of the following is not a potential complication of rapid sequence intubation (RSI)?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is not a potential complication of rapid sequence intubation (RSI), but hypotension is a potential complication.

The following are the potential complications of RSI:

* Hypoxia - occurs due to oxygen levels dropping during a short apnea episode before the endotracheal tube is secured

* Hypotension - mainly observed in hemodynamically unstable patients

* Regurgitation - rare, but occurs if preventive maneuvers such as application of cricoid pressure fail

* Aspiration - incidence is rare but occurs in 0.15% of cases. This leads to potential complications such as tracheal irritation, infection, airway obstruction, and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

* Difficult or failed airway

RSI is a technique of anesthesia induction in patients who are at an increased risk of gastric regurgitation and pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents. Common cases include pregnancy, full stomach, intestinal obstruction, poorly controlled gastroesophageal reflux disease, morbid obesity, and diabetic gastroparesis. The goal is to intubate rapidly to minimize the time between the loss of consciousness and securing of the airway with a cuffed endotracheal tube.

questions.text: 66. Which of the following statements is true about iodine-based contrast media?

choices.text: They do not interfere with the clotting time
Iohexol is an ionic iodine-based contrast
They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys
They are used in magnetic resonance imaging

questions.solution:
Iodine-based contrast media are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media:

Iodine provides the radio-opacity, while the other compounds act as carriers of iodine. They are commonly used in angiography and computed tomography. They interfere with the clotting times. Hence, clotting tests are usually avoided until 6 hours after the administration of contrast media. They are excreted unchanged via the kidneys.

Iodine-based contrast media are classified as ionic and non-ionic, based on the nature of the compound to which the iodine is bound. Ionic media consists of iodine bound to inorganic compounds, while non-ionic media consists of iodine bound to an organic compound. The common examples of ionic and non-ionic iodine-based contrast media are iothalamate and iohexol, respectively.

questions.text: 67. Which of the following patterns of valvular vegetations is likely to be seen in a patient who presents with the following finding?

Small, bland vegetations on the line of closure

questions.solution:
The image depicts a classic butterfly shaped malar rash typical of SLE, which is associated with Libman-Sacks Endocarditis characterised by small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve.

Libman Sacks Endocarditis is a fibrinous endocarditis typically seen in association with systemic lupus erythematosus, although the incidence is now lower due to early initiation of steroids. The lesions develop due to immune complex deposition with complement activation, an example of Type III hypersensitivity. There is intense vasculitis and fibrinoid necrosis of the valve leaflets. It is also seen in antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA).

SLE is associated with cardiac involvement due to inflammatory activity and while pericarditis is the most common cardiac manifestation, myocarditis and endocarditis are also seen and predispose patients to valvular insufficiency, ventricular dysfunction and heart failure. Patients are also at higher risk for atherosclerosis and MI.

questions.text: 68. On which chromosome are HLA genes located?
questions.solution:
The genes encoding HLA molecules are clustered on a short arm of chromosome 6 (6p).

The function of MHC molecules is to display peptide fragments of protein antigens for recognition by antigen-specific T cells. In humans, the MHC molecules are called human leukocyte antigens (HLA) because they were initially detected on leukocytes by the binding of antibodies. The combination of HLA alleles in each individual is called the HLA haplotype.

The HLA system is highly polymorphic. Each individual’s HLA alleles differ from the other. It has to be checked before organ transplantation.

questions.text:
69. Untreated syphilis passes through 4 stages from primary to late syphilis. Arrange the following features in the order of their occurrence.

* Positive serology with no clinical features

* Macular or papular syphilides

* Syphilitic gummata

* Chancre with bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 4,2,1,3.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema palladium. It is usually acquired through sexual contact and co-exists with other sexually transmitted diseases. However, congenital syphilis is acquired as a transplacental infection. The stages of untreated syphilis in the order of their occurrence are:

* Primary syphilis presents as a papule on external genitalia that rapidly ulcerates to form a primary chancre. Inguinal lymphadenopathy usually accompanies the primary syphilitic lesion. The chancre in men is most commonly on the glans penis. They are primarily on the cervix and labia in women.

* Secondary syphilis is the stage when generalized manifestations of syphilis appear on the skin and mucous membranes. A rash is commonly seen and this stage may be preceded by constitutional symptoms such as fever, sore throat, and malaise. The rash, known as syphilides is coppery-red, non-itchy, and symmetrical. It is initially macular, then progresses to papular syphilides.

*

Latent syphilis is the stage when there are no clinical features of the active disease but serological testing for the disease is positive.  

* Late syphilis (tertiary syphilis) commonly presents as superficial or nodular punched out ulcers or gummas (granulomas appearing as cutaneous plaques or nodules with central ulceration) appears 3-10 years after infection. It may also present as red nodules (nodular syphilides), neurosyphilis, and cardiovascular syphilis. 

Serological testing is done using standard non-treponemal antibody tests like VDRL and rapid plasma reagin (RPR). Specific treponemal antibody tests like TPHA (T. pallidum hemagglutination assay) and FTA-ABS (fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test) are further required. 

Microscopically, Trepenoma palladium is identified with characteristic corkscrew morphology and motility on darkfield microscopy.

Parenteral penicillin G is the drug of choice for all stages of syphilis. If the patient has a history of drug allergies, it is advisable to keep the patient under observation for 15 to 20 mins after injection. An emergency kit for the management of anaphylaxis should always be available.

Treatment of recent sexual contacts is recommended.

Pearl PM2340: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

* Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.

* Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes

* Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:



* A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.

* C & D: Condyloma lata.

* E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia

* F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.

* G: Pigmentary plaques

* H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions

* Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

* Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor

* Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  

* CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta

* CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

* Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection

* Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: 70. A 44-year-old female patient presents to the casualty with complaints of sudden onset of pain in the abdomen. On examination, there is a palpable tympanic swelling in the left side of the abdomen. X-ray abdomen of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the X-ray are suggestive of cecal volvulus. It is differentiated from sigmoid volvulus as there is only a single air-fluid level and the lower end of the dilatation is not pointed to the pelvis.

Cecal volvulus can only occur when the cecum and ascending colon arc on a mesentery. This is often associated with a degree of malrotation. It is commonly seen in females of 4th and 5th decade. They present with features of acute intestinal obstruction. Initially, the obstruction may be partial and the patient can pass feces and flatus.

A palpable tympanic swelling in the midline or the left side may be seen in 25% of the cases.

Radiological findings include cecal dilatation, single air-fluid level, and absence of gas in the distal colon. CT shows a whirl sign, which is also seen in the midgut volvulus.

If there are no concerns of ischemia, a barium enema can be used to confirm the diagnosis. The characteristic findings include the absence of barium in the cecum and bird beak deformity.

Other options:

Sigmoid volvulus- It is a cause of large bowel obstruction and occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. Sigmoid volvulus is differentiated from a cecal volvulus by its ahaustral wall and the lower end pointing to the pelvis. Abdominal radiographs will show a large, inverted U-shaped dilated loop of the colon, often with two air-fluid levels one in each limb of the loop.

Specific radiographic signs:

* Coffee bean sign

* Frimann-Dahl's sign - three dense lines converge towards the site of obstruction

* Bird of prey sign

* Absent rectal gas

The radiograph given below is that of sigmoid volvulus.



Differences between small bowel and large bowel obstruction:

  Small bowel Large bowel
Valvulae conniventes Present in jejunum Absent
No. of Loops Many Few
Distribution of loops Central Peripheral
Haustra Absent Present
Diameter 3-5 cm >5 cm
Solid feces Absent Present


An erect radiograph of small bowel obstruction with multiple air-fluid levels is shown below.



The dilated proximal small bowel is predominantly gas filled with a few air fluid levels.

More distally, the small bowel is fluid-filled and bubbles of gas are trapped between the valvulae conniventes, producing a chain of bubbles. This is known as a "string of beads" appearance.

Intussusception - It occurs when a portion of the alimentary tract is telescoped into an adjacent segment. The characteristic clinical triad is pain, red-currant jelly stools, and palpable sausage-shaped mass.

Radiological findings:

* Target sign, pseudokidney sign, and crescent in a doughnut sign in USG

* Coiled spring appearance on double contrast barium enema

The image given below shows the coiled spring appearance-



Pearl PM1804: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign



 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 



 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign



 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 



 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign



 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.



Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 



 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.



 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.



 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).



Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: 71. Which of the following gives rise to the structure marked in the given image of the liver?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the falciform ligament of the liver. It is an embryological derivative of ventral mesentery, which itself arises from septum transversum. 

Septum transversum is the undifferentiated lateral plate mesoderm at the cranial end of the embryo. It gives rise to:

* Central tendon of diaphragm

* Fibrous pericardium

* Liver stroma

* Ventral mesogastrium

As the liver grows into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum, ventral mesentery is divided into two parts:

* Lesser omentum, which extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver (hepato-gastric and hepato-duodenal ligaments)

* Ligaments of the liver: all ligaments of the liver except ligamentum teres are derived from the ventral mesentery. This includes falciform ligament, right and left triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments.



Dorsal mesentery connects the abdominal organs to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut. Depending on the abdominal organ to which it is attached, it has multiple regions: dorsal mesogastrium, mesoduodenum, mesentery proper (to the small intestine), mesocolon, mesoappendix, mesosigmoid, and mesorectum. The dorsal mesogastrium gives rise to greater omentum, gastrosplenic ligament, lienorenal ligament, and gastrophrenic ligament.

questions.text: 72. Which of the following is true for Daridorexant?
questions.solution:
Daridorexant is an Orexin Antagonist used for the treatment of Insomnia.

Insomnia is defined as difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep. It may be transient or persistent. Daridorexant is an orexin receptor antagonist indicated for treating adult patients with insomnia characterized by difficulties with sleep onset or sleep maintenance. The orexin neuropeptide signalling system plays a role in wakefulness. Daridorexant blocks the binding of wake-promoting neuropeptides orexin A and orexin B to their receptors suppressing the wake drive. It is an oral preparation and the most common adverse effects are headache and somnolence or fatigue. Suvorexant is also an Orexin Receptor antagonist used for the treatment of insomnia.

Other options: Melatonin analogue approved for the treatment of insomnia is Ramelteon. It is used mainly in conditions with difficulties of sleep onset. Tasimelteon and Agomelatine are other drugs included in this drug class.

Hypocretin neurons activate wake-promoting pathways in the CNS. A deficiency of hypocretin, likely due to autoimmune destruction of hypocretin neurons, produces narcolepsy, a condition of hypersomnia, including excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden attacks of sleep. Melatonin antagonists and Orexin agonists are not used in humans to treat narcolepsy. 

Rather CNS stimulants, which enhance transmission in monoamine pathways like modafinil and armodafinil are used in the treatment of Narcolepsy.

questions.text: 73. The lung autopsy finding of a primigravida mother who died of severe shortness of breath following the delivery of a healthy baby is given below. The mechanisms involved in this condition are listed below. In the morbidity and mortality of this illness, which of the following mechanisms is less significant than the others?

choices.text: Components of the innate immune system

questions.solution:
The given lung autopsy finding shows the presence of laminated swirls of fetal squamous cells in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature, which suggests that amniotic fluid embolism was the cause of death in this clinical scenario. Rather than amniotic debris mechanically obstructing the pulmonary vessels, a large portion of the morbidity and mortality associated with amniotic fluid embolism results from the biochemical activation of coagulation factors, elements of the innate immune system, and release of vasoactive substances.

Acute pulmonary hypertension and right heart failure are caused by vasoactive substances, resulting in hypoxia, left heart failure, pulmonary edema, and widespread alveolar destruction.

Amniotic fluid embolism is a potentially fatal complication of labour and the postpartum period. The symptoms include sudden onset of severe dyspnea, cyanosis, and shock, followed by neurologic impairment ranging from headache to seizures and coma, and DIC.

The underlying cause is amniotic fluid or foetal tissue infusion into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or uterine vein rupture. Autopsy findings will show the presence of squamous cells shed from the fetal skin, lanugo hair, fat from vernix caseosa, and mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract in the maternal pulmonary microvasculature.



Pearl PM0324: Causes of Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) is an acute, subacute, or chronic thrombohemorrhagic disorder occurring as a secondary complication in a variety of diseases. It is characterized by the activation of the coagulation sequence that leads to the formation of microthrombi throughout the microcirculation of the body. As a consequence of the thrombotic diathesis, there is a consumption of platelets, fibrin, and coagulation factors and, secondarily, activation of fibrinolytic mechanisms.

Causes of DIC:

Obstetric complications
  • Abruptio placenta
  • Retained dead fetus
  • Septic abortion
  • Amniotic fluid embolism
  • Toxemia
Infections
  • Sepsis
  • Meningococcemia
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Aspergillosis
  • Malaria
  • Toxemia 
Neoplasms
  • Ca. pancreas
  • Ca. prostate
  • Ca. lung
  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia
Massive Tissue Injury
  • Traumatic injury
  • Burns
  • Extensive surgery
Miscellaneous
  • Acute intravascular hemolysis
  • Snake bite
  • Shock
  • Stroke
  • Vasculitis
  • Aortic aneurysm
  • Liver disease


Pearl PM0317: Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

 Parameters of the coagulation pathway and its uses

Parameter Uses
Prothrombin Time (PT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the extrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal PT is 11–13 seconds.
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) It is used to monitor the functioning of the intrinsic and the common coagulation pathways. Normal aPTT is 25–35 seconds. A relatively rare cause of prolonged aPTT is the presence of antibodies against coagulation plasma proteins called inhibitors. It can be seen due to the following reasons: Hemophilia A and B patients receiving clotting factors to control their bleeding episodes, Pregnancy, Autoimmune diseases, Malignancies (lymphoma, prostate cancer), and Dermatologic conditions.
Thrombin time (TT) It is used for testing the conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin and depends on adequate fibrinogen levels. 
Bleeding time (BT) It is the time taken for a standardized skin puncture to stop bleeding. It tests the ability of blood vessels to constrict and platelets to form a hemostatic plug. 
Fibrin degradation products (FDPs) They are used to assess the fibrinolytic activity, and they are increased in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).

questions.text: 74. A 62-year-old man was diagnosed to have a brain tumor. The histological appearance of the excised tumor is shown in the image given below. Which type of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutation is most likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the histological image showing extensive necrosis with pseudo-palisading of malignant nuclei and endothelial cell proliferation, is suggestive of glioblastoma, which is commonly associated with IDH-wild-type mutations.

Gliomas constitute the most common type of primary brain tumor. They are classified as follows:

* Astrocytomas

* Localized type- eg. pilocytic astrocytoma (grade 1)

* Diffuse infiltrating type- Can be IDH mutant or IDH wild type

* Diffuse astrocytoma (grade 2)

* Anaplastic astrocytoma (grade 3)

* Glioblastoma (grade 4)

* Oligodendrogliomas- IDH mutant, 1p/19q co-deletion

* Ependymomas- NF2 gene mutations

Glioblastoma affects people usually in the sixth or seventh decade. These tumors may arise de novo or may result from a malignant transformation of lower-grade astrocytomas. Mutations of isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH), PTEN, and epidermal growth factor receptor gene (EGFR) are implicated in the pathogenesis.

 

The majority of the tumors (90%) have IDH wild-type mutation, and the remaining have IDH mutant type. Clinically, the patient presents with headaches, seizures due to raised intracranial pressure, or focal neurologic deficits, depending upon the site involved. 

Grossly, glioblastomas are found to infiltrate the brain tissue and are poorly delineated. They have grayish tumor cells with central yellowish necrosis and multiple areas of hemorrhages.



Microscopically, they are composed of poorly differentiated pleomorphic astrocytic cells with nuclear atypia and high mitotic activity. Necrosis and florid microvascular proliferation are characteristic. They exhibit pseudopalisading—a dense arrangement of tumor cells lining up around the foci of tumor necrosis.



They preferentially spread along the condensed white matter tracts such as corticospinal tracts and corpus callosum and can give rise to the butterfly glioma, involving the contralateral hemisphere. 

Radiologically, glioblastomas appear as a large ring-enhancing heterogeneous mass with central necrosis and surrounding edema that crosses the corpus callosum into both frontal lobes.

The image given below shows MRI findings seen in glioblastomas. Note the butterfly morphology of the tumor:



Standard treatment includes surgery followed by a combination of radiotherapy and chemotherapy with temozolomide following surgical resection. Bevacizumab, which is a vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) antibody, may be used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma.

Pearl PM2482: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

* Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas

* Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 

* Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions

* Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 



 

Medulloblastoma:

* Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells

* Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped

* Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil



 

Ependymoma:

* Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 

* Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel



 

Oligodendroglioma:

* Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 

* Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries



 

Retinoblastoma: 

* Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei

* Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen

* Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center

* Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: 75. Which of the following statement is true about Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY)?

choices.text: Autosomal recessive form of type 2 diabetes mellitus
MODY type 3 is most common form

questions.solution:
The true statement about MODY from the given options is that type 3 is the most common form.

Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY):

It is an autosomal-dominant form of type 2 diabetes mellitus affecting the younger population with a strong positive family history. It is a monogenic diabetes i.e only one gene mutation is present. Clinical features include glucose intolerance, along with association with renal cysts. There is insulinopenia with no antibodies and no insulin resistance. The patient does not have obesity, hypertension, or hyperlipidemia and responds to sulfonylureas.

There are 5 types of MODY:

* Types 1,3,5: HNF Mutation – Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor. Type 3 MODY is the most common form.

* Type 2: Glucokinase mutation

* Type 4: Insulin Promotor Factor-1 (PDX 1) mutation.

questions.text: 76. A male patient presented with a knee dislocation. The nerve at the level of the fibular neck is injured. All of the following can be used for the treatment of this condition, except ______.

choices.text: Transfer of tibialis posterior tendon on the dorsum of the foot.

questions.solution:
The common peroneal nerve is generally injured at the level of the fibular neck. It leads to a foot drop. Bohler-Braun splint is used in the fracture of the femur. It is an immobilizer frame, which is not suitable for transportation and hence cannot be used for nerve injuries.

The common peroneal nerve supplies the extensors and evertors of the foot. Injury to the common peroneal nerve results in foot drop. So the patient attempts to lift the leg high enough during walking so that the foot does not drag on the floor. This is known as a high-stepping gait.

Causes of common peroneal nerve injury:

* Fracture of the fibular neck

* Pressure from a splint or a plaster cast over the neck of the fibula

* Knee dislocations.

Toe-raising splint and ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) brace are used for conservative treatment. Reconstructive procedures like transfer of the tibialis posterior tendon on the dorsum of the foot can be done.

questions.text: 77. A 36-year-old female notices a midline swelling in her neck. On ultrasound, a unifocal 2*2 cm lesion is noticed in the right lobe of the thyroid without any lymph node enlargement. USG-guided FNAC is given below. What surgical management is recommended for this patient?

choices.text: Total thyroidectomy with central neck dissection

questions.solution:
The above clinical diagnosis of papillary carcinoma thyroid of unifocal lesion size 2*2cm without any lymph node enlargement is managed with hemithyroidectomy.

Papillary carcinoma thyroid is managed by hemithyroidectomy/lobectomy or total thyroidectomy depending upon the stage of the disease. Central neck dissection is done only in case of involvement of level VI nodes. If level VI plus other lymph nodes are enlarged - then total thyroidectomy + central neck dissection + modified radical neck dissection is done. In case of tumor size >4cm (T3 &T4), prophylactic central neck dissection is done.

Earlier, total thyroidectomy was the preferred surgery. However, according to the latest updates, hemithyroidectomy is an acceptable alternative to total thyroidectomy for low-risk differentiated thyroid carcinoma. Papillary, follicular, and Hurtle cell carcinoma are considered “differentiated” because they arise from the thyroid follicular epithelial cells and generally retain the ability to organify iodine.

Differentiated thyroid carcinoma that is low-risk includes:

* Unilateral lesion

* Size between 1-4cm

* No extranodal extension.

Exceptions to the above include:

* Radiation-induced Differentiated carcinoma thyroid.

* Familial nonmedullary thyroid carcinoma.

* Multifocal bilateral lesion.

* Extra thyroidal extension present

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine-sufficient areas, children, and those exposed to ionizing radiation. The mean age of presentation is the 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia, and dyspnea are associated with local invasion. It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

* Branching papillae 

* Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk

* Psammoma bodies.

* Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei

* Pseudo-inclusions

* Nuclear grooves.

 Below is the histopathological image of papillary carcinoma of the thyroid with characteristic Orphan Annie eye nuclei.



Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain. It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text:
80. An 8-year-old boy presented with jaundice and splenomegaly. His lab investigation results are given below. He is also found to have ankyrin gene mutation. What are the changes seen in his osmotic fragility curve?

Hemoglobin- decreased Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration- increased Mean corpuscular volume - decreased Red cell distribution width - increased
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, lab investigations, and ankyrin gene mutation are suggestive of Hereditary spherocytosis (HS). There is increased osmotic fragility and hence the curve will shift towards the right. 

Osmotic fragility is the measure of red blood cells to resist hemolysis when placed in reducing concentrations of saline solution. Normal hemolysis begins at a concentration of 0.5% NaCl and is completed at a concentration of 0.3% NaCl. It may be altered as follows:

* Increased fragility is seen as a right shift in the graph. Here hemolysis begins at a higher concentration of the hypotonic saline solution.

* Decreased fragility is seen as a left shift in the graph. Here hemolysis begins at a much lower concentration of the hypotonic saline solution (more dilute solution)

In hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility of the red blood cells is characteristically increased. These spherocytes lyse more easily in hypotonic solution than normal discoid RBCs due to the low surface area to volume ratio.



Hereditary spherocytosis is a type of hemolytic anemia that is most commonly inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. Mutations in α-spectrin, β-spectrin, ankyrin, band 4.2, and band 3 weaken the association of the membrane skeleton with the overlying plasma membrane, making them spheroid and less deformable. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and phagocytosed by macrophages.

The ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis. Mutations in the spectrin gene may result in severe forms of HS.



Patients usually present with anemia, fatigue, splenomegaly, and jaundice and the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. The unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia predisposes the patient to develop gallstones. An aplastic crisis might occur when red cell production is halted due to parvovirus infection. This lasts 1 to 2 weeks, usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

The most common peripheral smear finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor. This is, however, a non-specific finding. Other features seen are reticulocytosis, Howell-Jolly bodies (dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs), marrow erythroid hyperplasia, and hemosiderosis.

questions.text: 82. A G2P1 female with 5 months of gestation comes to the OPD with a complaint as shown in the picture. On examination, her BP is 130/90 mmHg. What is the appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shown is of edema and bed rest is the appropriate treatment for women having edema in pregnancy.

The cause of physiological edema is due to increased venous pressure of the inferior extremities by the gravid uterus pressing on the common iliac veins.

Features of the physiological edema:

* Slight degree (ankle edema)

* Usually confined to one leg, more on the right

* Unassociated with any other features of preeclampsia or proteinuria

* Disappears on rest alone

* Other pathologies of cardiac, renal, and hematological are absent.

Note: For this patient to qualify for preeclampsia, she should have blood pressure that exceeds 140/90 mm Hg or greater and should be documented on two occasions, at least four hours apart.

questions.text: 83. An 8-month-old child was brought for evaluation after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 5 minutes. The examination is positive for a fever of 103°F and otitis media. Neurological findings are normal. Which of the following factors increases the risk of recurrence of this condition?

choices.text: High serum sodium at the time of presentation

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an 8-month-old child presenting with generalized tonic-clonic seizures lasting for 5 minutes along with high-grade fever and otitis media in a neurologically healthy state suggests febrile seizure. The age of the child less than 1 year increases its risk of recurrence. 

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Risk factors for febrile seizures:

Major Minor
Age < 1 year Family history of epilepsy or febrile seizures
Duration of fever < 24 hours Complex febrile seizure (Option A)
Fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F) Male gender (Option B)
  Lower serum sodium levels at the time of presentation (Option D)


Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months of age to exclude meningitis. Electroencephalogram and neuroimaging are advised for children with suspected epilepsy or neurological abnormalities.

Acute treatment of febrile seizures includes lorazepam and midazolam for seizures lasting more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes. The use of antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but does not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.

questions.text:
84. A 33-year-old lady comes for a routine check-up at 34 weeks of gestation when her blood pressure is found to be 170/118 mmHg. Her urine analysis shows proteinuria 3+. Which of the following statements are true about the management of this situation?

* Oral Captopril can be used as a second-line drug.

* Labetalol is safe in asthmatics and cardiac failure patients.

* The maximum dose of labetalol that can be given is 300 mg.

* Intravenous labetalol is the drug of choice.

* Sodium nitroprusside is the first-line drug.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe pre-eclampsia with hypertensive crisis (BP>160/110 mmHg). Intravenous Labetalol is the drug of choice for controlling blood pressure in severe pre-eclampsia and the maximum dose that can be given is 300 mg. Therefore, options 3 and 4 are correct. 

Drugs used in the management of hypertensive crisis.

Hydralazine 10 mins 5 mg IV every 30 mins  30 mg IV 10 mg/hr

Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and is hence contraindicated in pregnancy.

Labetalol is avoided in women having asthma or cardiac failure.

Sodium nitroprusside is only given after treatment with other drugs has failed.

questions.text: 85. A 62-year-old male presented with multiple slow-growing nodules on the scalp. A biopsy was taken and the histopathological examination revealed a jigsaw puzzle architecture as shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with multiple slow-growing nodules in the scalp and with a 'jigsaw puzzle' appearance on histopathology points toward the diagnosis of cylindromas.

Cylindroma is an appendage tumour with ductal (apocrine or eccrine) differentiation inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern due to mutation of the CYLD gene. 

Patients present with multiple smooth, firm, pink to red coloured nodules on the forehead and scalp which may or may not be pedunculated. Nodules can coalesce and produce a hatlike growth which gives the name, turban tumour.

Histopathology shows lobules of epithelial cells arranged in a jigsaw or mosaic pattern. Each lobule is composed of islands of basaloid cells in the periphery and a paler zone of cells in the centre.

It is treated with wide excision and replacement of the area by a graft.



Other options:

Basal cell carcinoma is a locally aggressive skin malignancy occurring in sun-exposed areas in elderly individuals. Histology shows peripheral palisading of tumour cells which resemble normal cells of the basal cell layer of the epidermis.



Spiradenoma is a benign tumour of the sweat gland presenting as a solitary, painful bluish dermal nodule. Histology shows lobules containing larger pale cells around the lumina and smaller darker cells at the periphery, with intervening cystic spaces and vascular channels.



Merkel cell carcinoma is a highly aggressive neuroendocrine tumour of the skin which presents as a smooth reddish round tumour. Histology shows cell nests and trabecular patterns and is often referred to as trabecular carcinoma of the skin.

questions.text:
86. Match the following

* Joule Burns

* Filigree Burns

* Scald injury

* Frost bite
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D.

Arborescent burns/ Filigree burns / Lichtenberg's flowers are superficial, thin, irregular, and tortuous markings on the skin that are indicative of a lightning strike. They resemble the branches of a tree and are usually found over the skin of the shoulders or the flanks.



Scalding is due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam. It is an injury that results from the application of liquid above 60°C or from steam i.e moist heat. Redness appears immediately followed by blistering in a few minutes. Removal of the blistered skin leaves a raw, pink surface. Blisters are surrounded by a hyperaemic zone. Scalds appear soddened and bleached but the hair does not get singed. The skin does not get blackened or charred.

Scald injuries are limited to the area of contact and are more severe at the initial point of contact. It can occur through clothing, which worsens damage due to a longer period of contact with the hot liquid and a reduced cooling effect of evaporation.

It can be 

* Immersion burns: Accidental or deliberate immersion in hot liquid, usually water.  

* Splash or spill burns: Usually accidental.  

* Steam burns: Exposure to superheated steam.

Clinical degree of scalding:

* Erythema (reddening)

* Vesication (blister formation)

* Necrosis of the dermis when deeper layers of skin are involved



Joule burns or electric marks occur due to contact with electricity and are found at the point of entry of the current. They are observed as round or oval, shallow craters, having a ridge of skin around their circumference. The floor is lined with pale flattened skin.



Frost Bite occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures. Here, tissue damage results from severe environmental cold exposure or from direct contact with a very cold object. Tissue injury results from both freezing and vascular stasis. It usually affects the distal aspects of the extremities or exposed parts of the face, such as the ears, nose, chin, and cheeks.

Clinical features include decreased sensation (especially for pain, and temperature sensations) in the acral tips and extremities. The affected area appears waxy, mottled, or violaceous. Patients may have a wood-like sensation in the affected area.

Treatment:

* Initial treatment is by rapid rewarming (or thawing), which is accomplished by immersion of the affected part in a water bath at temperatures of 37°–40°C (99°–104°F) for 30–60 minutes. Rewarming by exercise, rubbing, or friction is not advised. 

* Analgesics such as ibuprofen are often required during rewarming.

* Antithrombotics, thrombolytic, and vasodilators such as prostacyclin can be given to improve circulation after rewarming.

* Frost bites are associated with an increased risk of infections and tetanus. Therefore, the injured area should be cleaned with soap or antiseptic, and sterile dressings should be applied. Tetanus prophylaxis must be given, but, empirical antibiotics are not recommended.

* The patient must be monitored for the development of compartment syndrome.

* Elective late amputation after imaging may be required in severe cases.
