questions.text: 87. A 50-year-old woman presents with numbness in her hands, generalized weakness, and easy fatiguability. She had undergone a gastrectomy recently and she looks very pale. Her peripheral smear findings are shown below. If the condition is left untreated, which of the following will be seen?

choices.text: Large-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of proprioception
Small-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of temperature sense
Small-fiber neuropathy, causing loss of vibration sense

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of numbness, generalized weakness, and easy fatiguability suggest anemia. The history of gastrectomy and the peripheral smear showing large hypersegmented neutrophils and macro-ovalocytes depicting macrocytic anemia is suggestive of vitamin B12 deficiency. The patient is at risk of developing large-fiber neuropathy causing loss of proprioception.

Vitamin B12 deficiency typically leads to large-fiber neuropathy, which presents with loss of vibration and loss of proprioception. Small nerve fibers are spared in B12 deficiency.

Pernicious anemia is a common cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. The other causes of vitamin B12 deficiency are gastrectomy, gastric bypass surgery, inflammatory bowel disease, pancreatic insufficiency, malabsorption of cobalamin from food, and so on.

The clinical features include easy fatiguability, numbness of hands, loss of vibration and proprioception, hyperreflexia, and loss of ankle reflexes. 

Investigations reveal anemia, macrocytosis, and reduced cobalamin levels. Serum methylmalonic acid and homocysteine are elevated. Antibodies to the intrinsic factor may be seen in pernicious anemia.

Peripheral smear shows marked variation in red cell size (anisocytosis) and shape (poikilocytosis). The presence of red cells that are macrocytic and oval (macro-ovalocytes) is highly characteristic. Neutrophils are also larger than normal and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules, instead of the normal three to four.

Treatment can vary according to the regimen. One regimen consists of intramuscular injections of 1000 micrograms of cyanocobalamin weekly for a month, and then monthly thereafter.  

Note: Small-diameter myelinated and unmyelinated fibers transmit pain and temperature sensation. Hence, small-fiber neuropathies present with temperature loss or burning or stabbing pain.

Pearl PM1665: Nerve Fiber Types And Sensory Neuropathies

Depending on the nerve fibers involved (Large or Small), the sensory neuropathies are classified as follows:

B. Large fiber (Ataxic neuropathies)

questions.text: 88. The image given below shows a dermatological manifestation of
questions.solution:
The given image shows rheumatoid nodules characteristically seen along the ulnar border of the forearm. They are one of the dermatological manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis.

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the most common form of chronic inflammatory arthritis. RA is a systemic disease with a variety of extra-articular manifestations like fatigue, dermatological manifestations, lung involvement, pericarditis, peripheral neuropathy, vasculitis, and hematologic abnormalities.

The incidence of RA is more between 25 and 55 years of age. Patients typically present with early morning joint stiffness lasting more than 1 hour and eases with physical activity. The earliest involved joints are the small joints of the hands and feet.

Dermatological manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis include:

* Rheumatoid neutrophilic dermatosis: Symmetrical erythematous nodules and plaques on the dorsal aspects of the hands and arms, extensor aspects of the joints, and back of the neck, scalp, and trunk. They are sometimes tender, and ulceration and vesiculation may occur. Histologically, there is a dense diffuse infiltrate of neutrophils in the dermis.

* Vascular lesions include small infarcts around the nails, sometimes at the apex of small cutaneous nodules.

* Leg ulcers due to venous insufficiency, trauma, pressure, or arterial insufficiency.

* Linear subcutaneous bands and interstitial granulomatous dermatitis may also be seen.

Other options:

Option A: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus generally presents typically as symmetrical, slightly scaling erythema of the face and neck. Erythema of the dorsal aspect of the hands and forearms may also be seen.

Option B: The cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis generally include a facial rash, eyelid erythema and edema, nail fold changes, Gottron’s papules, extensor surface dermatosis, scalp erythema, and hair loss.

Option C: Scleroderma is characterized by varying degrees of sclerosis, fibrosis, and atrophy in the skin and subcutaneous tissues. Skin induration, calcinosis cutis, telangiectasia, hyperpigmentation, and xerosis are some dermatological manifestations.

questions.text: 89. Which of the following statements is false about congenital rubella syndrome (CRS)?

choices.text: Demonstration of IgM antibodies in infants is diagnostic
Infection during the second trimester carries highest risk for CRS
The classic triad includes cataract, cardiac abnormalities, and deafness
At birth, the virus is detectable in pharyngeal secretions

questions.solution:
Infection during the first trimester is associated with the highest incidence (85%) of cases of congenital rubella syndrome, followed by infections in second trimester (16% of cases). Maternal infection after 20 weeks of gestation is rarely associated with the disease.

Other options:

Option a: Maternal IgM antibodies against the rubella virus does not cross the placenta. Therefore, the presence of IgM rubella antibodies in infants is diagnostic of congenital rubella syndrome.  In contrast, the maternal IgG antibodies may be transferred to the infants and may be detectable for about 6 months.

Option c: The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome includes:

* Sensorineural hearing loss

* Congenital cataract

* Congenital heart disease (Most commonly: patent ductus arteriosus)

Option d: At birth, the virus is detectable in pharyngeal secretions, multiple organs, cerebrospinal fluid, urine, and rectal swabs.

Pearl PM1450: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

* The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:

* Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome

* Congenital cataract

* Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus

* Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester

* Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness

* If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities

* Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome



The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome



The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.



 Rubella:

* Also called the German measles

* Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae

* Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash

* Droplet trasmission

* The incubation period is 2-3 weeks

* The rash appears on day 1

* Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx

* Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia

* The most serious complication is encephalitis

* Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: 90. Arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals the following values: pH of 7.1 and HCO3- of 6 mEq/L. Assuming this is a case of metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis, what is the expected pCO2?
questions.solution:
The expected pCO2 value will be 17 mm Hg.

The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis, plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L - signifies metabolic acidosis. 

The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula: Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2.

Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19. 

Alternatively,

The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.25 mm Hg decrease in pCO2 for every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate.

The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L

Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.25 = 22.5

Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22.5 = 17.5 mmHg (roughly ~ 17 mmHg since the standard values are approximations)

This method is also used to assess compensation. However, Winter's formula is more accurate.

questions.text: 91. What is the name of this medium shown below, which is used in the identification of Salmonella?
questions.solution:
Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium has been shown in the given image.

It is a type of selective and indicator media. 

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

It is a differential media as well, as it brings out different characteristics of bacteria. 

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. typhi forms large black colonies, with a metallic sheen. S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

On Deoxycholate citrate media and XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) , colonies show black heads due to H2S production.

Other options:

Option 1) PLET medium is used to isolate B. anthracis. It is a selective medium consisting of polymyxin, lysozyme, ethylene diamine tetraacetic acid (EDTA) and thallous acetate added to heart infusion agar.

Option 2) XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate) agar is a selective growth medium used in the isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species. It has a pH of 7.4, with a bright pink or red colour due to the indicator phenol red. Sugar fermentation lowers the pH and the phenol red indicator turns yellow. Most gut bacteria, like Salmonella, can ferment the sugar xylose to produce acid but Shigella colonies cannot and therefore remain red.

Salmonella also metabolise thiosulfate to produce H2S or hydrogen sulphide, which leads to the formation of colonies with black centers and allows them to be differentiated from the Shigella colonies.



Option 4) Stuart Transport Medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to laboratory.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

* Sodium glycerophosphate

* Sodium thioglycollate

* Calcium chloride

* Methylene blue

* Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium:

This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium that prevents microbial proliferation. Because of this composition,n the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.

Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment so as to improve the recovery of anaerobes. Methylene blue acts as oxidation oxidation-reduction indicator. Calcium chloride maintains permeability of bacterial cells and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium.

The medium appears colorless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

questions.text: 92. Identify the uterine anomaly in the HSG given below and the class it belongs to according to AFS classification.
questions.solution:
The given HSG shows Didelphys Uterus which belongs to class 3 according to AFS classification.

questions.text: 93. All of the following are true about Sanger sequencing, except ____.

choices.text: ddNTP is used as it doesn't allow further elongation of DNA
It is used for DNA sequencing
Sanger’s reagent is 1- fluoro 2,4 dinitro benzene
Automated DNA sequencing employs techniques that require the use of radioisotopes

questions.solution:
Techniques that do not require radioisotopes are employed in automated DNA sequencing.  The manual enzymatic Sanger method employs specific dideoxynucleotides that terminate DNA strand synthesis at specific nucleotides as the strand is synthesized on purified single-stranded template DNA.

The Sanger method is used for DNA sequencing. This method uses the mechanism of synthesis of DNA by DNA polymerases. In the process of synthesis of DNA, the 3'-hydroxyl group of primer reacts with an incoming dNTP to form a new phosphodiester bond. This reaction is catalyzed by DNA polymerase.

In the Sanger sequencing method, ddNTP is used because it halts the DNA synthesis. ddNTPs can bind to the template strand but lack the 3'-hydroxyl group, which is required to add the next nucleotide. The products of this reaction are a mixture of DNA strands of varying lengths. This mixture is then separated using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis and autoradiography. This produces a pattern of bands from which the DNA sequence can be read.

The image given below shows the steps involved in Sanger's method.



Sanger’s technique was the first technique used to determine the sequence of proteins. The first protein to be sequenced by this method was insulin. Sanger’s reagent is 1- fluoro 2,4 dinitro benzene.

questions.text: 94. A 67-year-old patient presents with chronic arthritis involving multiple joints. He has a history of scaly plaques on the skin but has not taken any treatment. Findings on clinical examination and radiography are shown below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
History of scaly plaques on the skin, with the given images showing osteolysis of phalangeal bones with telescoping of the digits, indicates that it is arthritis mutilans seen in psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

Joint involvement in psoriatic arthritis can take the following forms:

* Arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP)

* Asymmetrical oligoarthritis

* Axial involvement (spine and the sacroiliac joints)

* Arthritis mutilans refers to a highly destructive form of the disease, and is the most specific finding in psoriatic arthritis

Another important feature seen in PsA is inflammation of the periarticular structures. This includes enthesitis (inflammation at the site of the insertion of ligaments and tendons), tenosynovitis, and dactylitis (diffuse swelling of the entire finger or toe, called as sausage digit). 

In patients with active arthritis, anti-TNF therapy is the first line recommended treatment. The drugs include etanercept, infliximab, adalimumab, certolizumab, and golimumab. If anti-TNF therapy is contraindicated or not tolerated, methotrexate, sulfasalazine or leflunomide may be effective. Monoclonal antibodies against IL-17 (secukinumab, ixekizumab) or IL-23 (guselkumab) are also being used for the treatment.

Pearl PM1994: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.



Image :  Pitting is the commonest manifestation of nail psoriasis.



Image: oil drops visible in the nail bed.



Image: pitting and salmon patches in fingernails.



Image: Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis – Mnemonic

“Nail – POLISH”

* P – Pitting

* O – Oil drop sign, Onycholysis

* L – Leuconychia

* I – Irregular pitting pattern

* S – Splinter Hemorrhage

* H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

questions.text: 95. A 65-year-old man presents with complaints of redness of his eye which started 3 days ago. He has no pain, no discharge, and no complaints about his vision. There was no history of trauma. His blood pressure is 126/84 mmHg. He is not on any anticoagulants. The eye appears as shown in the image below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a subconjunctival hemorrhage in the eye. Blood gets absorbed gradually in 1-3 weeks' time without treatment. Hence, reassurance to the patient is the most appropriate management.

A subconjunctival hemorrhage is also called subconjunctival ecchymosis. It is due to the rupture of small blood vessels and can occur spontaneously in elders with fragile vessels, those with systolic hypertension, or after local trauma. The condition is usually associated with a benign course.

It appears as a flat sheet of homogeneous bright red color with well-defined limits. The vision is usually unaffected. Recurrent episodes warrant investigations for a bleeding diathesis or leukemia. 

Spontaneous resolution is typical. The use of NSAIDs and aspirin to treat the condition should be avoided.

Other options:

Option A: CT scan of the head would be appropriate if the patient gives a history of trauma, which raises a suspicion of skull/orbit fracture.

Option B: Anti-hypertensive therapy would be given if the patient has high blood pressure. 

Option D: INR levels will be checked if the patient is on any anticoagulant medication or if there are recurrent episodes.

questions.text: 96. A male patient with a history of depression presents with suicidal ideation. On further questioning, he reveals that he has had a previous suicide attempt and no family support. Which of the following is not an indication for hospitalization?

choices.text: Absence of a strong social support system

questions.solution:
The ability to discuss safety planning is not an indication for hospitalization in this patient.

Indications for hospitalization for suicide prevention include the following: 

* Suicidal plan of action

* Inability to discuss safety planning

* Absence of a strong social support system

* History of impulsive behavior

* Psychotic patient 

* Precautions were taken to evade discovery

* Severe agitation, poor judgment, and refusal to accept help

A suicide attempt is a psychiatric emergency. While suicide is hard to predict, the patient may unintentionally provide clues to the same. Some high-risk factors for suicide are male sex, age above 45, unemployment, multiple attempts at suicide, and social isolation. Most people who have committed or attempted suicide have an underlying mental disorder, of which depression and schizophrenia are the most common.

During hospitalization, objects that can be used for self-harm should be removed. Anti-depressants or antipsychotics are used depending on the underlying condition. Individual therapy, group therapy, and family therapy are other useful measures.

Suicide attempts and thoughts are more common in women, but the rate of committing suicide is more in men. Suicide rates increase with age and are rare before puberty.

Pearl PM0498: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

* Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.

* Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

* Treatment-resistant depression

* Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)

* Depression with psychotic features

* Depressed suicidal pregnant women

* Refusal to eat or drink

* Imminent risk for suicide

* Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

* Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia

* Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

* Retrograde amnesia (most common)

* Partial anterograde amnesia

* Disorientation

* Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

* Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction

* Space occupying brain lesion

* Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text:
97. A young man with pulmonary tuberculosis presented with back pain. History revealed non-compliance to ATT, hence he was suspected to have Pott's spine. Pick the incorrect statement about the radiographic appearance of this condition.

ATT: Anti-tubercular treatment

choices.text: Bird's nest abscess signifies paravertebral abscess formation
Narrowing of the disc space is the earliest finding
Fibrous ankylosis of the spine is a common sequel
Sclerotic appearance indicates the healing stage

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement about Pott's spine is that fibrous ankylosis of the joints occurs as a sequel. Tuberculosis of all joints results in fibrous ankylosis except in the spine where bony ankylosis is a common sequel.

The tuberculous infection first involves the vertebral bodies and the intervertebral disc. Hence, the early radiographic features include the rarefaction/ osteopenic appearance of the involved vertebrae and the reduction or narrowing of the intervertebral disc space.

In later stages, the infection leads to para-vertebral abscess formation and vertebral destruction. These features can be seen on a radiograph as bird’s nest abscess and anterior wedging of vertebrae, respectively. When the disease is in the healing phase, the sclerotic appearance of vertebrae can be seen.

The below image shows the MRI spine of a patient with tuberculous spondylodiscitis of the lumbar spine.



The below x-ray shows a soft tissue shadow suggestive of an abscess in the paravertebral region (bird nest abscess) presenting as the widened mediastinum.



Pott's spine occurs secondary to a pulmonary or gastrointestinal primary and spreads through the Batson's plexus of veins (paravertebral plexus). It most commonly involves the dorso-lumbar region. Image showing various parts and patterns of involvement in Pott's spine.

questions.text: 98. During the routine ward rounds, a neonatologist demonstrates a reflex as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the elicited reflex?

choices.text: The onset is at 37 weeks of gestation
It disappears one month after birth
It disappears by 3-6 months of birth

questions.solution:
The reflex elicited is the Moro reflex. It disappears by 3-6 months of birth. 

Moro reflex is a primitive neonatal reflex. The infant's head is held in a semi-erect position and then allowed to fall backward onto the examiner's hand. As a response to this, there is initial extension and abduction of fingers and upper extremities. This is followed by flexion of the upper extremities and an audible cry. 

The reflex begins to develop at 28-32 weeks of gestation and is fully developed at 37 weeks. It may be present until 6 months after birth.

An asymmetric reflex can point to a fractured clavicle, brachial plexus injury, or hemiparesis. Absent Moro reflex is suggestive of central nervous system dysfunction as seen in hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy and kernicterus.

questions.text: 99. Mr. Sonu is brought to the hospital because his family members feel that his movements and activities have become very slow. On examination, the patient has tremors, slurred speech, rigidity, and impaired cerebellar function. He also has orthostatic hypotension. The MRI of his brain is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the MRI showing hot cross bun sign suggest that the most likely diagnosis is multiple system atrophy. 

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a type of atypical Parkinson's disease. Along with the features of Parkinson's disease, they also have cerebellar and autonomic features. The common autonomic feature seen in these patients is orthostatic hypotension. MSA is characterized by the presence of degeneration in the striatum, cerebellum, and inferior olivary nuclei coupled with characteristic glial cytoplasmic inclusions. These inclusions stain positively for α-synuclein.

Other options:

Option A- Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) formerly known as Hallervorden-Spatz disease is caused by a mutation in the PANK2 gene. It usually occurs in childhood and has features of dystonia, parkinsonism, and spasticity. MRI shows the low signal abnormality in the center of the globus pallidus due to iron accumulation. This is known as the eye of the tiger sign.

The below image shows the Eye of the tiger sign seen in PKAN:



Option B- Parkinson's disease (PD) usually presents with bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremors. MRI is not useful in the diagnosis of the disease. Imaging of the brain dopamine system in patients with PD can be performed using positron emission tomography (PET) or single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT). They show reduced and asymmetric uptake of striatal dopaminergic biomarkers, particularly in the posterior putamen.

Option D- Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a form of atypical parkinsonism that is characterized by slow ocular saccades, eyelid apraxia, and restricted vertical eye movements with downward gaze palsy. Patients also have hyperextension of the neck with gait disturbances and frequent falls. MRI may reveal characteristic atrophy of the midbrain with normal pons. This is called a hummingbird sign. There is degeneration of the striatum, subthalamic nucleus, midline thalamic nuclei, and pallidum, coupled with neurofibrillary tangles and inclusions that stain for tau protein.

The below image shows the hummingbird sign seen in PSP:

questions.text:
100. A 25-year-old male patient presented with episodic wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. He was diagnosed with mild asthma with intermittent symptoms. According to GINA 2022 guidelines, what is the initial recommendation for treating this patient?

GINA - Global Initiative for Asthma
questions.solution:
According to GINA 2022 guidelines, beclomethasone with formoterol is preferred for mild asthma with intermittent symptoms.

Asthma is a respiratory condition characterized by reversible airflow obstruction. GINA recommends the treatment of asthma with low-dose inhaled corticosteroids with formoterol. Short-acting beta-agonists are associated with increased exacerbations.  

Low-dose inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) are found to have reduced hospitalizations, death, and exercise-induced bronchoconstriction and can improve lung function. 

Thus, adults or adolescents with asthma should be started on low-dose ICS with formoterol as needed. If there are multiple episodes during the week or the patient is waking up with asthma more than once a week, then maintenance therapy with the same can be started. 

Other options: 

Option B - Albuterol is a bronchodilator that is a short-acting beta 2 agonist (SABA). It is no longer recommended for treatment for asthma as regular use increases allergic responses, airway inflammation, and reduces the bronchodilator response during exacerbations. 

Option C - Beclomethasone alone is generally not prescribed as it is a combination of low-dose ICS with formoterol. 

Option D - Beclomethasone (ICS) and albuterol (SABA) can be given as an alternative in the form of regular low-dose ICS with as-needed SABA when the preferred treatment is not possible. However, the current guidelines prefer formoterol.

questions.text:
101. Given below is a list of equipment used for the cold storage of vaccines. Arrange the cold storage equipment in the correct order of usage, starting from the primary health center level to the national level.

* Walk-in-Freezers

* Walk-in-coolers

* Deep freezer

* Ice lined refrigerators
questions.solution:
The cold chain equipments that are used at various healthcare strata starting from the primary health center to the national level are 4-3-2-1 i.e. ice lined refrigerators → deep freezer → walk-in-coolers → walk-in-freezers.

Ice-lined refrigerators (ILRs) are similar to conventional refrigerators and are lined with ice packs or tubes. They are categorized based on the vaccine storage capacity. Smaller ones are supplied to the primary health center (PHC) headquarters, while larger ones are supplied to district headquarters. They maintain a temperature of 2-8° Celsius for the storage of vaccines. They have different temperature zones for different vaccines and they are stored accordingly in the baskets that are provided in most ILRs.

Deep freezer (DF) is also similar to a conventional refrigerator but has a top-opening lid. It maintains a temperature of -15° to -25° celsius. It is used at the district level and above for the storage of oral polio vaccines for 3 months. At the sub-district level, it is used for freezing icepacks.

Walk-in-coolers (WIC) are insulated cold rooms with two cooling units with an uninterrupted power supply. They maintain a temperature of 2-8° celsius. They are used at government medical store depots, state, regional, and occasionally district level vaccine stores. 

Walk-in-freezers (WIF) are similar to WIC but maintain a temperature of -15° to -25° celsius. They are used at national, state, and regional vaccine stores.

Pearl PM0697: Open Vial Policy

Open vial policy allows for reuse of partially used multidose vials of applicable vaccines under the Universal Immunization Programme in subsequent sessions up to 4 weeks subject to certain conditions and thereby reducing vaccine wastage.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

Pearl PM0698: Vaccine Vial Monitors

* Vaccine vial monitors are used to monitor heat exposure of vaccines.

* It is a chemical indicator that records the cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in color.

* If the color of the inner square is the same color or darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and it must be discarded.



* Currently, there are four types of VVMs (VVM2, VVM7, VVM14, and VVM30). They are chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine.

* The VVM can be located on the label of the vaccine or on the neck or cap of the ampule/vial.

* VVMs also help in reduction of vaccine wastage by indicating which batch of vaccines can be used first.

questions.text: 102. Which of the following is not part of sentinel surveillance?

choices.text: Indicates trends in the entire target population
Identifying cases that are free of disability

questions.solution:
Sentinel surveillance helps in identifying the missing cases among the old and new cases.

Sentinel surveillance is a method to identify the missing cases and hence supplement the notified cases.

The sentinel data collected in this type of surveillance can estimate the disease prevalence (old and new cases) in the total population. This system provides more valuable and detailed information compared to what is obtained from traditional notification systems.

In sentinel surveillance, a prearranged set of reporting sources agrees to report all the cases of a defined condition. This will indicate the trend of the disease in the entire target population.

Pearl PM0253: Sentinel Surveillance

* Sentinel surveillance is used to augment the notification systems used in surveillance of diseases.

* It detects the total case load and is used to identify the missing cases that are not notified among the old and new cases.

* Sentinel data from the same is extrapolated to the entire population and the prevalence can be commented on.

* Advantages: Bias in reporting is minimized and the feedback is simplified.

questions.text: 103. A 35-year-old woman presented with tingling and numbness of the upper and lower limb extremities. She also complains of blurring of vision with painful eye movements. Her brain MRI finding is given below. What is the best test to evaluate her eye pathology?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the symptoms of tingling and numbness of both limbs along with the brain MRI showing ovoid lesions with their long axis perpendicular to the ventricular surface called Dawson's fingers are characteristically seen in multiple sclerosis (MS). Optic neuritis is a common feature of MS, and is best evaluated by doing an MRI of the orbit.

Although the mainstay of imaging the orbit is CT, MRI is used as the first line in the evaluation of the optic nerve itself, for example in the setting of optic neuropathy/neuritis. It can be particularly useful in the characterisation of orbital masses and for delineating the spread of infection.

Multiple sclerosis(MS) is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system commonly associated with paresthesia (tingling sensations),  hypesthesia (numbness), optic neuritis, unilateral/ bilateral, limb weakness - spastic paralysis, Babinski's sign positive and bladder dysfunction. 

Optic neuritis (ON) presents as diminished visual acuity or decreased colour perception (desaturation) in the central field of vision. These symptoms can be mild or may progress to severe visual loss. Rarely, there is a complete loss of light perception. Periorbital pain (aggravated by eye movement) often precedes or accompanies the visual loss.

Pearl PM0645: Investigation of choice in Neurology

Generally, MRI is considered the best imaging for the spinal cord and nerves.

Conditions in which MRI is used include:

* Optic neuritis

* Vestibular schwannoma

* Multiple sclerosis

* Pituitary adenoma

* Spinal cord tumor

* Neurofibroma

* Viral encephalitis

* Hippocampal volumetry.

CT scan is preferred when the timing is critical. So, the investigation of choice for stroke is an NCCT. This helps to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

The investigation of choice for ischemic stroke is a diffusion-weighted MRI.

questions.text: 104. Hyperinflation of the lungs resulting in apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension is due to which of the following physiological reflexes?
questions.solution:
Apnea followed by rapid breathing after the hyperinflation of the lungs is due to the J receptor Reflex.

C fiber endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension. This is called the J reflex or pulmonary chemoreflex. A similar response is produced by receptors in the heart (Bezold-Jarisch reflex or the coronary chemoreflex).

Other options:

Option A: Tachycardia following acute volume overload is due to the Bainbridge Reflex. The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction.

Option B: Hypertension following a head injury is due to the Cushing Reflex. When the intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to RVLM neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration. The resultant rise in systemic arterial pressure tends to restore the blood flow to the medulla.

Option C: The activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (e.g. juxta capillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) that causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing is the Bezold Jarisch reflex.

It can be elicited by substances like capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, veratridine, myocardial ischemia and reperfusion due to increased production of oxygen radicals, radiocontrast agents used for coronary angiography.

questions.text:
105. As the junior resident posted in the casualty, you are creating hospital records for patients presenting with various wounds. Which of the following should you classify as having a grievous injury?

* A 22-year-old man with scrotal trauma resulting in emasculation

* A 33-year-old lady who has lost hearing in one ear due to a ruptured tympanic membrane which is now showing signs of healing

* A 16-year-old girl who has impaired vision in her left eye due to vitreal hemorrhage, but no other facial injuries

* A 39-year-old man with the loss of his premolar tooth due to trauma, and a small abrasion on the face

* A 12-year-old with a lacerated wound over the cheek, which would heal with a scar even if expertly sutured
questions.solution:
The following would be considered as grievous hurt:

* A 22-year-old man with scrotal trauma resulting in emasculation

* A 39-year-old man with the loss of his premolar tooth due to trauma, and a small abrasion on the face

* A 12-year-old with a lacerated wound over the cheek, which would heal with a scar even if expertly sutured

The 33-year-old lady who has lost hearing in one ear due to a ruptured tympanic membrane which is now showing signs of healing and the 16-year-old girl who has impaired vision in her left eye due to vitreal hemorrhage, but no other facial injuries have only suffered temporary privation/partial loss of function - hence would not be considered as grievous.

Grievous hurt is inflicted voluntarily on another person and comprises any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

* Clause 1 — Emasculation.

* Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye. 

* Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.

* Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint.

* Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.

* Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face.

* Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.

* Clause 8 — Any hurt which endangers life or which causes the sufferer to be, during the period of 15 days, in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits.

Grievous hurt is a cognizable offence for which a police officer can arrest a person without a warrant from a magistrate (Section 116, BNS).

Punishment for grievous hurt :

* Section 117, BNS Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt –imprisonment up to seven years and fine.

* Section 118, BNS Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by dangerous weapons or means—life imprisonment or imprisonment up to ten years and fine.

questions.text: 106. Contraceptive failure occurs in a 32-year-old woman who is taking an oral contraceptive pill (OCP) and tetracycline simultaneously. What is the mechanism causing OCP failure in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Broad-spectrum antibiotics like tetracyclines suppress the intestinal flora and interfere with the enterohepatic circulation of estrogen, leading to a lowering of plasma estrogen levels and resulting in contraceptive failure.

Enzyme inhibitors like verapamil, fluconazole, erythromycins inhibit the degradation of OCPs. OCPs thus have a longer duration of action and less incidence of contraceptive failure with these.

Most antiepileptic drugs are enzyme inducers, causing increased degradation of OCPs and hence leading to contraceptive failure. Eg: carbamazepine, phenytoin, efavirenz, primidone, nevirapine, rifampicin.

questions.text: 107. A drug that induces apoptosis in a kidney cell is being studied. Shown below is the mechanism of cell death in this case. Which of the following proteins does not belong to the group marked as "X" in the image given?
questions.solution:
In the given image, "X" represents anti-apoptotic factors. BAK is a pro-apoptotic factor and does not belong to this group.

In order for apoptosis to occur permeabilization of the mitochondrial membrane is necessary. This is facilitated by pro-apoptotic proteins, BAX, and BAK (represented by the group "Y" in the image). This action is inhibited by anti-apoptotic proteins (represented by the group "X" in the image). 

Apoptosis is a pathway of cell death that is induced by a closely regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes (caspases) that degrade the cell nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins. 

Mechanism of apoptosis: There are two distinct pathways that can lead to caspase activation and cause apoptosis of the cell.

* The mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway

* The death receptor or extrinsic pathway

The mitochondrial (intrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

* There are several proteins in the mitochondria that can induce apoptosis. These include cytochrome c and some proteins that neutralize the endogenous inhibitors of apoptosis.

* The permeability of the mitochondria is controlled by the BCL-2 family of proteins, which act as sensors.

* These sensors are activated when the cells are deprived of growth factors and other survival signals are exposed to agents that damage the DNA or accumulate a large number of misfolded proteins.

* These activated sensors, in turn, activate the proapoptotic molecules, like BAX and BAK, which form channels in the mitochondrial membrane, through which cytochrome c and other mitochondrial proteins escape into the cytosol and cause activation of caspase-9, which in turn leads to the activation of the caspase cascade and, eventually, apoptosis of the cell.

* On the other hand, if all the growth factors and other survival signals are present, then they produce more antiapoptotic members of the BH1-4 family like the BCL2, MCL 1, and BCL-XL. These proteins limit the escape of proapoptotic mitochondrial proteins.

The death-receptor (extrinsic) pathway of apoptosis:

* Death receptors are surface molecules that are members of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF) receptor family like the TNF 1 and Fas (CD 95).

* These receptors are expressed on the surface of many cells and can trigger apoptosis. In the cytoplasmic region, these receptors have a death domain.

* Fas ligand (FasL) is a membrane protein expressed mainly on activated T-lymphocytes. Fas-FasL interactions are required for thymic medullary negative selection. Defective interactions also cause autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome. 

* When these T-cells recognize Fas-expressing targets, Fas molecules are cross-linked by FasL, their cytoplasmic death domains form a binding site for an adaptor protein called Fas-associated death domain (FADD).

* These, in turn, recruit and activate caspase-8 and -10.

* In many cell types, caspase-8 and -10 may cleave and activate a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family called Bid, thus feeding into the mitochondrial pathway.

* The combined activation of both pathways delivers a lethal blow to the cell.

* Cellular proteins, notably, a caspase antagonist called FLIP, block the activation of caspases downstream of the death receptors. Interestingly, some viruses produce homologs of FLIP, and it is suggested that this is a mechanism that viruses use to keep infected cells alive.

* The death receptor pathway is involved in the elimination of self-reactive lymphocytes and in the killing of target cells by some cytotoxic T-lymphocytes.

questions.text: 108. A primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by vaginal delivery. She is a known case of bronchial asthma. After the delivery of the placenta, she started to bleed profusely. On examination, the uterus is atonic. Which among the following should not be used to control bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in a primigravida with bronchial asthma. Carboprost is a prostaglandin F2 alpha, which is contraindicated in bronchial asthma patients.

Contraindications of carboprost:

Absolute  Relative
  • Asthma
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Suspected amniotic fluid embolism
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Renal disease
  • Liver disease
  • Heart disease


Other options :

Option B: Oxytocin is the first-line drug to prevent and treat PPH according to WHO guidelines. Carbetocin, which is a long-acting analog of oxytocin, can also be used.

Option C: Misoprostol (PGE1 analog) is useful, especially in resource-poor settings. As per WHO, 400 to 600 μg is given orally as a single dose. It is contraindicated in the case of previous cesarean section.

Option D: Methyl ergometrine is contraindicated in hypertensive patients. It is given as an intramuscular injection or slow intravenous to avoid sudden hypertension.

questions.text: 109. Which of the following is false regarding the marked incision shown below?

choices.text: The rectus abdominis muscles are transected
Follows Langer lines of skin tension
Lower incidence of incisional hernias as compared to vertical incisions
Location is 3 cm above the pubic symphysis

questions.solution:
The incision marked is the Pfannenstiel incision where the rectus muscles are not transected. The rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Pfannenstiel incision is the most common incision made in cesarean delivery.It follows Langer lines of skin tension. A transverse and slightly curvilinear incision is made in the skin and subcutaneous tissue 3 cm above the superior border of the pubic symphysis. This is stretched laterally for 12-15 cm to accommodate the delivery of the fetus. Following this, the rectus sheath is incised transversely and rectus muscles are separated in the middle to gain entry to the peritoneum.

Compared to vertical incisions, the Pfannenstiel incision offers superior cosmesis and lower incisional hernia rates.

The Maylard incision (the unmarked incision in the image) differs mainly from the Pfannenstiel in that the bellies of the rectus abdominis muscles are transected horizontally to widen the operating space.



Pearl PM1833: Transvere and vertical incisions in Cesarean section

Transverse incisions:

Advantages-

* Follows Langer lines of skin tension, so superior cosmetic results

* Less postoperative pain

* Less fascial wound dehiscence

* Low incidence of incisional hernias

Disadvantages-

* High infection risks

* Narrow operating space

* Injury to neurovascular bundles

* Reentry during repeat C-section is difficult due to scarring

Vertical incisions:

Advantages-

* Quick entry

* Minimal blood loss

* Superior access to the upper abdomen

* Wide operating space

* Flexibility for easy wound extension if necessary

Disadvantages-

* Poor cosmetic results

* Higher fascial dehiscence 

* Higher incisional hernia rates

* Greater postoperative pain

questions.text: 110. A 14-month-old baby was brought with complaints of continuous watering from the eyes, present since birth. Antibiotic eye drops and frequent massaging to express the contents of the nasolacrimal duct did not show much improvement. Which of the following would be the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic dacryocystitis and the next best step in the management of this patient is the probing of the nasolacrimal duct under anesthesia.

Dacryocystitis is the inflammation of the lacrimal sac. It generally affects infants and adults, most commonly females over 40 years of age. Congenital dacryocystitis is almost always chronic, while acquired dacryocystitis may be acute or chronic.

Congenital dacryocystitis is due to incomplete canalization of the lacrimal system, most often at the valve of Hasner. In newborns, antibiotic drops and frequent massaging to express the contents of the nasolacrimal duct and sac clear out most infections. However, if the symptoms persist beyond a year without improvement, probing of the nasolacrimal duct under anesthesia is advised. Balloon dilatation of the duct or placement of a silicone tube can be done after localizing the level of obstruction.

Other options:

Option B: Antibiotic drops with repeated syringing is the first line of treatment in adults with chronic dacryocystitis.

Option C: In adults, if dacryocystitis persists after repeated syringing, anatomical assessment with digital subtraction macrodacryocystography localises the level of obstruction.

Option D: Dacryocystorhinostomy is the surgical management of chronic dacryocystitis and is advised in adults with blockage at the level of joining of the nasolacrimal duct and sac.

questions.text:
112. An 8-year-old boy presented with weakness, fatigue, excessive thirst, and urination. His blood pressure was 100/76 mmHg. His lab parameters are given below. What is the diagnosis?

Urine transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) - 8 (increased)

Urine calcium- increased

ABG analysis - metabolic alkalosis

Serum potassium - decreased (3.2 mmol/L)

Serum magnesium - decreased (0.3 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis of Bartter syndrome.

Bartter syndrome is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia (normal - 0.5-1 mmol/kg) and hypercalciuria with normal blood pressure. The transtubular potassium gradient (TTKG) is a physiologically based clinical test to study the renal excretion of potassium. A TTKG >4 in a patient with hypokalemia suggests excessive urinary losses of K+. 

Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle (TALH). Each genetic defect is a subtype of Bartter syndrome. Type 3 Bartter, also known as classical Bartter is due to loss of function in CLCKNB (Chloride Voltage-Gated Channel Kb).

A defect in the Na+/K+/Cl- channel impairs the transport functions of the TALH resulting in the following features:

* Polyuria and polydipsia

* Marked activation of RAAS leading to increased renal loss of potassium

* Hypokalemia

* Metabolic alkalosis due to bicarbonate retention

* Hypomagnesemia in 20% of patients

* Hypocalcemia and hypercalciuria

* Normotensive

Antenal presentation of Bartter syndrome is characterized by polyhydramnios, premature birth, polyuria, and salt loss. Antenatal diagnosis can be made by elevated levels of chloride and aldosterone in the amniotic fluid. Antenatal Bartter can be managed by intravenous saline infusion to prevent dehydration and even death. Cyclooxygenase inhibitors are also useful in antenatal Bartter to reduce polyuria and salt wasting.

Other options:

Option A- Gitelman syndrome is due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the Distal convoluted tubule. It is characterized by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with normal blood pressure.

Option B: EAST syndrome is characterized by epilepsy, ataxia, sensorineural deafness, and tubulopathy. Biochemical abnormality is similar to Gitelman syndrome.

Option D: Liddle syndrome is due to direct increased activation of the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) on the principal cells. Liddle's also causes hypokalemia, hypercalciuria but is characterized by severe hypertension.

Pearl PM2381: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.text: 114. A 7-year-old child was scheduled for strabismus correction surgery. The induction of anesthesia was uneventful. After conjunctival incision as the surgeon grasps the medial rectus the anesthetist looks at the cardiac monitor. Why do you think he did that?

choices.text: To check the depth of anesthesia
To see if there was an oculocardiac reflex
To ensure there were no ventricular arrhythmias

questions.solution:
The anaesthetist would have looked at the monitor as soon as the medial rectus was grasped, to see if there was an oculocardiac reflex.

The oculocardiac reflex is a trigemino-vagal-reflex (afferent through trigeminal nerve, efferent through vagus nerve). It is most common in pediatric patients undergoing strabismus surgery. It is caused by traction on extraocular muscles or pressure on the eyeball and surrounding structures, particularly the medial rectus muscle.

Mechanism of reflex: Stretch receptors are located in the extraocular muscles. Once activated, the receptors send afferents through short and long ciliary nerves. The ciliary nerves will merge with the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve at the ciliary ganglion. The trigeminal nerve carries impulses to the Gasserian ganglion resulting in increased parasympathetic tone and bradycardia.

The manifestation can range from bradycardia (most common) to sinus arrest and ventricular ectopic to ventricular fibrillation. Administration of antimuscarinic drug glycopyrrolate or atropine reduces the incidence of bradycardia during eye surgery.

Treatment is done by temporary cessation of any surgical manipulation, prevention of hypercapnia or hypoxemia with adequate ventilation, IV glycopyrrolate or IV atropine if bradycardia persists.

Pearl PM0406: Oculocardiac Reflex

Traction on the extraocular muscles or pressure on the globe causes bradycardia, atrioventricular block, ventricular ectopy, or asystole.

In particular, it is seen with traction on the medial rectus muscle, but it can occur with stimulation of any of the orbital contents, including the periosteum.

Reflex arc involves-

* Afferent: Orbital contents to ciliary ganglion to ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve to the sensory nucleus of trigeminal

* Efferent: Vagus nerve to the heart.

Procedures evoking the reflex-

* Strabismus surgery in the paediatric age (most common) 

* Cataract extraction

* Enucleation

* Retinal detachment repair.

Management-

* Temporary cessation of surgical stimulation until heart rate increases

* Adequate ventilation, oxygenation, and depth of anaesthesia

* IV atropine (10 mcg/kg) if bradycardia persists

* In recalcitrant episodes, local anaesthetic infiltration of the rectus muscles.

Pretreatment with intravenous atropine or glycopyrrolate can be effective in preventing this condition.

questions.text: 115. What is the name of the marked structure that serves as a barrier to the progression of prostate cancer into the rectum?
questions.solution:
The marked structure 'A' is the Denonvilliers’ fascia, which serves as a barrier preventing posteriorly spreading prostate adenocarcinoma into the rectum. 

The lower third of the rectum is separated by the following:

* from the prostate or vagina anteriorly - by Denonvilliers’ fascia

* from the coccyx and lower two sacral vertebrae- by Waldeyer’s fascia

Waldeyer's fascia originates at the S2 to S4 level from the presacral parietal fascia and fuses with the rectal visceral fascia at the posterior aspect of the rectum. It divides the retro-rectal space into superior and inferior compartments. Identification and preservation of the presacral fascia play an important role in preventing complications and reducing local recurrences of rectal cancer.

The fascial layers play a crucial role in surgery as they serve as obstructions to the spread of cancerous cells and create the architectural framework for total mesorectal excision (TME).

Total mesorectal excision (TME) is a standard procedure done for rectal cancer. It includes resection of the tumor along with the surrounding fatty tissues, blood vessels, and lymphatics present in the mesorectum. 

The image below shows an image depicting the fascias and their relations with other structures.



Other options :

Option A: Mesorectum is a fat-filled space surrounding the rectum, which contains lymph nodes and blood vessels. It is excised in total mesorectal excision and contains the superior rectal vein. 

Option C: Rectal proper fascia is the fascia that covers the mesorectum and is also known as the visceral endopelvic fascia.

questions.text: 116. A 45-year-old male patient came with complaints of purplish itchy lesions on his skin as shown below. On examination, thin white lines were present on the surface of the lesions. He was diagnosed with hepatitis C infection 3 years back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a purplish papular itchy lesion on the skin with Wickham's striae and a history of hepatitis C, which is suggestive of lichen planus.

Lichen planus (LP) is an idiopathic inflammatory disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes. 

Patients present with pruritic, purple, polygonal, papules. The lesions have thin white lines on their surface known as Wickham’s striae. They are commonly seen on the volar aspect of the wrists, the lumbar region, and around the ankles. There is an increased risk of developing lichen planus in individuals with a history of hepatitis C.

The mucosal involvement is also seen. The commonest mucosal sites are the buccal mucosa and the tongue. Nail involvement can be seen as the thinning of the nail plate leading to an exaggeration of longitudinal lines, and linear depressions.

Microscopy will show acanthosis of the epidermis, irregular thickening of the granular layer, and compact hyperkeratosis.  Degenerating basal epidermal cells are transformed into colloid bodies. The rete ridges may have a sawtooth appearance, and focal separation from the dermis may lead to Max Joseph spaces. In active LP, a band‐like infiltrate of lymphocytes and histiocytes is seen near the dermo-epidermal junction.



Corticosteroids are the mainstay of lichen planus treatment.

Other options:

Option A- Pityriasis rosea is an acute self-limiting disease. A typical bilateral symmetrical skin eruption consists of macules with a collarette scale in the periphery. It is seen in a characteristic "Christmas tree pattern" over the back and if a lesion on the upper chest may have a V-shaped pattern. The most common persisting sign is the oval salmon herald patch.



Option B- Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory condition of the skin. It is seen particularly over the extensor surfaces, scalp, and lumbosacral region as erythematous plaques covered with silvery scales. On removal of these scales pinpoint bleeding is seen. This is called as Auspitz sign.



Option C- Reiter's syndrome is also called reactive arthritis. Conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis after a genitourinary or gastrointestinal tract infection is the classic triad of reactive arthritis. A common dermal manifestation of reactive arthritis is keratoderma blenorrhagicum.



Pearl PM0292: Papulosquamous Disorders

* Lichen planus

* Psoriasis

* Parapsoriasis

* Pityriasis rubra pilaris

* Pityriasis rosea

* Seborrheic dermatitis

* Secondary Syphilis

* Drug Reactions

* Reiter’s disease

* Eczema

* Neoplasms (Mycosis fungoides, Squamous cell carcinoma,  Bowen’s disease)

* Tinea infections

questions.text: 117. Which of the following is not associated with criminal responsibility in mental illness?
questions.solution:
Nysten's rule is not associated with insanity, it describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis.

Tests to determine criminal responsibility in persons with mental illness:

Durhams's rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental disease or mental defect.

Curren’s rule states that an accused person is not criminally responsible if, at the time of committing the act, he did not have the capacity to regulate his conduct to the requirements of the law as a result of mental disease or defect.

The American Law Institute test states that a person is not responsible for criminal conduct, if at the time of such conduct, as a result of mental disease or defect, he lacks adequate capacity either to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to adjust his conduct to the requirements of the law.

Other such tests include:

* Mc Naughten rule, also called the right or wrong test

* The irresistible impulse test, also called as New Hampshire Doctrine

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity/death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours.

Muscles are affected in the given order:

* Involuntary muscles: Heart (left chamber of the heart is affected first)

* Eyelids

* Neck and lower jaw

* Face

* Chest

* Upper extremities

* Abdomen

* Legs

* Fingers and toes

Pearl PM2059: BNS section 22, M'Naghten's rule

M'Naghten's rule, BNS 22 (Previously - Section 84 IPC):  Criminal responsibility of the insane.

Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law.

questions.text:
118. A 19-year-old female patient presented to the emergency with an altered sensorium. A non-contrast CT revealed hydrocephalus, requiring urgent surgical intervention. The patient had nobody accompanying her or any identity proof. Under which of these sections of the BNS (IPC) can the neurosurgeon perform the procedure without obtaining informed consent from the guardian?

IPC- Indian Penal Code
questions.solution:
BNS Sec 30 (92 IPC) deals with an act done in good faith without consent.

The following situations would apply:

* Emergency (Not mandatory to take consent during emergencies)

* The person is incapable of giving consent

* The person has no guardian to give consent

Other options:

Option A- BNS Sec 28 (90 IPC) deals with consent known to be given under fear or misconception and consent of the insane person.

Option C- BNS Sec 33 (95 IPC) deals with the act causing slight harm.

Option D- BNS Sec 26 (88 IPC) deals with acts done by consent in good faith for a person's benefit, not intended to cause death.

25

87

An act done in good faith for the benefit of a child under 12 years of age or an insane person, with the consent of a parent or guardian is not an offense.

  • Given under fear or misconception.

questions.text: 119. A 65-year-old multiparous woman presents to you with complaints of involuntary leakage of urine on coughing, sneezing, and lifting of heavy objects. Which of the following is least likely to be the treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of urinary incontinence on coughing, sneezing, and lifting heavy objects in a multiparous female in a post-menopausal age group is suggestive of genuine stress incontinence (GSI). Bladder training is a treatment option for detrusor instability (not for GSI).

GSI is defined as a small involuntary leakage of urine with increased abdominal pressure in the absence of detrusor contraction. It occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction.

 

Grading of GSI:

* Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging

* Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walking, and going up and down the stairs

* Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Conservative management of GSI:

* Kegel pelvic floor exercises

* Drugs - Alpha-adrenergic drugs, venlafaxine, imipramine, and estrogen cream.

* Ring pessaries/vaginal cones

* Electric stimulation

* Artificial urinary sphincter (AUS) system

Surgical management of GSI:

* Vaginal Operations: 

* Kelly’s repair: Anterior colporrhaphy with plication of the bladder neck

* Pacey’s repair: Apposing medial fibers of puborectalis muscles in the midline under the bladder neck region to elevate it

* Abdominal Operations:

* Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation: Retropubic colposuspension, where bladder neck and the vaginal vault are sutured to the periosteum of the back of the pubic symphysis

* Burch's colposuspension: Vaginal suspension achieved using the iliopectineal ligament

* Laparoscopic colposuspension

* Combined abdominal and vaginal operations: Pereyra operation

* Tension-free vaginal tapes

* Periurethral collagen injection

Detrusor instability: Incontinence happens when the detrusor muscle contracts on provocation or spontaneously during the filling phase when inhibition of micturition is attempted. It is mostly caused by parasympathetic overactivity, seen most commonly in old women with decreased bladder capacity.

questions.text: 120. An 18-year-old football player presented after collapsing suddenly on the field. The evaluation showed ECG and echocardiographic findings suggestive of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in managing HCM with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction(LVOT)?
questions.solution:
Diuretics should be avoided in HCM with LVOT because of their adverse effect on the LV outflow gradient and ventricular volume.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) -

HCM is the leading cause of sudden death in young. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by predominant diastolic dysfunction presenting as exercise intolerance. 

The patients have a dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction due to septal hypertrophy and systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve leaflet (SAM). It causes mitral regurgitation with a jet of blood flow posteriorly. It is characterized by misalignment of the enlarged myofibrils and myocytes

Clinical features - While most patients are asymptomatic some of them may develop the following symptoms - dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, presyncope and syncope, and palpitation.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) is associated with a mid-systolic murmur with the following features:

* Loudest along the left sternal border

* Increases in intensity by maneuvers that result in increasing degrees of outflow tract obstruction:

* Reduction in preload or afterload: Valsalva, standing, vasodilators

* Increased contractility: inotropic stimulation  

* Decreases in intensity when there is

* Increase in preload: squatting, passive leg raising, volume administration

* Increase in afterload: squatting, vasopressors

* Reduced contractility: β-adrenoreceptor blockers

Diagnosis - 

* ECG - findings include -

* Prominent abnormal Q waves

* P wave abnormalities 

* Left axis deviation.

* Deeply inverted T waves 

* Echocardiography -

*  LV wall thickness ≥15 mm

* Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve

* LVOT(left ventricular outflow tract) obstruction

Treatment -

* For patients with LVOT obstruction - beta-blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, and disopyramide may be used. Vasodilators and diuretics must be avoided in patients with LVOT obstruction.

* Patients without LVOT obstruction with LVEF ≥50 percent - Initial monotherapy with either a beta-blocker or a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker is started. Diuretics may be used as needed.

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text:
121. A 12-year-old girl complains of blurred vision despite using eyeglasses with a correction of -7D. On examination, you note that her eyes are prominent and her pupils are large. Which of the following clinical features may be seen in this condition?

D- diopters
questions.solution:
The history of a rapidly progressive refractive error and findings of prominent eyes with large pupils are suggestive of pathological myopia. Optic disc crescent can be seen in this condition.

Pathological myopia is otherwise known as degenerative/progressive myopia and starts during childhood. It results in high myopia, greater than -6D, by the time the children become adults.

Children complain of defective vision and with progressive degeneration, there will be uncorrectable loss of vision. High myopes often have prominent eyeballs with a deep anterior chamber and mildly large pupils which react sluggishly to light.

Fundus examination shows a characteristic myopic crescent at the optic disc. Other features that are seen are Foster-Fuchs' spot (due to sub-retinal neovascularization), lattice degeneration/snail track lesion, posterior staphyloma (ectasia of the sclera at the posterior pole), and posterior vitreous detachment due to vitreous degeneration.

Pathological myopia is optically treated with under-correction to avoid minification of the images. Contact lenses are preferred as they avoid peripheral distortion as well as the minification caused by strong concave spectacles.  

Other options:

Option A & B: Small optic disc and a shallow anterior chamber are seen in patients with hypermetropia.

Option C: Munson's sign is seen in keratoconus. There is a localized bulging of the lower eyelid that can be seen in a downward-looking eye.

Pearl PM0717: Grading of Myopia

American Optometric Association (AOA) Grading of Myopia:

* Low myopia, when the error is < –3D.

* Moderate myopia, when the error is between -3D to -6D.

* High myopia, when the error is > –6D.

Myopia

Etiology

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

questions.text: 122. A 14-year-old girl with a long-standing history of systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis presents with a fever. Examination reveals splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show anemia, thrombocytopenia, elevated ferritin levels, and abnormal liver function tests. Bone marrow biopsy shows the findings as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of hemophagocytic lymphocytosis (HLH). This condition occurs more commonly in patients with rheumatological conditions such as systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA). The image shows shows stromal macrophages engulfing red blood cells suggestive of hemophagocytosis. 

Hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH) is a reactive condition that occurs in association with conditions that are characterized by signs and symptoms of systemic inflammation.

The systemic activation of macrophages and CD8+ cytotoxic T cells is a basic feature found in all kinds of HLH. The marrow's blood cell progenitors and produced components are phagocytosed by activated macrophages. Mediators secreted by lymphocytes and macrophages will inhibit hematopoiesis and also lead to systemic inflammatory symptoms. These consequences result in cytopenias and a shock-like state known as the systemic inflammatory response syndrome (also known as "cytokine storm").

Associated conditions include hematological conditions, infections, rheumatologic/immunologic conditions such as Still's disease, systemic lupus erythematosus, polyarteritis nodosa, mixed connective tissue disorder, sarcoidosis, sJIA, Sjogren's syndrome. 

Clinical features include fever, splenomegaly, hepatitis, and encephalitis features. Other findings include respiratory abnormalities, severe hypotension, skin rashes, erythroderma, bleeding.

Laboratory findings in HLH: Anemia, thrombocytopenia, high serum ferritin, high plasma IL2 receptor levels, elevated liver enzyme levels.

Other options:

Option A: Hemolytic-uremic syndrome may have anemia and thrombocytopenia but renal function tests are not usually normal. The triad required for diagnosis is microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.

Option B: Kawasaki disease may cause a fever and occurs in children, but this patient does not fulfil the diagnostic criteria for this condition. It requires the presence of fever and four of five clinical findings - conjunctivitis, mucosal changes, rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy. 

Option D: Drug rash with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) usually has a temporal relationship with new drugs which is not the case in this patient. Furthermore, it usually presents with an extensive skin rash in association with visceral organ involvement, lymphadenopathy, eosinophilia, and atypical lymphocytosis. Although fever and abnormal liver function test results are seen in this patient, the diagnosis should be suspected when these findings are associated with a typical cutaneous eruption two to eight weeks after starting a new drug. In the pediatric population, antiepileptics and antibiotics account for the majority of cases of DRESS.

questions.text: 123. A 3-year-old child is brought to the ophthalmology department with the following complaint. Which of the following forms the first line of management for the patient?
questions.solution:
The given image shows esotropia (convergent squint),  commonly seen in children with hyperopia (also known as hypermetropia). The first line of management in the treatment of esotropia includes refractive error correction with glasses. 

In a child with associated accommodation issues and non-compliance to glasses, miotics are generally used. Di-isopropyl fluorophosphate (DFP) or echothiophate (Option-A) is commonly used for this condition. Long-term usage causes secondary iris cysts. Prevention of these secondary iris cysts can be achieved by the concomitant use of phenylephrine. So, in such cases, both echothiophate + phenylephrine eye drops are prescribed (Option-B)

Further treatment may include orthoptic training (Option-D) or surgical correction of the squint.

Accommodative esotropia is a common type of squint due to the overaction of convergence associated with accommodation. This overaction is usually to overcome a hyperopic refractive error. It presents at around 2 to 3 years of age.

Types of accommodative esotropia include:

* Refractive

* Associated with high hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D)

* Fully correctable by spectacles

* Non-refractive type 

* Occurs independent of refractive errors

* A small increase in accommodation is accompanied by a dis­proportionately large increase in convergence

* Abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio

* Fully corrected by bifocal glasses

Image: Accommodative esotropia with and without correction





Mnemonic

The algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows:

* R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics

* O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia

* O: Operative correction: for non-accommodative component

* P: Prism correction: for remaining error

The given image shows an iris pigment epithelial (IPE) cyst near the pupillary margin seen clinically secondary to echothiophate use.

questions.text: 124. As a part of project work in radiology postings, you were asked to measure the biological risk of an individual i.e, the risk that a person will suffer health effects from exposure to radiation. Which of the following SI unit will be used for this purpose?
questions.solution:
The biological risk of an individual is measured by using the SI unit Sievert (Sv).

Different units of measure are used depending on what aspect of radiation is being measured

* SI unit becquerel (Bq) or conventional unit curie is used for measuring the amount of radiation being emitted by a radioactive material.

* SI unit gray (Gy) or conventional unit rad is used for measuring radiation dose absorbed by a person (that is, the amount of energy deposited in human tissue by radiation)

* SI unit sievert (Sv) or conventional unit rem is used for measuring the biological risk of exposure to radiation (One Sv is equal to 100 rem).
