questions.text: 125. Triangle of Koch does not include
questions.solution:
Crista terminalis is not a part of triangle of Koch.

It is a C shaped smooth muscular ridge that begins from the upper part of septal surface to the right side of Inferior vena caval orifice.

Triangle of Koch is formed by

* Coronary sinus orifice

* Tendon of Todaro

* Tricuspid valve septal leaflet

It is used as an anatomical landmark to locate the atrioventricular (AV) node.

questions.text: 126. Which of the following findings is not suggestive of antemortem hanging?

choices.text: Multiple bruises on neck with absence of vital reaction
Dilation of one eye and other eye being closed
Area of hypostasis limited to legs and hands with a pale face

questions.solution:
In the case of antemortem hanging, injuries are associated with the presence of a vital reaction. 

Eyes may show the following findings in antemortem hanging:

* La facies sympathique- in case of hanging, one of the eyes may be opened with dilated pupil, while the other eye may be closed. This occurs due to the pressure of the ligature knot on the cervical sympathetic ganglia in the neck. Thus, on the side on which the ligature knot presses the cervical sympathetic ganglia, the eye remains open with dilatation of its pupil. It is a sign of antemortem hanging.

* Subconjunctival hemorrhages

* Prominent eyeballs



Other findings seen in antemortem hanging:

* Post-mortem hypostasis- present in the legs and hands

* Petechial hemorrhages- these are usually the exception, rather than the rule

* In most cases the face is pale, in some cases it may be congestion due to venous occlusion

* Ligature mark- above the thyroid cartilage and incomplete

* Soft tissue hemorrhage may be seen.

* Laryngeal fractures- fractures of the hyoid and thyroid may be seen

* Amussat sign- damage to intima and media of the carotid artery

* Simon's sign- hemorrhages on the anterior aspects of intervertebral discs

* Dribbling of saliva- It is often found dribbling from the angle of the mouth, opposite to the side of the knot. This may be due to stimulation of salivary glands or congestive hypoxia. Salivation may not occur when the death is due to vagal inhibition or injury to the spinal cord. Evidence of dried marks of dribbling saliva is suggestive of antemortem hanging but its absence alone will not suggest that the body was suspended after the death.

questions.text: 127. A 40-year-old man presents with abdominal pain, nausea, and dizziness for the past few weeks. His investigations reveal hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. He also complains of skin changes as seen in the image below. He was previously diagnosed with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Which of the following is not a feature of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical presentation, along with the history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis and the image showing skin hyperpigmentation, is highly suggestive of Addison’s disease. Hyperglycemia is not a feature of this condition.

Addison's disease occurs due to primary adrenal insufficiency. The secretion of both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids is impaired, resulting in various clinical manifestations.

The clinical features of Addison’s disease include:

* Features of hypoaldosteronism- 

* Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, salt craving

* Dizziness, postural hypotension

* Acute kidney injury due to volume depletion

* Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis

* Features of decreased cortisol-

* Anorexia, weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, arthralgia, fever (increased IL-1)

* Postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia (loss of feedback inhibition of ADH)

* Slightly increased TSH (loss of feedback inhibition)

* Decreased androgens-

* Loss of libido, loss of pubic and axillary hair

* Features of elevated ACTH- hyperpigmentation

questions.text: 128. A 47-year-old female patient comes to the clinic for evaluation of constant dribbling of urine. Upon performing the following test, the swab labeled "B" is stained blue. Which of the following statements are true?

choices.text: Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation is done for this condition
The test is called the Q-tip test
Keigel's exercises is the first-line management for this condition
Latzko procedure can be done to treat this condition

questions.solution:
The given clinical complex describes a case of vesicovaginal fistula which is diagnosed using a methylene blue3 swab test in which the middle swabs stains with methylene blue. Latzko's procedure is done for this condition.

The preferred technique of repair of the vesicovaginal fistula which occurred post-hysterectomy is Latzko's procedure.

Latzko's procedure: It is done by denudation of vaginal epithelium around fistulous edges, freshening the edges, and approximation of raw surface with absorbable sutures. This technique is suited for post-hysterectomy fistula that is caused by cancer cervix. It can lead to narrowing of the vagina or vaginal atresia.

Fistula located at the vaginal vault post hysterectomy is the most difficult to treat, this technique is suited for such cases.

In case of an established fistula, it is better to wait for about 3 months for all tissue inflammation to subside, before surgery is undertaken.

Most vesicovaginal fistulae are repaired per vaginally.

The various surgeries done for the repair of VVF (vesicovaginal fistula) are as follows:

* Latzko procedure

* Chasser Moir technique

* Ureteric implantation

 The image below shows the swab test for VVF



Other options:

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz operation (Option 1) is a surgical management option for genuine stress incontinence.

Q tip test (Option 2) is done for stress incontinence. A Q-tip cotton swab stick dipped in Xylocaine jelly is placed in the urethra. The patient is asked to strain or cough. Initially, the stick will be parallel to the floor and reach an angle of around 10-15. This angle increases by 20 or more in cases suffering from GSI. A positive test indicates a sufficient degree of bladder neck descent. Unfortunately, all patients with GSI may not have a positive test. This test is not very specific.

Keigel's exercises (Option 3) are the conservative management modality for young women with urge incontinence.

questions.text: 130. An 18-year-old girl presents with an abdominal mass. After laparotomy, the mass demonstrates a cystic cavity filled with hair, sebaceous material, cartilage, bone, along with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage. On microscopic examination, varying amounts of the immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, muscle, and other elements are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is consistent with immature teratoma.

Immature malignant teratomas:

* The tumor is found chiefly in prepubertal adolescents and young women, the mean age being 18 years.

* The component tissues resemble embryonal and immature fetal tissue most, often consisting of primitive neuroepithelium on histological examination. On microscopic examination, there are varying amounts of the immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, muscle, and other elements.

* The histologic grade of the tumor, based on the proportion of tissue containing immature neuroepithelium indicates risk for extra-ovarian spread.

* High-grade tumours confined to the ovaries are treated with prophylactic chemotherapy.

Mature (Benign) teratoma(Option B):

* Cystic teratomas are usually found in young women during the active reproductive years. 

* They are bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases.

* They are unilocular cysts containing hair and sebaceous material sometimes cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue.

* Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of stratified squamous epithelium, with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skin adnexal structures.

* About 1% of the dermoids undergo malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma, but also to other cancers as well (e.g., thyroid carcinoma, melanoma).

Monodermal or specialized teratomas:

* Struma ovarii (Option C) is composed entirely of mature thyroid tissue, which may be functional and cause hyperthyroidism.

* Ovarian carcinoid (Option D), which presumably arises from intestinal tissue, may be functional and causes carcinoid syndrome in the absence of hepatic metastasis.

questions.text: 131. The given life cycle belongs to _____.
questions.solution:
The given life cycle belongs to Schistosoma haematobium.

S. haematobium or vesical blood fluke is a trematode that lives in the pelvic and vesical venous plexuses. Its lifecycle involves man as a definitive host and freshwater snails as the intermediate host. Infective forms of schistosomes are fork-tailed cercaria larva. The eggs are non-operculated with a characteristic spine at one end.

The eggs are passed in the urine of the infected person, which will hatch in the water to release free-living ciliated miracidia. Miracidia then penetrate a suitable intermediate host and reaches its liver. In the liver, they produce first and second-generation sporocysts. The second generation sporocyst undergoes asexual reproduction producing cercaria larva. These are then released into the water. Persons become infected by contact with water containing cercariae during bathing. After entering the human body, they migrate through the heart and pulmonary circulation to reach the liver, where they attain sexual differentiation. From the liver, they reach the pelvic and vesical venous plexus, where they mature, mate, and lay eggs.

Clinical features include acute schistosomiasis in the form of skin rash at the site of penetration (swimmer's itch) or anaphylactic symptoms due to the release of toxic metabolites. Chronic schistosomiasis presents with chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the bladder leading to obstructive uropathies. There is an increased risk for bladder carcinoma and calculus formation.

Diagnosis : 

* Detection of eggs in urine microscopy and bladder mucosal biopsy.

* ELISA for antigen detection 

* Detection of S. haematobium adult worm microsomal antigen (HAMA) by 

* Falcon assay screening test (HAMAFAST) or ELISA

* HAMA enzyme-linked immunoelectrotransfer blot (HAMA-EITB).

* Intradermal skin testing (Fairley's test)

Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis.

The following are the unique features distinguishing schistosomes from other trematodes:

* Only one intermediate host.

* They are unisexual/dioecious.

* They produce non-operculated eggs.

* Mode of infection is by penetration of intact skin with the help of forked tails of cercariae

Forms of most trematodes that are infective to humans are metacercaria larvae.

questions.text:
132. Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in which of the following conditions?

* Hodgkin's lymphoma

* Advanced melanoma

* Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)

* Medulloblastoma

* Renal cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in Hodgkin's lymphoma, advanced melanoma, advanced NSCLC that is previously treated, renal cell carcinoma, and advanced head and neck cancers.

Nivolumab is a checkpoint inhibitor that blocks the interaction between PD-1 and its ligands. It is a fully human monoclonal IgG4 antibody. It has a good response rate in patients with pretreated solid tumours and haematological malignancies. Similar effectiveness is also seen with pembrolizumab which is also an anti-PD-1 monoclonal antibody.

The adverse effects of nivolumab include rash in patients with melanoma. Fatigue, dyspnea, cough, musculoskeletal pain, decreased appetite, and constipation can be seen in patients with advanced squamous NSCLC. Pneumonitis, colitis, nephritis, hepatitis, and renal dysfunction are also seen.

Important note:

The FDA on May 2021 approved the use of nivolumab in patients having completely resected oesophagal or gastroesophageal junction cancers with residual pathologic disease who have received neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy.

questions.text: 133. A young, female patient who recently underwent abdominal surgery presented to the OPD with the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about her condition?

choices.text: It extends beyond the boundary of the original incision
It is associated with elevated growth factor
It occurs in people with light pigmentation of skin
They most commonly occur in the sternal area

questions.solution:
The given history of abdominal surgery and the image is suggestive of keloid and the incorrect statement about keloid is it occurs in people with light pigmentation of the skin. Keloids have increased incidence in individuals with darker pigmentation.

A keloid is defined as excessive scar tissue that occurs after traumatic mechanisms like cuts, lacerations, or burns. They extend beyond the boundaries of the inciting injury. The keloid is glossy in appearance and rubbery in texture. They are composed of thick bundles of collagen. 

Treatment of keloids usually involves intralesional injections of triamcinolone. Multiple doses are required at intervals over several weeks and may result in flattening but rarely does the wound narrow. 

Other options: 

Option A - Keloids extend beyond the boundary of the original incision due to the chronic inflammation that occurs during the wound-healing phase. 

Option B - Keloids are associated with elevated growth factors. Histologically, keloids appear as nodular myofibroblasts and whorl-like arrangement of thick hyalinized collagen. 

Option D - Keloids most commonly occur in the sternal area in the triangle formed by the tips of the shoulders and the xiphisternum. The other areas involved are the neck, ears, extremities, and trunk.

134. Match the following inborn errors of amino acid metabolism and their characteristic urine odours:

1) Tyrosinemia a) Swimming pool
2) Phenylketonuria b) Tomcat urine

carboxylase deficiency

 c) Mousey

questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-d,2-c,3-b,4-a.

* Tyrosinemia - Boiled cabbage

* Phenylketonuria - Mousey

* Multiple carboxylase deficiency - Tomcat urine

Tyrosinemia- Boiled cabbage odour may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds).

Phenylketonuria-It is due to deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the body fluids and the brain. The excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones,  namely, phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine, giving rise to the term phenylketonuria(PKU). Phenylacetate gives rise to the characteristic mousy odor in the urine in PKU.

Multiple carboxylase deficiencies lead to defects in the utilization of Biotin. Tomcat urine odor is characteristic. Affected infants should be treated with Biotin.

Hawkinsinuria- It is an autosomal-dominant condition caused by mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD. Swimming pool odor of the urine is characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: 135. An infant was brought by his mother for evaluation of a large head. On examination, there was growth retardation and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood investigations revealed pancytopenia. X-ray imaging is shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the x-ray image showing dense bones, is suggestive of osteopetrosis.

Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease/Albers–Schönberg disease is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to mutation of CLCN7 (in osteoclasts).

Clinically, patients present with macrocephaly (due to hydrocephalus), developmental delay, pancytopenia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis)

Blood investigations show low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels.

Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. Diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity.

Treatment: Symptomatic treatment and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done.

Other Options:

Option A: Achondroplasia is characterized by short stature, extreme joint laxity, bowing of legs, macrocephaly, frontal bossing, midfacial hypoplasia, small chest, redundant skin folds, recurrent infections, cor pulmonale, and restrictive pulmonary disease. It is not characterized by hepatosplenomegaly and pancytopenia.

Option B: Scurvy results from a deficiency of vitamin C and is characterized by petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses at pressure points, epistaxis, gum bleeding, phrynoderma, and perifollicular hemorrhages. 

Option C: Osteogenesis imperfecta (or brittle bone disease) is a connective tissue disorder due to a mutation in the COL1A and COL2A genes. Bowing of the long bones, wormian bones, and multiple diaphyseal fractures of long bones at various stages are the common radiological findings that are observed.

questions.text: 136. A patient is undergoing a parotidectomy. Which of the following measures reduces the risk of developing Frey's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Frey's syndrome or gustatory sweating occurs as a result of aberrant innervation of the dermal sweat glands by the regenerating fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve following parotid surgery. This can be prevented intraoperatively by placing a temporalis fascia flap between the skin and the parotid bed.

Patients with Frey's syndrome present with sweating, warmth, and redness of the face as a result of salivary stimulation by the smell or taste of food. The diagnosis can be confirmed with Minor's starch-iodine test. This test involves applying iodine and dry starch over the suspected area, and giving a stimulus that can cause salivation is given to the patient. In the presence of iodine and sweat, the starch over the affected area will turn blue.

Frey's syndrome occurs as a consequence of parotidectomy in most patients but is usually not significant. It can be prevented by the following methods:

* Raising a thick flap (including the subcutaneous tissue) over the parotid

* Interposition of tissues such as sternocleidomastoid flap, temporalis fascia or autologous fat between the skin and the surgical bed

* Extracapsular dissection of parotid gland for benign pathologies

Treatment of established Frey's syndrome involves the use of anti-perspirants, botulinum toxin injection into the affected skin, and neurectomy of the Jacobson's nerve, which forms the tympanic plexus and gives the pre-ganglionic parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion, in the form of lesser petrosal nerve.

questions.text: 137. A 38-year-old female patient comes with complaints of a palpable swelling on her breast. On histopathology examination, dyscohesive infiltrating tumor cells and signet ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets are seen. Immunohistochemistry shows the tumor to be under the luminal group. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of palpable breast mass, with histopathology showing dyscohesive infiltrating tumor cells and signet ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, is suggestive of invasive lobular carcinoma.

They also show a single file pattern or Indian file pattern on histopathology. Immunohistochemically, lobular carcinoma is a special histologic type that comes under the luminal group, which means that they are ER-positive/HER2-negative. 

The most common genetic abnormality observed in the above lesion is loss of function of the CDH1 gene. The function of the CDH1 gene is to make E-Cadherin protein which makes the cell cohesive. Loss of function makes the cell dyscohesive. 

A histopathology image of invasive lobular carcinoma showing a single file pattern is given below.



Other options:

Option B- Phyllodes tumor arises from the intralobular stroma and on histology, it appears as increased stromal cellularity with typical leaf-like architecture as shown below.



Option C- Fibroadenoma is a benign breast tumor that appears as a delicate and often myxoid stroma that resembles normal intralobular stroma as shown below.



Option D- Medullary carcinoma of the breast appears as sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders as shown below.

questions.text: 138. A 1-week old infant born prematurely has frequent episodes of cessation of breathing lasting more than 20 seconds. There is associated bradycardia. What is the treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the clinical features is apnea of prematurity. Treatment includes administration of caffeine citrate.

Apnea of prematurity results from immature respiratory control and most frequently occurs in infants <34 weeks of gestational age. It is defined as cessation of breathing for longer than 20 seconds or for any duration if accompanied by cyanosis or bradycardia. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. It is seen in preterm infants and usually resolves by the 37th week of gestation.

A gentle tactile stimulation or provision of flow and/or supplemental oxygen by nasal cannula is often adequate therapy for mild and intermittent episodes.

Recurrent apnea of prematurity may be treated with caffeine or theophylline. Caffeine citrate is preferred due to its longer half-life and lesser side effects. A loading dose of 20 mg/kg followed by a 5 mg/kg/hr maintenance dose is used.  Apart from this, aminophylline can be given intravenously as a loading dose of 5-7 mg/kg followed by a maintenance dose of 1-2 mg/kg every 6-12 hours.

In apnea of prematurity, methylxanthines such as theophylline and caffeine increase the central respiratory drive by lowering the threshold of response to hypercapnia. They also enhance the contractility of the diaphragm and prevent diaphragmatic fatigue. 

Doxapram, which is a potent respiratory stimulant, can be used in those not responding to methylxanthines.

questions.text: 139. A 58-year-old lady with a previous history of breast conservation surgery presents to the OPD with complaints of hardness in the region of the scar. What is the best-suited investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
In a patient with hardness in the region of the BCS scar, an MRI must be performed to rule out scar recurrence. 

MRI  of the breast can be used in the following cases:

* To detect scar recurrence in women with a history of breast conservative surgery  

* To assess lobular cancer and high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)

* To assess multifocality and multicentricity

* Women with breast implants

* Women with BRCA or other genetic mutations or strong family history.

* Women with dense breasts or discordant or equivocal findings on mammogram/ultrasonography.

questions.text:
140. Which of the following are major criteria to diagnose infective endocarditis?

* Phase I IgG antibody titer for Coxiella >1:800

* Single positive blood culture for coagulase-negative Staphylococci

* New onset valvular regurgitation

* IV drug abuse

* Janeway lesions
questions.solution:
Phase I IgG antibody titer >1:800 for Coxiella and new onset valvular regurgitation are major criteria in the Modified Duke criteria for infective endocarditis.

Single positive blood culture for coagulase-negative Staphylococci (statement 2) is likely to be due to contamination of the blood culture sample during sample collection. One set of samples taken for infective endocarditis consists of 2 bottles of blood culture (one for aerobic and one for anaerobic culture).

Three such sets are taken from different venipuncture sites over 1-2 hours. At least two of these cultures have to be positive for the positive blood culture criteria to be considered positive in the Duke criteria. Antibody titers to Coxiella are included in the major criteria because it is difficult to recover the organism by blood culture.

Predisposing factors such as IV drug abuse (statement 4) and certain congenital heart diseases and vascular phenomena such as Janeway lesions are included in the minor criteria.

Pearl PM2026: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

* Pathologic criteria

* Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.



Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

* Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR

* If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text:
141. A 38-year-old African-American woman is at the risk of developing metabolic syndrome and has been suggested to switch to the Mediterranean diet which is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids. Which of the following describes the effect of monounsaturated fatty acids?

HDL - High-density lipoproteins LDL - Low-density lipoproteins

choices.text: Increase HDL + decrease LDL + decrease plasma triacylglycerol
Decrease HDL+ decrease LDL + decrease total cholesterol
Decrease HDL + decrease LDL + decrease plasma triacylglycerol
Increase  HDL + decrease LDL + decrease total cholesterol

questions.solution:
MUFA (Monounsaturated fatty acids) causes an increase in HDL levels and decreases serum LDL and total cholesterol levels. Plasma triacylglycerols remain unchanged.

The Mediterranean diet is rich in monounsaturated fatty acids (from olive oil) and n-3 fatty acids (from fish oils and some nuts), but low in saturated fatty acids. It contains seasonally fresh food, abundant plant material, low amounts of red meat, and olive oil as the principal source of fat. When substituted for saturated fatty acids in the diet, MUFAs lower both total and LDL cholesterol and increase HDL. This may explain why the Mediterranean diet, is associated with decreased serum total and LDL cholesterol compared with a typical Western diet high in saturated fats.

Unsaturated fatty acids contain one or more double bonds. These are classified into monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) and polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA). Unsaturated fatty acids lower blood cholesterol levels by the upregulation of LDL receptors on the cell surface, causing an increase in the catabolism of LDL. Omega-3 (ω3) fatty acids also have an anti-inflammatory effect and decrease triacylglycerol levels.

Monounsaturated fatty acids (MUFA) contain a single double bond, Ex:

* Palmitoleic acid (ω7)

* Oleic acid (ω9)

* Elaidic acid (ω9)

Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) are divided into two types based on the position of double bonds (when counted from the methyl end of the fatty acid molecule)

* ω-3 fatty acids: The first double bond is at the third carbon atom

* ω-6 fatty acids: The first double bond is at the sixth carbon atom

PUFA lowers plasma cholesterol and LDLs, but HDLs, which protect against coronary heart disease, are also lowered.

questions.text:
142. A 28-year-old woman presents with painful menses and pain during intercourse. Per vaginal examination revealed a normal-sized uterus and tenderness in the lateral fornices. A speculum examination revealed bluish puckered spots in the posterior fornix. What is the gold standard investigation for this condition?

TVS - Transvaginal sonogram

TAS - Transabdominal sonogram

MRI - Magnetic resonance imaging
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with symptoms of dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea is most likely suffering from endometriosis. The presence of puckered spots in the posterior fornix is pathognomonic of endometriosis. Laparoscopy is the gold standard for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis.

Endometriosis is a condition that is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue in ectopic sites such as:

* Ovary (chocolate cysts- left/right lower quadrant pain)

* Pouch of Douglas (pain during defecation)

* Uterosacral ligaments (chronic pelvic pain & infertility)

* Appendix (right lower quadrant pain)

* Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar endometriosis

* Umbilicus

* Lung (cyclical hemoptysis)

These extra-uterine sites of endometrial tissue are influenced by cyclical changes in the hormone levels which give rise to location-specific symptoms as mentioned above.

Management:

Investigations include:

* USG: TVS will show a chocolate cyst.

* MRI

* CA-125 more than 35 U/mL

* Laparoscopy: Gold standard for the diagnosis and treatment of endometriosis. It is used to locate the sites, take a biopsy and surgically remove the deposits.

Drugs used for symptom control include the following:

* Oral contraceptive pills

* Mirena IUD

* GnRH analogs

* Letrozole

Surgical management includes:

Minimally invasive surgery may be used to destroy the tissue by cautery, laser vaporization, and lyse adhesions that have formed as a complication of endometriosis.

Major surgical measures include incision of chocolate cyst and removal of lining, salpingo-oophorectomy, hysterectomy, and unilateral or bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy.

Pearl PM1005: Endometriosis

Sites of Endometriosis:

* Pelvic endometriosis: Pelvic peritoneum, the pouch of Douglas, uterosacral ligament.

* Rectovaginal endometriosis.

* Ovarian endometriosis.

* Chocolate cyst of the ovary.

* Other sites—appendix, pelvic lymph nodes.

* Metastatic— lungs, umbilicus, scar endometriosis.

One pathology review revealed that endometriosis has been identified on all organs except the spleen.

Examination findings in endometriosis:

* Abdomen: Cystic swelling, fixed and tender.

* Pelvis: Cystic tender mass.

* Vaginal examination: Fixed, tender, retroverted uterus. Tenderness in the lateral fornices (indicative of endometriosis even if no mass).

* Speculum inspection of the Posterior fornix: Bluish/blackish puckered spots on speculum, tender to touch. The presence of puckered spots is pathognomonic of endometriosis.

* Posterior Fornix Palpation: Uterosacral ligaments & pouch of Douglas feel thickened and shotty with multiple small palpable nodules. This is called the cobblestone feel of uterosacral ligaments.

questions.text: 143. An ENT surgeon is performing mastoid surgery on a patient through an endaural approach. The surgeon would cut through which of the following parts of pinna for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The area between the tragus and crux of the helix is called the incisura terminalis (marked 2). The mastoid is endaurally approached through this structure as it is devoid of cartilage. 

The parts of the pinna are depicted in the image below.



The ear can be surgically approached in three ways - endomeatal, endaural, and postaural approaches.

The mastoid is endaurally approached through Lempert's incision. 

Lempert I - It is a semicircular incision made from the 12 o'clock to 6 o'clock position in the posterior meatal wall at the bony-cartilaginous junction.

Lempert II - Starts from the first incision at 12 o'clock and passes through the incisura terminalis and does not cut the cartilage. 

It is used for :

* Excision of osteomas or exostosis of the ear canal

* Large tympanic membrane perforations

* Attic cholesteatomas

* Modified radical mastoidectomy



In endomeatal or transcanal approach Rosen’s incision is used. It is used for stapedectomy, exploratory tympanotomy to find the cause of conductive hearing loss, inlay myringoplasty, and ossicular reconstruction.

It consists of two parts:

* A small vertical incision at 12 o’clock position near the annulus.

* A curvilinear incision starting at 6 o’clock position to meet the first incision in the posterosuperior region of the canals, 5–7 mm away from the annulus.



Wilde’s incision is used in postaural approach. It starts at the highest attachment of the pinna and follows the curve of retroauricular groove, lying 1 cm behind it. The incision ends at the mastoid tip

questions.text: 144. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the benefits under Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY)?

choices.text: It provides health insurance of upto Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year
No cap on family size and age of members
Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services

questions.solution:
Under Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), all pre-existing diseases are also covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.

Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PM-JAY), the largest health assurance scheme in the world which aims at providing a health cover of Rs. 5 lakhs per family per year for secondary and tertiary care across public and private empanelled hospitals in India, to over 12 crores poor and vulnerable families 

Benefits under the scheme:

* The government provides health insurance coverage of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year(Option B).

* All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per the defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members (Option C).

* Priority is given to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.

* Free treatment is available at all public and empaneled private hospitals in times of need.

* It covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.

* 1,929 procedures covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, the cost of medicines, and diagnostics.

* It covers up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days of post-hospitalization expenses such as diagnostics and medicines

* All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.

* Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services (Option D).

* Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.

questions.text: 145. A patient presents with complaints of drooling of saliva and deviation of the angle of the mouth. Bell's Palsy is suspected. When the patient is asked to close the affected eye, the sign given in the image below can be seen. What is the likely cause?

choices.text: Left sided LMN type of facial nerve palsy
Right sided LMN type of facial nerve palsy
Left sided UMN type of facial nerve palsy
Right sided UMN type of facial nerve palsy

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario history of drooling of saliva, deviation of the angle of the mouth, and the image showing Bell's phenomenon of left eye are suggestive of a left-sided LMN type of facial nerve palsy. It presents with an inability to close the eye, and when the patient attempts to close the eye, eyeball turns up and out. This is known as the Bell's phenomenon.

Bell's palsy is an acute onset idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis. It is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Other features include drooling of saliva and facial asymmetry. There may be noise intolerance and a loss of taste sensation.

Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigations. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. Tape to depress the upper eyelid during sleep and artificial tears can be used to prevent corneal drying. Most patients recover within a few weeks or months.

The following image shows a patient with Bell's palsy.

questions.text: 146. A 21-year-old man often remains alone, has few friends, always dresses in black, and prefers solitary activities. He says that he can read people's minds and believes in cleansing his aura by energizing crystals. Which cluster of personality disorders does this person belong to?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of the patient's odd and eccentric beliefs and magical thinking is suggestive of schizotypal personality disorder. Schizotypal personality is classified as a cluster A personality disorder.

A schizotypal personality disorder is a cluster A personality disorder. It is characterized by strange perceptions, disturbed thinking, and behavior. They usually lack friends due to poor interpersonal relationships. They tend to have magical thinking, bizarre fantasies, and preoccupations, such as excessive superstition, beliefs that they have superpowers, etc. They have peculiar speech and eccentric appearances. They can be differentiated from schizophrenia by the lack of psychotic features.

questions.text: 147. During an ophthalmoscopic examination of a patient in bright light, you notice a finding similar to that of 'A' in the given image. The same patient is made to sit in a dark room and a subsequent examination reveals you a fundus similar to that of 'B'. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a comparison in the fundus appearances ("A" shows the golden yellow color of the fundus in a light-adapted state; "B" shows a normal-appearing fundus after prolonged dark adaptation of 3 to 4 hours). The fundus has an unusual golden yellow colour in the light-adapted state, which becomes normal after prolonged dark adaptation is called Mizuo or Mizuo–Nakamura phenomenon. 

Mizuo phenomenon is seen in Oguchi's disease. 

Oguchi's disease is a type of congenital stationary night blindness with abnormal fundus. Rod function is absent even after 30 minutes of dark adaptation (normal dark adaptation time is 20–30 mins) but recovers to a near-normal level after a long period of dark adaptation (4 hours).

Congenital stationary night blindness refers to a group of disorders characterized by infantile-onset nyctalopia but non-progressive retinal dysfunction.

questions.text: 148. The following image depicts a biotechnology process. Choose the false statement regarding it.

choices.text: Hybrid cells lack the enzyme hypoxanthine phosphoribosyl transferase
Specific antibody-producing cells are integrated with myeloma cells
Hybrid cells are cultured in HAT medium

questions.solution:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology. Myeloma cells (not hybrid cells) are deficient in the enzyme HPRT (Hypoxanthine phosphoribosyl transferase).

Monoclonal antibodies refer to the antibodies produced by a group of lymphocytes that produce antibodies against a single antigen. These antibodies are produced by hybridoma technology. 

In this technology, the B-lymphocytes of mice spleen are immunized with an antigen to produce specific antibody. These specific antibody-producing B lymphocytes are then fused with myeloma cells that can multiply indefinitely.

The myeloma cells are deficient in the hypoxanthine-guanine-phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) gene and do not produce immunoglobulins. Therefore, the resulting hybrid cell is producing antibodies against a single antigen indefinitely. These hybrid cells are cultured in a HAT medium (containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine) and the monoclonal antibodies are obtained.

questions.text: 149. Surgical consultation is planned for a neonate in the neonatal intensive care unit. On examination, the following findings were found along with a bifid uvula. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this child?

choices.text: Cleft soft palate repair at 9 to 12 months
Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months
Cleft soft and hard palate repair at 12-15 months

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient would be cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months. 

As the neonate in question has a unilateral right-sided cleft lip along with cleft hard and soft palate, the appropriate management for this patient would be (two separate procedures):

* Cleft lip and soft palate repair at 5 to 6 months, followed by 

* Hard palate repair with or without a revision surgery for the lip and soft palate at 15 to 18 months.

The different types of facial clefts are shown below:



* Unilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement

* Bilateral cleft lip with alveolar involvement

* Unilateral cleft lip associated with cleft palate

* Bilateral cleft lip and palate

* Cleft palate only

Clefts of the lip, alveolus, and hard and soft palate are the common congenital anomalies of the orofacial structures.

Cleft-lip repair techniques:

* Millard’s rotation advancement technique (most common)

* Thompson

* Le Mesurier

* Tennison–Randall

Techniques of hard palate closure include the use of the following:

* Unipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the Wardill-Veau-Kilner repair 

* Bipedicled hard palate mucoperiosteal flaps as in the von Langenbeck repair

questions.text: 150. A 35-year-old male was brought to the casualty after a road traffic accident. He presented with pallor, cold sweats, weakness, lightheadedness, thirst, and rapid breathing. On examination, he was found to be mildly anxious and confused, with several bruises and lacerations in his limbs, a heart rate of 132 bpm, and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. Based on the clinical signs, what is the estimated percentage of blood loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features showing mild tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotensive with anxiety and confusion are suggestive of Class III of hypovolemic (hemorrhagic) shock, where the percentage of blood loss is estimated to be 30 - 40 % ( ~ 1.5L).

questions.text: 151. Inhibition by Renshaw cells is being studied by a physiologist. All of the following are the properties of these cells, except:
questions.solution:
Feedforward inhibition is not a property exhibited by Renshaw cells. 

Renshaw cells are involved in feedback inhibition and lateral inhibition.

Feedback inhibition (Recurrent inhibition): Signals from neurons may inhibit themselves by negative feedback. This is known as feedback inhibition or recurrent inhibition. Signals from a neuron may stimulate the Renshaw cell, which in turn inhibits the same neuron.

Lateral inhibition: Stimulation of one motor neuron inhibits adjacent motor neurons. This is known as lateral inhibition. Signals from the spinal motor neurons stimulate Renshaw cells, which are inhibitory interneurons. Renshaw cells transmit inhibitory signals to the adjacent motor neurons, by releasing the neurotransmitter glycine. This helps in sharpening signals in order to maintain the desired direction of signal transmission. 

Feedforward inhibition: Signals from neurons stimulate inhibitory cells. These inhibitory cells then inhibit a different group of neurons. This is called feedforward inhibition. For example, granule cells stimulate the inhibitory basket cells and stellate cells via parallel fibers. These basket and stellate cells then inhibit the Purkinje cells. This is known as feedforward inhibition.

questions.text: 152. Which of the following statements regarding the use of cardiac biomarker troponin for the workup of a patient with suspected myocardial infarction is false?

choices.text: Troponin should be measured at presentation
Troponin assay at 2-3 hours after symptom onset has poor negative predictive value
Troponin should be repeated at 3–6 h using conventional troponin assays
Troponin should be repeated at 1–3 h using high-sensitivity troponin

questions.solution:
Troponin assay at 2-3 hours after symptom onset has an excellent negative predictive value. This means that more than 2-3 hours after symptom onset, a negative troponin is sufficient to exclude a diagnosis of myocardial infarction.

In patients with suspected ACS, troponin is:

* Measured at presentation

* Repeated at 1–3 h using high-sensitivity troponin

* Repeated at 3–6 h using conventional troponin assays

Additional measurements of troponin beyond 3–6 h may be warranted when the clinical condition still suggests possible ACS or if there is diagnostic uncertainty. 

Cardiac-specific troponin T and cardiac-specific troponin I are the preferred biomarkers for detection of MI.

questions.text: 153. A 2-month pregnant woman undergoes a sonographic evaluation of fetal parameters. The parameter marked in the USG shown below best measures ____________.
questions.solution:
The parameter shown in the ultrasonography image is crown-rump length (CRL), which is the most accurate parameter used for the sonographic estimation of gestational age in the first trimester. It has an accuracy range of ± 5 days.

Parameters for estimation of fetal age

Trimester

Parameter

First

     Crown-rump length (CRL)

Second
  • Biparietal diameter (BPD)
  • Abdominal circumference (AC)
  • Head circumference (HC)
  • Femur length (FL) 

Third

      Femur length


Other options:

Fetal aneuploidy is assessed by measuring the nuchal translucency (NT) on ultrasound. It represents the maximum thickness of the subcuta­neous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overly­ing the fetal spine at the back of the neck. NT is measured in the sagittal plane between 11 and 14 weeks.

Fetal growth profile can be assessed by the ratio of head circumference (HC) to abdominal circumference (AC). In asymmetric intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR), HC/AC ratio is elevated. In symmetric IUGR, HC/AC ratio remains normal. Abdominal circumference is the most sensitive in detecting IUGR.

Fetal weight is estimated ultrasonographically by combining a number of biometric data like BPD, HC, AC, and FL using Hadlock and Shepard formulae.

It can also be calculated using Johnson’s formula which is the height of the uterus above the symphysis pubis in centimeters minus 12, if the vertex is at or above the level of ischial spines or minus 11, if the vertex is below the level of ischial spines — multiplied by 155, in either case, gives the weight of the fetus in grams.

questions.text: 154. A patient with 6 weeks of amenorrhea presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding per vagina and slight abdominal pain. A diagnosis of unruptured ectopic pregnancy was made. Baseline beta HCG was measured and medical management with 50mg/m2 of methotrexate was started (Day 1). The serum beta HCG level measured on Day 2 was more than the baseline beta HCG level. What is the appropriate management in this case?

choices.text: Measure beta HCG levels on day 4 and 7

questions.solution:
Following the administration of methotrexate mean beta hCG levels may rise during the first 4 days followed by a gradual decline. Hence the next best step, in this case, is to measure beta HCG levels on day 4 and day 7.

Dose

hCG measurement Days 1(baseline), 3, 5, 7 Days 1(baseline), 4, 7

When to administer an additional dose (Option B)

If serum β-hCG level declines <15%, give additional dose; repeat serum β-hCG in 48 hours and compare with the previous value; a maximum of 4 doses

  
  • If serum β-hCG level does not decline by 15% from day 4 to day 7
  • Less than 15% decline during weekly surveillance
 


If the decline is ≥15%, the patient is followed up weekly till the levels fall to <10 IU/L. A repeat dose is required if the decline is less than 15% between days 4 and 7 - about 20% women would need a repeat dose.

 Medical management is preferred in the following cases:

* Low initial serum beta-hCG level (Less than 5,000 IU/L)

* Small ectopic pregnancy size (Less than 4 cm)

* Absent fetal cardiac activity

Other options

Option A:

Surgical management with salpingectomy or salpingostomy is done when:

Option C:

The next best step in the management in this case is to measure beta hCG levels. An alternative regimen with KCL is not recommended in this case.

questions.text: 155. A 22-year-old male patient presented with hematuria, pedal edema, and hypertension. He also gives a history of episodes of hemoptysis in the past. His renal biopsy showed crescent formation and a linear pattern of staining on immunofluorescence. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the renal biopsy findings are suggestive of Goodpasture syndrome also known as anti-glomerular basement membrane (GBM) disease. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.

In Goodpasture syndrome, antibodies that are directed against the GBM also cross-react with the basement membrane of the alveoli of the lung. This causes the characteristic clinical picture of pulmonary hemorrhage associated with renal failure. The antibodies are targetted against a peptide in the non-collagenous portion of the α3 chain of collagen type IV. In the kidney, anti-GBM antibodies lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which is characterized by the formation of crescents. On immunofluorescence, deposition of IgG and C3 is seen in a linear pattern along the GBM.

Other options:

Option A: Mutation of type IV (α5 chain) collagen is responsible for Alport syndrome, which presents with haematuria, ophthalmologic conditions (such as anterior lenticonus), and sensorineural hearing loss. This condition most commonly occurs as an X-linked dominant condition, and males express the full syndrome. Female heterozygotes typically present with just hematuria. Electron microscopy findings include a glomerular basement membrane with alternating portions of thickening and thinning associated with splitting the of lamina densa, known as a basket-weave appearance.



Option C: The typical sign of IgA nephropathy is episodic hematuria linked to the deposition of IgA in the mesangium. Recurrent episodes of macroscopic hematuria during or right after an upper respiratory infection, frequently accompanied by proteinuria, and persistent asymptomatic microscopic hematuria is the two most typical manifestations of IgA nephropathy. Mesangial and paramesangial dense deposits are seen on electron microscopy.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis) involves the upper and lower respiratory tracts and kidneys. A c-ANCA pattern with positive anti-PR3 antibodies is seen. A lung biopsy will show evidence of vasculitis and necrotizing granuloma formation, which is characteristic of this disease. Renal abnormalities vary from mild instances characterized by focal glomerular necrosis and isolated thrombosis of the capillary loops (known as focal and segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis), to more severe glomerular lesions featuring widespread necrosis accompanied by the proliferation of parietal cells, leading to the formation of crescents (referred to as crescentic glomerulonephritis).

questions.text: 156. Which of the following is a prescriptive screening?

choices.text: Screening of sex workers for HIV

questions.solution:
Screening for cervical cancer is an example of prescriptive screening.

Screening is defined as the search for an unrecognized illness in apparently healthy individuals by means of rapidly applied tests, examinations or procedures. In general, screening may be classified into two types:

* Prescriptive screening

* Prospective screening

The differences between them are highlighted in the table below:

  Prescriptive screening Prospective screening
Definition It is the screening test done in an individual for his/her own benefit It is the screening test done in an individual for the benefit of others
Purpose To detect cases and start the appropriate treatment To control disease spread by isolating the individual and providing treatment
Request for screening There is no specific request by the patient/individual. The physician responsible for the patient's care decides to perform the test. Specific requests come from to screen certain individuals.
Examples

Screening for:
- Bacteriuria in pregnancy
- Breast/cervical cancer
- Urine for sugar
- Deafness in children
- Iron deficiency anemia
- Pulmonary tuberculosis
- Newborn screening

 Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases to protect the population in the home country like screening of travellers coming from China, under request from the government to prevent the transmission of coronavirus to the Indian population.
-Screening of sex workers for HIV to prevent transmission of HIV to others
- Screening of blood donors to prevent transmission of infection to the recipient.

questions.text: 157. The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of the drug of choice for actinomycosis.
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for actinomycosis is Penicillin, which is a beta lactam.Beta lactams act on step 4 in the given image.

Mechanism of action of beta-lactams: They are the cell wall synthesis inhibitor. The β-lactam antibiotics inhibit this last step in peptidoglycan synthesis. They inhibit the enzyme transpeptidase which is required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan chain. Transpeptidases cleave the terminal D-alanine of the peptide chains and form cross-linkages between them. This cross-linking provides rigidity and stability to the cell wall.   

Transpeptidases and other related proteins constitute penicillin-binding proteins(PBP) and, are located in the bacterial cell membrane. β-lactam antibiotics are bactericidal. This is because bacterias swell and burst due to deficient cell walls when they divide in the presence of β-lactam antibiotics. Penicillins, cephalosporins, monobactams, and carbapenems are examples of β-lactam antibiotics.

Gram-positive bacteria are more susceptible to β-lactam antibiotics than gram-negative because their cell wall is almost entirely made of peptidoglycan.

Resistance to β-lactam antibiotics develops due to the production of the beta-lactamase enzyme and the development of altered penicillin-binding proteins like in methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). β-lactamases inactivate β-lactam antibiotics by opening the β-lactam ring. This could be overcome by using drugs that inhibit this enzyme. Examples of β-lactamase inhibitors are clavulanic acid, sulbactam, and tazobactam.

Other options:

Option A: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall and hence cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

Option B: Bacitracin inhibits step 2 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation in the cycling of the lipid carrier which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall. It is only given for topical application because of its severe nephrotoxicity when given systemically.

Option C: Vancomycin inhibits step 3 in the image. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking. It is used against MRSA and Clostridium difficile infection. Redman syndrome due to histamine release following infusion is an important side effect.

questions.text: 158. A patient with appendicular mass is managed by the Ochsner-Sherren regimen. After 24 hours, the patient complaints of increased abdominal pain. On CT examination the size of the mass is found to be increased. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Increasing the dose of analgesics and watch for spontaneous resolution.
Increasing the dose of both antibiotics & analgesics and watch for spontaneous resolution.

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient's condition is worsening, and the CT reveals an increase in the size of the mass. Immediate surgical intervention should be done in this patient.

Ochsner–Sherren regimen is indicated for patients with appendicular mass in whom conditions are stable.

The patient's temperature and pulse rate are recorded 4-hourly, and adequate fluid balance is maintained. CECT abdomen is done and antibiotic therapy is started. If an abscess if present, it is drained. Improvement is usually seen within 24–48 hours.

If the patient's condition deteriorates or if there is evidence of peritonitis, laparotomy is performed.

Criteria to stop conservative treatment of an appendicular mass:

* Rising pulse rate.

* Increasing or spreading abdominal pain

* Increase in size of the mass.

Pearl PM1318: Oshner Sherren Regimen

Principle :

* The inflammatory process is already localised and that inadvertent surgery is difficult and may be dangerous.

* It may be impossible to find the appendix and, occasionally, a faecal fistula may form.

* Antibiotic therapy should be given after performing CECT abdomen

* Abscess if present can be drained radiologically.

Outcome :

* Improvement in 24–48 h

* 90% cases resolve

* Failure should raise suspicion of Crohn’s disease and carcinoma. 

Criteria for stopping conservative treatment of Appendicular mass:

* Rising pulse rate

* Increasing or spreading abdominal pain

* Increasing size of the mass

questions.text:
159. Which of the following is true regarding MMUs (Mobile Medical Units)?

* Lab investigations like hemoglobin estimation and pregnancy testing are available.

* Distribution of essential drugs is done from MMU.

* One MMU is approved for a district with a population of 5 lakhs.

* IEC (Information, education, and communication) sessions are conducted by MMUs.

* MMUs cover remote urban areas as well.
questions.solution:
The true statements about MMUs are 1, 2, 4, and 5.

Statement 3 is false- According to the current guidelines, 1 MMU is approved for a district with a population of 10 lakhs, and not 5 lakhs. This limit can be relaxed in tribal and hilly regions that are more inaccessible.

Mobile Medical Units (MMU) is a major initiative under NRHM to provide a range of healthcare services for people living in remote, inaccessible, un-served, and underserved areas in both rural as well as urban areas, with the aim of taking healthcare services to the doorsteps of such people.

The staff of MMUs includes:

* Medical officer (MBBS only, preferably women): 1

* GNM (General nursing and midwifery): 1

* Lab Technician: 1

* Pharmacist cum Administrative Assistant: 1

* Driver cum Support Staff: 1

Clinical services are provided by a medical officer and team, whereas mobilization and outreach services are provided by ANMs and ASHA.

MMUs provide primary care services for common diseases (communicable and non-communicable), RCH services, screening tests, and referral to higher facilities and specialists as required. These include:

* Provide point-of-care diagnostics: Blood glucose, pregnancy testing, urine microscopy, albumin and sugar, Hb, vision testing, and RDT for Malaria.

* Collect sputum samples.

* Screen populations over 35 for hypertension, diabetes, and cancers annually.

* Undertake follow-up checks during the monthly visit and provide patients requiring drugs with a monthly supply (hypertension, diabetes, epilepsy)

* Undertake IEC sessions on a range of health topics:

* Improved preventive and promotive behaviors for maternal and child health, communicable diseases, including vector-borne diseases

* Educate the community on lifestyle changes, the need for screening for NCDs, and early recognition and appropriate referral.

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

* Government-operated MMU

* Operation outsourcing to an external agency. However, capital expenditure, drugs, and supplies are provided by the Government.

* Both capital expenditure and operational expenditure are outsourced to an external agency. However, drugs and supplies are to be provided by the Government.

questions.text: 160. A psychiatric patient with a history of bipolar disorder is brought by her relatives. They give a history suggestive of an acute manic episode. She is already on lithium therapy and the serum lithium levels are measured to be 0.2 mEq/L. What steady-state concentration will you be aiming to achieve in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing increased activity, energy, and euphoria with a decreased need for sleep is indicative of an acute manic episode for which a steady-state concentration of 0.8 - 1.2 mEq/L of lithium has to be achieved for adequate treatment.

Lithium is used in the management of bipolar disorder, and mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and blood levels in excess of this may cause symptoms of toxicity. Therapeutic drug monitoring is done by measuring lithium levels 12 hours after the last dose.

Lithium therapy for acute mania:

* Three individual 10-mg/kg doses of a sustained-release preparation administered at 2-h intervals.

* The sustained-release form is used to minimize GI adverse effects (e.g., nausea, diarrhea)

* Subsequent treatment may then be continued with Li+ carbonate.

Steady state-concentrations for therapy :

* For maintainance therapy in bipolar disorder - 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

* For episodes of acute mania - 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

* Toxic levels - >1.5 mEq/L

The blood sample for serum lithium estimation is to be collected after a time interval of 10-12 hours from the previous dose of lithium which is used to estimate the steady-state concentration.

Known significant side effects of lithium therapy include

* Polyuria-polydipsia (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus)

* Hand tremors

* Confusion 

* ECG changes

* Psoriasis

* Hypothyroidism

* Diarrhea

questions.text: 161. A 4-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days. Examination reveals a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly increased respiratory rate. His chest X-ray showed subglottic narrowing appearing like a steeple. Which among the following is not indicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child with a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low-grade fever, and increased respiratory rate and an X-ray showing subglottic narrowing appearing like a steeple is suggestive of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis). Parenteral cefotaxime is not indicated in its treatment.

The median age for laryngotracheobronchitis is 3 months to 5 years. It is caused due to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions. Patients present with low-grade fever,  barking cough, hoarseness of voice, and inspiratory stridor. 

The image below shows a steeple sign, seen in croup.



Treatment of croup involves:

* Racemic epinephrine nebulization - It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption from the interstitial space and reduction of edema. The indications for the administration of nebulized epinephrine are:

* moderate to severe stridor at rest

* the possible need for intubation

* respiratory distress

* hypoxia

* Oral dexamethasone - Indicated in all the grades of croup. Corticosteroids reduce laryngeal edema through their anti-inflammatory action. IM dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equal clinical effect. Corticosteroids should not be administered to children with varicella or tuberculosis as they may worsen the disease.

* A helium-oxygen mixture (heliox) may be considered for severe croup when intubation is being considered. Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %)

* Antibiotics are not indicated.

Most children that have croup can be managed safely at home. Indications for hospitalization:

* Progressive stridor

* Severe stridor at rest

* Respiratory distress

* Hypoxia

* Cyanosis

* Depressed mental status

* Poor oral intake

* Need for reliable observation

NOTE:

As the duration of action of racemic epinephrine is only less than 2 hours, it is mandatory to place the patient on observation for 2-3 hours to watch for the reappearance of symptoms. The patient can be discharged home if he has:

* No stridor at rest

* Normal air entry

* Normal O2 saturation

* Normal level of consciousness

* Received steroids

questions.text:
162. A new-born child was rushed to the neonatal ICU after he had been diagnosed with pentalogy of Cantrell. This condition includes all of the following midline defects except:

* Midline abdominal wall defect

* Microcephaly  

* Bronchial cyst

* Pericardial defect

* Intracardiac defects
questions.solution:
The pentalogy of Cantrell does not include bronchial cyst and microcephaly.

The pentalogy of Cantrell (POC) is a collection of five congenital midline birth defects. It involves defects of the heart, pericardium, diaphragm, sternum, and abdominal wall.

It can be complete or partial. Complete manifests as the presence of all five defects, while others may present with only partial defects. It is also called thoracoabdominal ectopia cordis, a condition where the heart is covered by an omphalocele-like membrane. 

The various components of the pentalogy are:

* Midline abdominal wall defect

* Anterior diaphragmatic hernia

* Cleft sternum

* Pericardial defect

* Intracardiac defects such as ventricular septal defect, Tetrology of Fallot

The pentalogy of Cantrell can be diagnosed at the first-trimester ultrasound. It may be associated with trisomy 13, 18, 21, and Turner syndrome.

Treatment is directed at the repair and reconstruction of the defects.

A fetal MRI is seen below seen in the picture below, showing the heart in an ectopic position (indicated by *). Eventration of a part of the liver at the midline (indicated by arrow) is also seen with a small thoracic cavity (t).

questions.text: 163. A middle-aged man who presented with malaise, fever, a cutaneous ulcer, and preauricular lymphadenopathy was diagnosed with tularemia. Which among the following is a vector that transmits the disease?
questions.solution:
The vector that transmits tularemia is a hard tick.

Hard ticks are ectoparasites of vertebrate animals. They mainly transmit tularemia, tick typhus, and Kyasanur forest disease.

The dorsal surface of a hard tick is covered by scutum which is made up of chitin. This is absent in soft ticks. The head of the hard tick is at the anterior end. 

Diseases transmitted by hard ticks are:

* Tick typhus (Rocky Mountain spotted fever)

* Viral encephalitis (Russian spring-summer encephalitis)

* Viral fevers (e.g. Colorado tick fever)

* Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g. Kyasanur Forest disease in India)

* Tularemia

* Tick paralysis

* Human babesiosis

Tularemia is a tick-borne disease caused by Francisella tularensis. It is a gram-negative bacillus and a category A bioterrorism agent. It is a disease of rabbits and rodents. The most common mode of transmission is by direct contact with rodents or tick bites. They manifest as flu-like symptoms with cutaneous ulceration and preauricular lymphadenitis.

Other options:

Option A- Soft tick mainly transmits Q fever and relapsing fever.

Option C- Blackfly mainly transmits onchocerciasis.

Option D- Sandfly mainly transmits kala-azar and oriental sore.

questions.text: 164. A mother brings her 6-month-old baby to your PHC with complaints of a lump in the axillary region. The child's immunization history is up-to-date. Examination revealed a tender lymph node of 2cm in the axilla of the infant. Adverse reaction to which of the following could be the likely cause of the baby's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lymphadenitis which is an adverse reaction to BCG vaccination.

At least one enlarged lymph node of size > 1.5 cm can be detected (mostly axillary), which can then develop a draining sinus over a lymph node leading to suppurative lymphadenitis. It occurs within 2 to 6 months after receipt of the BCG vaccine, on the same side as inoculation.

It usually heals spontaneously and is best left untreated, unless the lesion is. adherent to skin. In such cases, surgical drainage and local instillation of anti-tuberculous drug can be done. Systemic treatment with anti-tuberculous drugs would be ineffective. 

Other adverse reactions following BCG vaccination include BCG osteitis/ osteomyelitis, ulceration, and disseminated BCG infection.

questions.text: 166. You are conducting a study on bactericidal activity of immune cells. You find that defects in the metabolism of a particular amino acid lead to dysfunction of nitric oxide production. Identify the involved amino acid.
questions.solution:
The involved amino acid is arginine, which is required for the production of nitric oxide (NO).

NO is an inflammatory mediator synthesized from arginine by a calcium-dependent reaction catalyzed by NO synthase.

The given image shows the process of nitric oxide synthesis.



The co-enzymes of NO synthase are :

* FMN

* FAD

* Heme

* Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)

Three isoenzymes of NO synthase:

* eNOS (endothelial nitric oxide synthase): Found in the endothelium and plays a role in vasodilatation. It is calcium-calmodulin dependent.

* nNOS (neural nitric oxide synthase): Found in the neural tissue and acts as a neurotransmitter. It is calcium-calmodulin dependent.

* iNOS (inducible nitric oxide synthase): TNF-α, IFN-γ and bacterial endotoxins induce hepatocytes, macrophages, monocytes, and neutrophils to produce this enzyme. It is inducible and calcium independent.

Functions of NO:

* Vasodilator: NO activates the cytosolic form of guanylate cyclase. This increases cGMP, activates protein kinase G, inactivates myosin light-chain kinase and thereby produces smooth muscle relaxation.

* Macrophage bactericidal activity: Production of NO synthase is stimulated by bacterial lipopolysaccharide and IFN-γ released in response to infection. The NO formed combines with superoxide radicals from macrophages to form the OH radical which is highly bactericidal. 

* Inhibitor of platelet aggre­gation (by activating the cGMP pathway)

* Neurotransmitter in the brain.

Pearl PM2196: Amino Acid Derivatives

questions.text: 167. A 26-year-old man presented to the ED with a history of severe retrosternal chest pain. His serum cholesterol level was 380 mg/dL and LDL was 200 mg/dl. Despite appropriate resuscitative efforts, the patient did not survive. The given image shows his abdominal aorta at the time of the autopsy. Which of the following correctly describes the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a young patient with grossly elevated serum cholesterol and LDL >190 mg/dl, accelerated atherosclerosis (as shown in the image of the aorta), and symptoms suggestive of myocardial infarction, a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (type II hyperlipoproteinemia) is likely. In this disorder, there is a reduction in the activity of the LDL receptor. 

Familial hypercholesterolemia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused due to mutations that reduce the functioning of LDL receptors, the most common being a mutation in the LDLR gene itself. Physical findings present in some of the patients include tendon xanthomas (especially involving the Achilles tendons) and corneal arcus. These patients may have a myocardial infarction at a young age.

Diagnosis is usually established based on biochemical tests. LDL cholesterol >190 mg/dL or total serum cholesterol >300 mg/dL without any secondary etiology should point to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia. Homozygotes for the disease might have total serum cholesterol even up to 1000 mg/dL.

Treatment includes restriction of saturated and trans fats in the diet and high-intensity statin therapy. If adequate control is not achieved with statins alone, a cholesterol absorption inhibitor (Ezetimibe) or a PCSK9 inhibitor (Alirocumab, Evolocumab) can be added to the treatment.

questions.text:
168. A 7-year-old male patient presented with short trunk dwarfism. Findings of ocular examination are shown in the given image. The child was assessed and was found to be of normal intelligence, and a provisional diagnosis of MPS IV was made. Which of the following is least likely to be seen in this child?

MPS IV - Mucopolysaccharidosis IV
questions.solution:
The given image shows corneal clouding, which is a feature seen in mucopolysaccharidosis (MPS) IV. Impaired hearing is not seen in MPS IV. 

MPS-IV, also known as Morquio disease, is caused by a deficiency of N-acetylgalactosamine-6-sulfatase (MPS-IVA) or of β-galactosidase (MPS IVB). Deficiency of either of these enzymes results in defective degradation of keratan sulfate. MPS-IVA is usually more severe than MPS-IVB, with the adult height being <125 cm in MPS-IVA and >150 cm in MPS-IVB.

MPS IV is characterized by short trunk dwarfism and normal intelligence. 

Early symptoms of MPS-IV:

* Genu valgus

* Kyphosis

* Growth retardation with short trunk and neck

* Waddling gait

* Tendency to fall.

Impaired hearing is seen in all MPS except MPS IV. Visceromegaly and leukocyte inclusions are characteristically absent in MPS-IV.

Extra-skeletal manifestations include corneal clouding, small teeth with abnormally thin enamel, frequent caries formation, and occasionally cardiac valvular lesions. Life-threatening atlantoaxial instability due to instability of the odontoid process and ligamentous laxity are characteristic.

Management is by enzyme replacement therapy. A recombinant human GALNS enzyme replacement therapy elosulfase alfa is approved for the treatment of MPS IVA. Treatment has been shown to improve ambulatory mobility and decrease pain, but no effect on growth or skeletal dysplasia. There is no current specific treatment for MPS IVB.

Corneal clouding is absent in Hunter (MPS-II) and Sanfilippo (MPS-III) syndromes.

Note: As a general rule, the impaired degradation of heparan sulfate is more closely associated with mental deficiency and deficiency of dermatan, chondroitin, and keratan sulfate with mesenchymal abnormalities.

questions.text: 169. Which of the following is not an indication for damage control surgery?
questions.solution:
Serum lactate >5 mmol/L is an indication for damage control surgery.

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical:

* Inability to achieve hemostasis

* Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas

* Combined vascular, solid, and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury

* Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava

* Demand for non-operative control of other injuries e.g. fractured pelvis

* Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve):

* Temperature <34ºC

* pH <7.2

* Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)

* Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s

* Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s

* blood transfusion approaching 15 units

* Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental:

* Operating time >60 min

* Inability to approximate the abdominal incision

* Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centers on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries.

3 Phases  :

Phase I (Initial Exploration) -

This phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination.

Phase II (Secondary Resuscitation) -

This phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis.

Phase III (Definitive Operation) -

It consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. This phase typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Pearl PM2082: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection 2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination 3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit 4. Deﬁnitive surgery 5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 1: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room Phase 2: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination Phase 3: ICU care for resuscitation Phase 4: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair Indications for damage control surgery: Anatomical

* Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury

* Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava

* Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis

* Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

* Temperature <34ºC

* pH <7.2

* Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)

* Blood transfusion approaching 15 units

* Blood pressure <70 mmHg
