* Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

questions.text:
170. Choose the correct statements regarding "A" in the image shown.

* It is synthesized primarily in the liver

* It is a negative acute phase reactant

* Mutations leading to its excess production are implicated in Wilson's disease

* It represses iron release from the macrophages

* Its deficiency is implicated in hemochromatosis
questions.solution:
The molecule represented as "A" in the given image is hepcidin. It is synthesized in the liver, represses iron release from the macrophages, and its deficiency is implicated in hemochromatosis.

Hepcidin is the key regulatory hormone that allows the liver to communicate with the bone marrow. It has anti-bacterial properties and derives its name from hepatic bactericidal protein. It is also called liver-expressed antimicrobial peptide (LEAP-1).

It is produced in the liver. It suppresses basolateral iron transport in the intestine and iron release from the macrophages and other cells by binding to ferroportin. It is a positive acute-phase reactant and its values strongly correlate with ferritin.

Hepcidin responds to liver-mediated signals, HFE, TfR2, and hemojuvelin. Mutations in hepcidin cause a form of hemochromatosis. It is excreted by the kidney and reabsorbed in the proximal tubules.

questions.text: 171. A 62-year-old male patient presented with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and polyuria. On examination, he has an altered mental state. His past medical history is significant for lung cancer, which is now in remission. The abnormalities in his blood reports are elevated serum calcium levels and low serum parathyroid hormone levels. What is the most likely type of underlying lung cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts the symptoms of hypercalcemia secondary to humoral hypercalcemia of malignancy (HHM)—a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with underlying squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

Hypercalcemia results from the ectopic production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) or PTH-related peptides.

Clinical manifestation of hypercalcemia:

* Renal - polyuria, polydipsia, nephrolithiasis

* Central nervous system - lethargy, altered mental status, stupor, coma

* Gastrointestinal - Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, peptic ulcer disease, pancreatitis

* Cardiac - bradycardia, AV block, short QT interval

* Skeletal - bone pain, pathological fractures

Treatment:

* Volume expansion by intravenous normal saline (200-500 mL/h)

* Forced diuresis using loop diuretics after sufficient rehydration

* Intravenous bisphosphonates (zoledronic acid, pamidronate)

* Others - Denosumab, gallium nitrate, steroids

Paraneoplastic syndromes may be the presenting finding or the first sign of recurrence of malignancy.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with lung cancer:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC)
  • Hypercalcemia of malignancy
  • SIADH
Small cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) 
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Eaton-Lambert syndrome
  • Retinal blindness
Adenocarcinoma 
  • Hypertrophic primary osteoarthropathy
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC)
  •  Clubbing


Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is associated with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Although SIADH presents with fatigue, nausea, and confusion, it also presents with hyponatremia, which is detected on laboratory investigations (not seen in this patient).

questions.text: 172. A 28-year-old man, homozygotic for atypical pseudocholinesterase, is set to undergo surgery. The response expected in this patient on administering succinylcholine and the dibucaine number would be:

choices.text: Prolonged duration of action, Dibucaine number 80
Prolonged duration of action, Dibucaine number 20
Shorter duration of action, Dibucaine number 80
Shorter duration of action, Dibucaine number 20

questions.solution:
The response expected in this patient on administering succinylcholine would be a prolonged duration of action of succinylcholine and a dibucaine number of 20.

This is due to the presence of homozygous atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme in this patient.

Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant that is rapidly metabolized by pseudocholinesterase into succinylmonocholine as soon as it enters the circulation. 

Simultaneously, succinylcholine molecules diffuse away from the neuromuscular junction, the net effect being a reduced duration of action of succinylcholine.

Abnormal pseudocholinesterase enzyme resulting from homozygous or heterozygous gene defects, cannot metabolise succinylcholine efficiently, leading to a prolonged duration of action.

In patients heterozygous for the atypical pseudocholinesterase, the duration of action is prolonged modestly (2-20minutes) whereas in homozygotes it may be prolonged up to 4-8 hours.

Dibucaine is a local anaesthetic that inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase activity by about 80% but inhibits atypical enzyme activity by only 20% and the percentage of inhibition of pseudocholinesterase activity is called the dibucaine number. It is a measure of pseudocholinesterase function.

Therefore, a patient with normal pseudocholinesterase has a dibucaine number of 80 and a patient with homozygous abnormal pseudocholinesterase will have a dibucaine number of 20.

questions.text: 173. A middle-aged woman presents with excruciating pain in her lips, gums, and cheeks for the past 6 months. The pain is usually triggered by talking and brushing her teeth. Each pain episode lasts for 1-2 minutes. On examination, there is no sensory loss over the face. Which of the following is the first-line management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. The first-line management of this patient is carbamazepine.

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin and, rarely ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. It is also known as tic douloureux (a painful condition of the face). It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. 

The large myelinated fibers of the trigeminal nerve carry tactile stimuli from the face and do not carry pain fibers themselves. In trigeminal neuralgia, due to compression or other pathologies, the large fibers undergo demyelination. These demyelinated large fibers become hyperexcitable and electrically coupled with the surrounding smaller unmyelinated pain fibers of the trigeminal nerve. This explains why tactile stimulation of trigger zones (lips, gums, cheek, or chin) leads to pain paroxysms. Symptoms occur due to ectopic generation of action potentials in pain-sensitive afferent fibers of the trigeminal nerve root just before entering the pons.

The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, smiling, washing the face, brushing teeth, or exposure to wind. On examination, the physician will not find any sensory loss over the area. The pain usually lasts for seconds or minutes. The intensity of pain is severe, so much so that the patient winces. Therefore it is called a 'tic'.

Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, Phenytoin, Topiramate, or Gabapentin are other options that may be tried if Carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Differential diagnoses of trigeminal neuralgia include:

* Migraine and cluster headaches - They tend to have deep-seated and continuous pain while trigeminal neuralgia has more of a superficial stabbing quality pain and is episodic. 

* Short-lasting unilateral headache with conjunctival tearing (SUNCT) - It will typically present with unilateral conjunctival congestion, tearing, and nasal stuffiness. 

* Temporal arteritis - It will usually be accompanied by myalgias and signs of systemic inflammation. ESR and CRP will be elevated.

* If trigeminal neuralgia develops in a young patient or is bilateral, a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis should be considered. In such cases, the cause of the pain is a demyelinating plaque near the entry point of the trigeminal nerve in the pons.

questions.text:
174. A 58-year-old male patient was found to have a BP of 146/94 mmHg. His laboratory findings are given below. Which of the following will be the most appropriate anti-hypertensive for this patient?

Fasting blood sugar: 200 mg/dL

Post-prandial blood sugar: 320 mg/dL

HbA1C: 9%
questions.solution:
The most appropriate anti-hypertensive drug for this patient would be telmisartan. Telmisartan has PPARγ agonistic activity, leading to improved insulin sensitivity in patients with diabetes mellitus.

By acting as an agonist on PPARγ receptor, telmisartan regulates the downstream glucose and lipid metabolism. It increases basal and insulin-stimulated uptake of glucose into the adipocytes via GLUT-4. It also decreases the amount of reactive oxygen species and increases serum adiponectin. By these mechanisms, it improves oxidative stress and insulin resistance in patients with type II diabetes mellitus. Furthermore, it has been shown to reduce cardiac fibrosis and hypertrophy.

ACE inhibitors such as Lisinopril (option B) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are able to stop the progression of diabetic nephropathy in patients with diabetes mellitus. They are the first-line anti-hypertensive drugs in diabetic patients. However, because of its additional beneficial effects as described above, telmisartan is preferred.

Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic (option A) and amlodipine, a DHP type of calcium channel blocker (option D) offer no added advantage to the treatment of hypertensive patients with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
175. A medical officer working at a PHC refers complicated cases to a secondary or tertiary hospital. Which committee established this system of development of referral services?

PHC: Primary health center
questions.solution:
The development of referral services from the PHC to the secondary or tertiary hospitals was established by the Shrivastav committee. 

The Shrivastav committee was started by the ministry of health and family planning. Its goals were to provide training to health assistants that can be the link between the medical practitioners and multipurpose workers to form an effective health care team. It also suggested steps to improve the medical educational process based on the national requirements. 

The committee recommended that at least one male and female health care worker should be available for every 5000 population. For every two male and two female health care workers, one male and one female health assistant should be available at the sub-centre level.

As part of this committee, bands of para-professional and semi-professional health workers were formed. These individuals were part of the community already as postmasters and school teachers. They were trained to provide simple preventive and curative services to the community.  

Other options: 

Option A: The Chadah committee outlined the responsibility of block-level PHCs in the national malaria eradication program. They recommended one basic health worker for every 10,000 population. 

Option C: The Jungalwalla committee recommended the integration of health services from the highest to the lowest level and the elimination of private practice by government doctors. 

Option D: The Mudaliar committee recommended that district hospitals be strengthened by adding specialist services. They also added regional deputy and assistant directors to supervise district medical and health officers. They limited the population served by each primary health centre to 40,000.

questions.text: 176. A Brazilian tourist who has traveled to India on vacation presents with lesions on his chest and back. The lesions are shown below. On examination, no oral or mucosal lesions are found. Acantholytic cells are seen on the Tzanck smear. A histopathological sample is sent for further examination. Which type of blister is present in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the lesions seen in a Brazilian patient and acantholysis on Tzanck smear, without oral or mucosal lesions is highly suggestive of pemphigus foliaceus. It is characterized by a subcorneal blister.

Pemphigus foliaceus is a benign form of pemphigus, an inflammatory blistering disorder, that is endemic in Brazil and occurs sporadically in other geographic regions. This is a form of a subcorneal blister, where the stratum corneum forms the roof of the bulla. It is caused by autoantibodies that result in the dissolution of intercellular attachments within the epidermis. There is no involvement of the mucosal epithelium in pemphigus foliaceus but is rarely affected.

Lesions are most common on the scalp, face, chest, and back. Bullae are superficial and mainly present as areas of erythema and crusting. These represent superficial erosions at sites of blister rupture.

Other options:

Suprabasal blisters: A portion of the epidermis, including the stratum corneum, forms the roof. They are seen in conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris.

Subepidermal blisters: The entire epidermis separates from the dermis. They are seen in conditions such as bullous pemphigoid.

Junctional blisters: These are blisters at the basal lamina. This type of blister is seen in conditions such as junctional epidermolysis bullosa, bullous pemphigoid, and toxic epidermal necrolysis.

questions.text: 178. A 7-month-old infant was brought by the mother due to abnormal eye movements and developmental delay. MRI findings are shown in the image given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the axial T1-weighted MRI image showing the molar tooth sign at the level of superior cerebellar peduncles is suggestive of Joubert syndrome.

The molar tooth sign is a cardinal feature of the Joubert malformation. It is created by a combination of midbrain hypoplasia, along with an abnormally deep interpeduncular fossa and a failure of the superior cerebellar peduncles to decussate across the midline.



Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive neurologic disorder. It is characterized by cerebellar vermis hypoplasia. It is associated with hypotonia, developmental delay, ataxia, irregular breathing pattern, and abnormal eye movements.

questions.text: 179. The following structure (arrowed) is marked during an anatomy practical exam. Which of the following structure contains the same type of white matter fiber present in the marked structure?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the corpus callosum which contains the commissural fibres. Among the given options, the commissure of the fornix/ Hippocampal commissure is made up of commissural fibres.

The locations of the commissural fibres are:

* Corpus callosum- Medial surface of the brain

* Anterior commissure- Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum

* Posterior commissure- In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland

* Habenular commissure- In the superior lamina of the pineal gland

* Hippocampal commissure- Between the right fornix and the left fornix



The fornix is a part of the connecting pathways of the limbic system. It arises from the hippocampus which wraps around the thalamus and ends in the mammillary body. It connects the hippocampus with distal brain sites. It is supplied by the anterior communicating artery arising from the anterior cerebral artery. 

The types of fornical fibres are:

* Association fibres: They connect the various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

* Commissural fibres: They connect the corresponding regions of two hemispheres. It is seen in the hippocampal commissure of the fornix. 

* Projection fibres: Some fornical fibres project to the anterior thalamic nuclei, ventral striatum, medial septum, and nucleus reuniens.

Uncinate fasciculus and the Cingulum contain long association fibres. Arcuate fasciculus/ U fibres have short association fibres.

Pearl PM2240: White matter tracts of the brain

They include

* Corpus callosum

* Anterior and posterior commissure

* Habenular commissure

* Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

* Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus

* Long association fibers:

* Cingulum

* Superior longitudinal fasciculus

* Inferior longitudinal fasciculus

* Fronto-occipital fasciculus

* Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)



Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

* Internal capsule

* Corona radiata

questions.text: 180. A 20-year-old fisherman presents with firmly adherent, black, gritty, hard nodules on the hairs of the scalp. He has no other complaints. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of black piedra. It is a fungal infection of the hair shafts caused by Piedraia hortae resulting in hard, dark, gritty superficial nodules. 

The fungus produces sexual spores in its parasitic phase. As the fungus grows into the hair shaft, the hair may fracture easily. 

Shaving or cutting the hair effects a cure and to prevent a recurrence, antifungal preparation such as benzoic acid ointment is used.  

Option B: Trichosporon beigelli causes white piedra or trichosporosis nodosa.

Option C: Hortaea werneckii causes tinea nigra.

Option D: Aspergillus niger causes otomycosis.

Image: Black piedra- formation of superficial, dark, and gritty nodules



Image: White Piedra - formation of superficial, soft, white, grey, or brown nodules.

questions.text: 181. HMG CoA is not an intermediate in which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, tyrosine catabolism does not have HMG CoA as an intermediate.

Tyrosine produces homogentisic acid as an intermediate during catabolism, which is converted to fumerylacetoacetate by homogentisic acid oxidase. Fumerylacetoacetate is further hydrolyzed to form fumarate (glucogenic) and acetoacetate (ketogenic).

Other options:

Option A: HMG-CoA is reduced to mevalonate by NADPH in a reaction catalyzed by HMG-CoA reductase which is the principal regulatory step in the pathway of cholesterol synthesis. It is the site of action of the cholesterol-lowering statins, which are HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors.



Option B: Leucine is a purely ketogenic amino acid. In the penultimate step of its catabolism, HMG CoA is produced which is acted upon by HMG CoA lyase to form acetoacetate + acetyl CoA.

Option C: Ketone synthesis is also known as ketogenesis. In this process, acetoacetyl CoA combines with acetyl CoA with the help of HMG CoA Synthase which is a rate-limiting step to form HMG CoA.

questions.text: 182. A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. In order to determine the resectability status, a CECT abdomen is performed. Which of the following vessels is not included in Varadhachary-Katz criteria for the resectability of pancreatic cancer?
questions.solution:
Inferior mesenteric artery is not included in Varadhachary-Katz criteria. This criteria considers the following arteries:

* Superior mesenteric artery (SMA)

* Common hepatic artery (CHA)

* Superior mesenteric vein-portal vein confluence (SMV-PV)

Abutment and encasement describe the tumor-vessel relationship based on a CT scan:

* Abutment- The tumor is inseparable from the vessel (contiguity) for ≤180° or ≤50% of the vessel circumference.

* Encasement- The tumor is inseparable from the vessel for >180° or >50% of the vessel circumference.

questions.text:
183. An 8-year-old boy is being evaluated for seizures. There is no history of weakness of any part of the body. A CT scan was done, and the image is given below. The characteristic sign depicted in the image is ______.

(MCA- middle cerebral artery)
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the CT image showing the bracket sign is suggestive of pericallosal lipoma. 

The most common site of lipoma in the brain is pericallosal region. Calcification at the periphery of the midline lipoma produces the characteristic bracket sign. Approximately 50% of patients present with seizures. Many cases are detected incidentally in utero by antenatal sonography.

Pericallosal lipomas can be grouped into two distinct types based on imaging:

* Tubulonodular

* Curvilinear

The tubulonodular variety is usually associated with more severe and extensive abnormalities and patients are symptomatic.

Other options:

Option B: The racing car sign refers to widely spaced lateral ventricles due to agenesis of the corpus callosum with intervening Probst bundles.



Option C: Hyperdense MCA sign- It refers to the hyperdense middle cerebral artery seen on non-enhanced CT images in acute stroke.



Option D: Dural tail sign: It refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumor, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases).

questions.text: 184. A 5-year-old child is brought with complaints of abdominal pain and gross hematuria. On examination, a large palpable abdominal mass is present. He is noted to have hypertension. Biopsy of the mass shows the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of abdominal pain, gross hematuria, large palpable abdominal mass, and hypertension with histopathological image showing triphasic cell types suggest a likely diagnosis of Wilms tumor.

Wilms tumor is one of the most common causes of childhood renal tumors and has a peak incidence at ages 2 and 5 years. It can occur in association with several syndromes such as:

* WAGR syndrome: Wilms tumor, Aniridia, Genitourinary abnormalities, and Mental retardation

* Denys–Drash syndrome: Gonadal dysgenesis and early onset nephropathy

* Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome: Organomegaly, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, omphalocele, and adrenal cytomegaly

Grossly, Wilms tumor occurs as a large, solitary, and well-circumscribed renal mass. Microscopically, you can see the classic triphasic cell types composed of blastemal, epithelial, and stromal cell types. The blastemal component consists of sheets of small round blue cells. The epithelial cell type consists of abortive tubules and the stromal cell type consists of fibroblasts. The histopathological slide is shown below:



Because of their primitive histologic appearance, the following childhood tumors are known as small round blue cell tumors:

* Wilms tumor

* Neuroblastoma

* Rhabdomyosarcoma

* Lymphoma

* Ewing's sarcoma

* Medulloblastoma

* Retinoblastoma

Other options:

Option B: Rhabdomyosarcoma is a malignant mesenchymal tumor that has skeletal muscle differentiation. It has four subtypes: alveolar, embryonal, pleomorphic, and spindle cell type

Option C: Neuroblastoma includes tumors that arise from primordial neural crest cells occurring in sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla. They can also present with hypertension and a palpable mass. However, histopathologically, they contain tumor cells arranged concentrically about a central space filled with eosinophilic fibrillary material (neurophil). This arrangement is known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes (shown below).



Option D: Medulloblastoma is a brain tumor that is one of the most common embryonal neoplasms. Histologically, they contain Homer-Wright pseudorosettes similar to neuroblastomas.

questions.text: 185. While working in a family planning center, you have been advising couples regarding contraceptive methods. The curious interns ask you to explain the pearl index mentioned in a learning poster in the clinic. Which of the following points related to this would be incorrect?

choices.text: It is a method to measure the contraceptive efficacy
Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions
Four months are deducted from total months of exposure for abortion
The number 1200 indicates the number of months in 100 years

questions.solution:
The option stating "Total accidental pregnancies do not include abortions" is the incorrect statement.

Total accidental pregnancies include every form of conception, like live births, stillbirths, or abortions, or the pregnancy that has not yet been terminated.

Pearl index:

It is defined as the number of "failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY)." It is a method used to measure contraceptive efficacy. This rate is given by the formula - 

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure.

Other options:

Total months of exposure in the denominator is calculated after deducting 10 months for a full-term pregnancy, and 4 months for an abortion.

The number 1200 in the formula indicates the number of months in 100 years.

There is a decline in failure rates with increasing duration of use with most methods of contraception but the Pearl index is usually based on a specific exposure (usually one year) and, therefore, fails to accurately compare methods at various durations of exposure.

Pearl PM1715: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).



* In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.

* In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

* It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.

* It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.

* Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: 186. For an epidemiological study, sampling was done as shown below. What is this type of sampling known as?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Simple Random Sampling.

In Simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has an equal chance of being included. Randomness here refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome. The picking of the elements happens through a lottery system.

In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn. In this image, no strata or groups are seen.

In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples. Here no such clusters are seen. Also in cluster sampling equal number of cases are taken from each cluster.

In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern for selecting the elements of a sample, like every fifth individual is selected. No such pattern is seen in the image.



Pearl PM1146: Sampling

1. Simple random sampling

* In simple random sampling, samples are drawn in such a way that every element in a population has equal chances of being included.

* Randomness refers to the method of picking the sample and not the outcome.



2. Stratified random sampling

* In stratified random sampling, the population is first divided into homogeneous groups, or strata. From these strata, random samples are drawn.

* For example, dividing a population into the strata of men, women, and children and then picking samples randomly from these strata.



3. Cluster sampling

* In cluster sampling, the population is divided into internally heterogeneous groups. Then a simple random sampling is done of these clusters and taken as the samples.

* In other words, the clusters are the sampling unit.

* This is usually done when large-scale simple random sampling or stratified sampling is laborious or expensive.

* This is the method used in assessing the immunization status of children.

* Cluster sampling involves a design effect, which is an adjustment to allow for design structure. It aids in the correlation between clusters.

* Multistage sampling is a form of cluster sampling, where sampling clusters are chosen from the already divided clusters.



4. Systematic random sampling

* In systematic sampling, there is a systematic pattern to selecting the elements of a sample.

* For example, every 3rd baby to be born can be selected.

questions.text: 187. You were posted for the forensic examination of victims of an airplane explosion, following an emergency landing. You decide to use Gustafson's method for age estimation. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the method?

choices.text: Root transparency is the most reliable criteria.
Age above twelve  years can be estimated.
Weight and length of the teeth are measured.
Nitrogen content of the enamel is  measured.

questions.solution:
According to Gustafson's method, root transparency is the most reliable criterion.

Gustafson's method of estimating the age of an individual is based on physiological changes in dental tissues. It is mainly useful in adults over 21 years of age (option B).

Gustafson’s criteria:

* Attrition - Gradual wear and tear changes of the occlusal or upper surface due to mastication

* Periodontosis -  Regression of gums and periodontal tissue surrounding the tooth, resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling

* Secondary dentin - Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity and gradual decrease in the size of the cavity

* Cementum apposition - Cementum increases in thickness near the end of the root due to changes in the tooth position. Secondary cementum deposition occurs continually and slowly, forming incremental lines.

* Root resorption -  Involves both cementum and dentin, which show characteristic sharp grooves 

* Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criteria. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals, and they become transparent gradually. Dentine becomes transparent due to rarefaction.

Other options:

Option C - Weight and height of the erupting teeth of a child are used to estimate the age of infants by Stack's method, not Gustafson's method.

Option D -  Chemical methods for estimation of the nitrogen content of enamel, which increases with age, are used for estimating the age beyond 25 years. It is not a part of Gustafson's criteria.

questions.text: 188. A middle-aged woman presents to the OPD with fever and malaise for the past 4 weeks. On examination, the following ocular finding is noted along with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. What is the likely causative agent for her condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing Romana's sign is suggestive of Chagas disease. It is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi.

Inoculation of T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless edema of periocular tissues in the eye is called Romana’s sign. This is classically seen in acute Chagas disease that lasts for 1 to 4 months.

Transmission occurs by the rubbing of the feces of the reduviid bug (Shown in the image below) into bite wounds or eye, blood transfusion, and transplacental spread.

Clinically, the infection course of Chagas disease is divided into acute and chronic phases.

In the acute phase, the majority of the patients will be asymptomatic. Fever, regional lymphadenitis, hepatosplenomegaly, chagoma (localized subcutaneous nodule at the bite site), and Romana's sign (unilateral swelling of the eyelids) may be seen.

Chronic Chagas disease is characterized by megaesophagus, megacolon, and myopathy.



Other options:

* Trypanosoma brucei causes African Trypanosomiasis (also known as Sleeping Sickness).

* Leishmania donovani is predominantly responsible for visceral leishmaniasis, also known as kala-azar but may also cause cutaneous leishmaniasis.

* Leishmania tropica predominantly causes cutaneous leishmaniasis

questions.text: 189. Which of the following women would not be diagnosed as having polycystic ovarian syndrome as per the Rotterdam criteria?

choices.text: 29-year-old woman with Alopecia & acne and cycles of length 40 days
31-year-old woman with an ovarian volume of 12 mL and cycles of length 42 days
23-year-old woman with ovaries showing 7 follicles of 1-2 mm diameter and hirsutism
27-year-old-woman with severe hirsutism, acne and a cycle length of 38 days

questions.solution:
Polycystic ovaries is defined as ≥ 12 follicles measuring 2‐9 mm in diameter and/or an ovarian volume > 10 mL in at least one ovary as per the Rotterdam criteria.

PCOS is an endocrinopathy seen in women of reproductive age, affecting multiple systems. Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose PCOD. The presence of two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis:

1) Irregular menstrual cycles, defined as:

* normal cycles in the first year post-menarche (due to pubertal transition)

* < 21 or > 45 days in 1-3 years post menarche

* < 21 or > 35 days or < 8 cycles per year > 3 years post menarche to perimenopause

*  > 90 days for any one cycle > 1-year post menarche

* Primary amenorrhea by age 15 or > 3 years post thelarche (breast development)

2) Clinical/Biochemical hyperandrogenism characterised by alopecia, acne, hirsutism

3) Ultrasound findings: (old criteria)

* Enlarged ovaries with ovarian volume ≥ 10 mm3

* ≥12 small follicles of 2-9 mm in size

The new International Evidence-based Guidelines for the assessment and management of polycystic ovary syndrome 2023 supersede the previous USG recommendations of the Rotterdam criteria. According to this guideline, these three factors should be considered accurate ultrasound markers for PCOS in adults:

* Follicle number per ovary (FNPO) - ≥ 20 in at least one ovary 

* If an accurate follicle count is not possible:

* Follicle number per cross-section (FNPS) - ≥ 10 in at least one ovary, or 

* Ovarian volume (OV) - ≥ 10 ml

PCOS can increase the risk for:

* Cardiovascular disease 

* Obstructive sleep apnea

* Gestational and type 2 diabetes mellitus

* Endometrial cancer

* Hirsutism

* Acanthosis nigricans

Pearl PM1151: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

* Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.

* LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.

* Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.

* Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)

* Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor

* DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated

* DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour

* Serum SHBG is reduced.

* Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.

* Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance

* Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases

* Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases

* Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)

* 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

* Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

questions.text:
190. A 16-year-old girl on a vegan diet undergoes her annual checkup. The results of her laboratory studies are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

* Serum ferritin: 10 μg/L 

* TIBC: elevated

* Serum iron: normal

* Percent transferrin saturation: 40%

* Peripheral smear: normocytic normochromic erythrocytes
questions.solution:
The given patient has reduced serum ferritin (normal 50-200 μg/L) and elevated TIBC, but with normal transferrin saturation (normal 30-50%) and normal RBC morphology. This indicates that she is in the stage of negative iron balance. 

The progression to iron deficiency develops in 3 stages. The first stage is the stage of negative iron balance. In this, the demand for iron exceeds the body's ability to absorb iron from the diet. This stage can result from a number of physiological mechanisms, like blood loss, pregnancy, rapid growth during adolescence, or inadequate dietary intake. Under such circumstances, the iron stores from the reticuloendothelial sites are mobilized. Thus, the body's iron stores level, which is reflected by serum ferritin, decreases during this phase. As long as the iron stores are present, the serum iron and RBC morphology remain normal.

When the iron stores become depleted, the serum iron and transferrin saturation begin to fall. Once the transferrin saturation falls below 20%, hemoglobin synthesis becomes impaired. This is termed as the stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis. Gradually, the hemoglobin begins to fall and the erythrocytes become microcytic and hypochromic, leading to the stage of iron-deficiency anemia.

  Negative iron balance Iron-deficient erythropoiesis Iron deficiency anemia
Marrow iron stores Decreased Decreased Decreased
S. ferritin Decreased Decreased Decreased
TIBC Increased Increased Increased
S. Iron Normal Decreased Decreased
Transferrin saturation Normal Decreased Decreased
Red cell protoporphyrin Normal Increased Increased
Red cell morphology Normal Normal Microcytic hypochromic


Pearl PM2420: Causes of Iron Deficiency Anemia

Dietary lack

* Infants, who are at high risk due to the very small amounts of iron in milk. Human breast milk provides only about 0.3 mg/L of iron.

* The impoverished, who can have suboptimal diets for socioeconomic reasons at any age

* Older adults, who often have restricted diets with little meat because of limited income or poor dentition

* Teenagers, who subsist on junk food

Impaired absorption

* Sprue

* Gastrectomy (Billroth II surgery)

Increased requirement

* Growing infants, children, and adolescents

* Premenopausal women, particularly during pregnancy.

* Economically deprived women having multiple, closely spaced pregnancies are at exceptionally high risk.

Chronic blood loss

* Menorrhagia

* Carcinoma of the cecum

* Hookworm infestation

questions.text: 191. The victim and accused in a rape case were brought to the forensic medical expert for examination by the police. Which of the following is false regarding the examination of the accused in a rape case?

choices.text: Presence of smegma in an uncircumcised accused is definitive proof against rape
Papanicolaou test is performed as a part of penile examination
Clothes, hair, saliva, penile swab, or blood stains are collected as specimens
DNA from victim can be recovered from penile swabs up to 24 hours after intercourse

questions.solution:
The presence of smegma is not definitive proof against rape. 

Smegma usually collects in 24 hours and is rubbed off during intercourse. Hence, its presence indicates that the person was not engaged in sexual activity in the last 24 hours. Nevertheless, it has no medicolegal significance since smegma may be preserved in cases of mere penetration of the vulva, which also legally constitutes rape.

Absence indicates sexual activity might have occurred in the last 24 hours.

Other options:

Option B: Papanicolaou test and Lugol's iodine test are performed as a part of the penile examination to identify vaginal cells.

Option C: Clothes, hair, saliva, penile swab, or blood stains are collected as specimens and are preserved.

Option D: DNA from victims can be recovered from penile swabs up to 24 hours after intercourse by short tandem repeat (STR) analysis.

questions.text: 192. A 78-year-old diabetic male patient presents with a week-long history of severe pain and discharge from the right ear and pain in the jaw while chewing. Examination reveals tenderness, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and granulation tissue on the floor of the external auditory canal. Which of the following can be used for diagnosis and follow up in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an elderly diabetic developing severe pain, discharge from the right ear associated with pain while chewing, multiple cranial nerve palsies, and the finding of granulation tissue in the inferior portion of the external auditory canal, is suggestive of malignant otitis externa. Gallium-67 scan can be used for diagnosis and follow-up in this condition.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an inflammatory condition seen in elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs due to pseudomonal infection. It is an infective condition and not a malignant condition. It mimics diffuse otitis externa associated with excruciating pain, discharge, and granulations on the floor of EAC. Bony erosion aids in the spread of infection. Facial paralysis is common. Multiple cranial nerve palsies can occur when the infection spreads to the skull base and jugular foramen. The infection can spread anteriorly into the temporomandibular fossa. 

Diagnosis: Severe ear pain associated with granulation tissue in the external auditory canal in a diabetic patient should raise the suspicion of malignant otitis externa. CT scan helps in detecting bony erosions and demineralization of the bones. Gallium-67 is more useful in the diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but cannot be used to monitor the disease as the test remains positive for a year or so. (Option B)

Treatment: The treatment of malignant otitis external would include control of diabetes, ear toileting to remove the discharge, debris, or granulation tissue, antibiotic therapy against Pseudomonas with fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins, beta-lactam antibiotics with/without aminoglycosides.

Other options:

Option A: Iridium 192 radioisotope can be used in brachytherapy to treat tumors by selectively delivering a cytotoxic dose of radiation to the tumor site.

Option D: Phosphorus 32 is used to label DNA and proteins.It has been used to treat polycythemia vera and certain types of leukemia.

questions.text: 193. As a pathologist, you receive a brain biopsy of the frontal cortex of a 66-year-old male, which shows the following on silver staining. The patient's case sheet shows memory impairment as the chief complaint. Which of the following conditions is this patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological sample from the frontal cortex shows a characteristic swelling containing cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous inclusions are pick bodies. It stains strongly with silver methods are found in Pick's disease which falls under the frontotemporal dementias.

Pick's disease is a form of Frontotemporal lobar degenerations (FTLDs) - tau where the affected cortical regions demonstrate progressive neuronal loss and reactive gliosis, along with the presence of cytoplasmic tau inclusions in neurons. Smooth contoured inclusions (Pick bodies) are seen in Pick's disease.

Like most neurodegenerative diseases, FTLD is associated with cellular inclusions comprised of specific proteins; the two most common patterns are those with tau inclusions (FTLD-tau) and those with TDP-43 inclusions (FTLD-TDP).

Dementia is defined as a disease process marked by progressive cognitive impairment in clear consciousness. Depending on the site of the cerebral lesions, the dementias are classified as cortical or subcortical.

Subcortical dementias are associated with movement disorders, gait apraxia, psychomotor retardation, apathy, and akinetic mutism. They include:

* Huntington's disease

* Parkinson's disease

* Normal-pressure hydrocephalus

* Vascular dementia

* Wilson's disease

Cortical dementias are associated with aphasia, agnosia, and apraxia. They include:

* Alzheimer's type of dementia

* Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)

* Pick's disease

Other options :

Option A: Alzheimer's disease is a β-amyloidopathy characterized by the accumulation of Aβ amyloid protein and tau deposition while FTLD-tau shows only tau aggregation and accumulation. Pick's disease is characteristic in that, the inclusions are smooth and contoured while other FTLD-tau show tangles which resemble the ones seen in Alzheimer's disease.

Option B: Dementia of Lewy Bodies is characterized by the presence of Lewy bodies, which is an eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion that contains both neurofilaments and alpha-synuclein. In addition to dementia, a patient with probable DLB must have at least two "core clinical features" of DLB: cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, rapid eye movement (REM), sleep behavior disorder (RBD), and parkinsonism.

Option D: Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging are noticed in vascular dementia.

questions.text: 194. Which of the following air cells is marked by the asterisk in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The marked area represents the floor of the orbit and Haller cells are present in that area.

Haller cells are an anterior ethmoidal group of hair cells that are present in relation to the floor of the orbit and roof of the maxillary sinus. Enlargement of these hair cells may prevent drainage of the maxillary sinus.

Ethmoidal sinuses are air-containing cavities that are present in the lateral mass of the ethmoid bone. They are bound medially by the lateral nasal wall, laterally by a thin plate of bone called the lamina papyracea, and superiorly by an extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone. 

The ethmoid sinusoidal air cells range from 3 to 18 in number and are divided into anterior and posterior groups by a basal lamina.

* Anterior cells- They open into the middle meatus. They contain-

* Agger nasi cells that are present in the agger nasi ridge.

* Ethmoid bulla that forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris.

* Supraorbital cells

* Frontoethmoid cells- In the area of the frontal recess

* Haller cells present in the floor of the orbit. 

* Posterior cells - They open into the superior meatus. Occasionally, they may also open directly into the sphenoid sinus. They contain about 1-7 cells, the most important one being the Onodi cells. The onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.

The image below shows Onodi hair cells.

questions.text: 195. A 20-year-old female patient is referred to a dermatologist for evaluation of vesicles and bullae and increased pigmentation over sun-exposed areas such as the dorsal aspect of the hands and forearms, legs and feet, neck, and face. On further evaluation, she is diagnosed with variegate porphyria. Deficiency of which of the following enzymes causes this disease?
questions.solution:
The cause of variegate porphyria is the deficiency of the enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase.

Variegate porphyria is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the PPOX gene, which results in either the deficiency or decreased function of the enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase. Protoporphyrinogen IX and other intermediates prior to the block accumulate in the urine. Patients are photosensitive.

questions.text:
196. Match the following variants of Reed-Sternberg cell with the corresponding subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma.

* Lacunar

* L&H Popcorn cells 

* Pleomorphic

* Mononuclear

* Nodular sclerosis

* Lymphocyte predominant

* Lymphocyte depleted

* Mixed cellularity and lymphocyte rich
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are as follows:

* Lacunar - Nodular sclerosis

* L&H popcorn cells - Lymphocyte predominant

* Pleomorphic - Lymphocyte depleted

* Mononuclear - Mixed cellularity and lymphocyte rich

Reed-Sternberg cell (RS cell) is the characteristic tumor giant cell of Hodgkin Lymphoma. It is derived from the germinal center B cell. It has a classic owl-eyed appearance due to the presence of a symmetric or mirror-image bilobed nucleus, with prominent nucleoli surrounded by a clear space. It has the following variants:

* Lacunar

* Classic 

* L&H popcorn cells 

* Pleomorphic

* Mononuclear

RS cells should be present in a background of non-neoplastic inflammatory cells like lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils, to make a diagnosis of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

The image given below shows the diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cell, with two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm, surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil.



The image below shows the Reed-Sternberg cell, mononuclear variant.



The image below shows Reed-Sternberg cell, lacunar variant. This variant has a folded or multilobated nucleus and lies within an open space, which is an artefact created by disruption of the cytoplasm during tissue sectioning.



The image below shows the Reed-Sternberg cell, lymphohistiocytic variant. Several such variants with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm are present.



Pearl PM0119: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)



Classic subtypes

* Nodular sclerosis 

* Mixed cellularity 

* Lymphocyte-rich

* Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

* Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

* Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich 

* Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 

* L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: 197. A 28-year-old woman with irregular periods was evaluated for infertility and underwent an endometrial biopsy. The histology image is given below. Which phase is seen here?
questions.solution:
The image depicts the secretory phase of the endometrium.

During menstruation, the endometrium goes through three phases, namely proliferative, secretory, and menstrual phases. Their histological features are given below:

 Features in secretory phase/ luteal phase:

* The secretory phase of the endometrium begins on the 15th day of the menstrual cycle and persists until the onset of menstruation.

* The epithelium shows subnuclear vacuolation (presumptive evidence of progesterone activity).

* Characteristic corkscrew-shaped glands and edematous stroma.

The image below shows secretory endometrium



Features in proliferative phase/ follicular phase:

* It begins when the regeneration of menstruating endometrium is complete and lasts until the 14th day of the menstrual cycle.

* The glands of the functional layer are simple tubules with regular epithelium.

* The basal layer of the endometrium and functional layer become more defined.

* Arteries become more coiled and spiraled and extend through the endometrium.

The image below shows proliferative endometrium



Menstrual phase: Glands shrink with prominent vessels and haemorrhagic spots.

questions.text: 198. A 35-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with incoordination, tremors, and impaired concentration. On examination, the abdomen is distended and the liver is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. The ophthalmic examination is shown in the picture. Which of the following is the gold standard test for the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wilson's disease with the ophthalmic examination showing a typical sunflower cataract and the gold standard test for the diagnosis of this patient is liver biopsy.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder of copper transport, primarily affecting the liver and brain (hence, it is also known as hepatolenticular disease). It occurs due to a loss-of-function mutation in the ATP7B gene. This gene encodes ATP7B, a copper-transporting ATPase, which is responsible for biliary copper excretion and incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin.

Clinical features of Wilson's disease are:

* Hepatic: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, ascites, cirrhosis, anorexia

* Neurologic: Dystonia, dysarthria, dysphagia, rigidity, tremors, abnormal gait, uncoordinated handwriting

* Psychiatric: Decreased scholastic performance, irritability, depression, and anxiety

* Ophthalmic:

* Kayser-Fleischer rings: These are golden-brown rings formed due to the deposition of copper in descemet’s membrane of the cornea. They are present in 95% of patients with neurologic/psychiatric symptoms and 65% of patients with hepatic symptoms.

* Sunflower cataracts: These are formed due to the deposition of copper in the lens.

* Autonomic: Orthostatic hypotension; sweating; bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction

* Endocrine: Delayed puberty, amenorrhea

* Hemolytic anemia (due to the release of copper from necrosed hepatocytes into the bloodstream)

* Osteoporosis and rickets

* Renal Fanconi syndrome

Laboratory findings show low serum copper and ceruloplasmin levels and elevated hepatic enzymes. Increased urinary excretion of copper (>100 μg/24 h) is also an important diagnostic test. However, percutaneous needle liver biopsy to measure hepatic copper remains the gold standard. Hepatic copper values >200 μg/g of dry weight indicate Wilson’s disease.  DNA testing for mutations in ATP7B can be done and can make a definitive diagnosis in about 50–75% of patients.

Treatment of Wilson's disease includes:

* Copper chelation:

* D-penicillamine: It increases urinary excretion of copper and prevents copper overload. Pyridoxine (vitamin B6 ) is administered along with it to counter pyridoxine deficiency that occurs due to penicillamine.

* Triethylenetetramine dihydrochloride: This chelating agent is given in patients intolerant to D-penicillamine and those with severe neurologic manifestations (D-penicillamine worsens neurological status).

* Tetrathiomolybdate: This fast-acting agent decreases copper absorption and circulating free copper. It is currently under clinical trials.

* Zinc acetate: This is used to reduce copper absorption. Zinc is beneficial in pregnancy (lower teratogenic effects) and as a maintenance therapy.

* Liver transplantation: This is considered in advanced stages of irreversible hepatic damage or poor compliance with medical therapy.

questions.text: 199. A senior resident asks you to incise and drain the abscess in a 20-year-old student during your surgery postings. Which of the following blades you would use for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The blade marked as '2' in the image, represents the 11 size-blade which is often used to incise and drain the abscess.

questions.text: 200. Identify the culture medium shown in the given image_________
questions.solution:
Lowenstein-Jenson medium is shown in the given image. It is a selective medium used for Mycobacterium tuberculosis culture.The presence of malachite green imparts a green colour and makes Lowenstein Jenson medium a selective media by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Components of LJ medium:

* Egg: Provide fatty acids and protein required for the metabolism.

* Malachite green: Prevents growth of contaminants.

* Mineral salt solution: Buffer.

* Glycerol: Source of carbon, Favours growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. bovis.

* L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen. 

Colony characteristics on LJ Medium:

Mycobacterium bovis forms moist, smooth, flat, white colonies on LJ media that break-up easily when touched. 

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, irregular colonies with a wrinkled surface, tenacious, difficult to emulsify, creamy white and buff-colored. (Rough, tough, buff). 

 

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

* Solid Culture Media: Lowenstein–Jensen: A commonly used, egg-based, selective media. contains malachite green, which prevents growth of other organisms.  

* Liquid Culture Media: Middle Brook’s media: Used for preparation of antigens and vaccines, and sensitivity testing. 

* Automated Culture Media: BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes, BacT alert: A colorimetric method, BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method. 

Other options:

Thayer-Martin medium is shown in the image below. It is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae because the antimicrobials present in it, suppress the growth of other commensal organisms which may inhibit the growth of N.gonorrhoeae. Thayer Martin Medium selectively favors the growth of Neisseria by inhibiting the growth of gram-positive organisms with Vancomycin, gram-negative organisms (except Neisseria) with Trimethoprim and Colistin, and fungi with Nystatin

Thayer-Martin medium contains antimicrobials like vancomycin 3.0 mg, colistin 7.5 mg, and nystatin 12.5 units per ml of agar, in chocolate agar.



Loeffler's serum slope is an enriched medium for the growth of Corynebacterium diphtheria.

Advantage of Loeffler's serum slope:

* Rapid growth(6-8 hrs)

* Best medium for metachromatic granules production

Disadvantage: As it is not a selective medium, if incubated beyond 6-8 hrs, it also supports the growth of commensals.



Liquid culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis: Middle Brook’s media, used for preparation of antigens and vaccines, and sensitivity testing.
